PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Discrimination against Women

To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purposes for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Anthony,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Cadman,Mr Connolly,Mr Hollis,Mr Newman and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatry Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, The Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of podiatry service for lower fixed income members of the community.

Podiatry is an essential health service especially in preventing greater dependency of older people. It would be much more cost effective to maintain the mobility of older people through adequate and effective services than to force them into premature institutional care.

The fees for repeated podiatry consultations to provide essential ongoing care are well beyond the means of pensioners. Considering that Department of Veterans Affairs' pensioners are entitled to podiatry care, and this scheme is already operating successfully, we strongly urge that this service be extended to cover all pensioners.

We believe this could be best achieved through including podiatry along with the existing concessions on the Health Care Cards. This would enable a flexible system of care through private practice, community health or rehabilitation services. It would also be essential in negotiations with the Podiatry Association to ensure assistance would be available to the housebound and those in institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3.The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitions reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

We, the undersigned students and staff of Bentley and Tuart Colleges, wish to bring to the attention of Parliament certain inequities in the Student Allowances Schemes which are at present forcing many students to abandon their T .A.E. studies as they do not have access to sufficient funds to enable them to live whilst studying full time. We respectfully point out that it is possible for a student to receive unemployment benefits and study for T.A.E. over a 2 year period. This situation necessitates a far greater government pay out than a one year allowance for 18 year olds to complete a full T.A.E.
We draw your attention to the regulations and their implications.
TEAS/ASEAS: REGULATIONS
1. Students attempting 'matriculation, tertiary orientation or other secondary level courses' (TEAS information, p.6) are not eligible to apply for Tertiary Education Assistance (TEAS)
2. Students who, having completed Year 10, enrol in diploma, certificate, advanced certificate, secretarial and certain pre-trade, post-trade courses are eligible for TEAS.
3. Students undertaking such studies (e.g. those enrolled in adult TEA courses at Bentley and Tuart Colleges) may apply for Adult Secondary Assistance (ASEAS).
4. TEAS is available to any student enrolled in an approved TAFE or other tertiary course. There is no age limit.
5. ASEAS, however, is available only to students who are 19 years of age or over at 1 January of the year of application.

6. When a complete breakdown in family relationships occurs and students are self-supporting, they must prove they have access to $1800 for the year of study in order to be eligible for Secondary Allowances Scheme-which is $871 at most and, as a living allowance, inadequate.
Implications of the above for students enrolled at the adult colleges, but under the age of 19 years.
1. Any student enrolling at the Colleges for a full-time course (i.e. 4 or more subjects) cannot receive unemployment benefit.
2. Student under the age of 19 cannot receive ASEAS although they might have been eligible for TEAS if they had enrolled in TAFE for non-matriculation subjects.

3. Many students enrolling at the Colleges left school at the end of Year 10. Of these, most have been employed or available for employment for 2 years. Were they 19, they would be able to get full ASEAS at the independent rate.

4. The decision to return to full-time TAE study thus seriously disadvantages a large group of students who are considered to be adult by every other criterion, and yet cannot claim an independent living allowance from the government.

5. The Secondary Allowances Scheme (SAS) is available to the parents of students under 19; however, this, at best, is only worth $871.00 p.a. and pre- supposes that the student is financially dependent on his parents. As this is means tested (cuts out when parental income exceeds $14,678 for one eligible child) many parents cannot apply.

6. It is the contention of this statement that this is an inequitable-and in many cases impossible-situation for many students. It is a matter of record that some parents refuse to support their children once they have left school, or are unable to do so. Some students are known to have left the College because no financial assistance was available to them.

We respectfully request urgent consideration of the anomalies occurring in student allowance regulations so that presently disadvantaged students desiring to better their employment opportunities through TAE study have access to a living allowance whilst doing so. Many students are being forced to give up study and take unemployment benefits as they can neither afford to continue studying, nor find employment.
Your petitioners therefore pray that urgent consideration be given to removing these anomalies and hardships.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (H.S.C.) subject in Secondary schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Department of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Construction of Railway Overpass, Port Augusta, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the railway crossing situated approximately 5 kilometers east of Port Augusta on highway one (the main highway between Adelaide and all northern and western centres of South Australia and continuing through to Western Australia) has once again been the sight of an horrendous accident.
This accident has caused two, possibly three fatalities.

Previous requests have been made by the city council of Port Augusta for the construction of an overpass, so that this section of the highway no longer presents a danger to the motoring public and those involved in driving trains over this crossing.
Permission for construction of this overpass has previously been refused and the situation has now become critical.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and approve construction of an overpass at this fatally dangerous railway crossing to avoid further loss of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully urge that the enabling legislation to protect the Franklin River in Southwest Tasmania be passed at the earliest opportunity.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of New South Wales respecfully showeth:

Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads; alcohol is a factor in 50 per cent of road deaths; alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol; alcohol advertisments are glamourous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Transcontinental (North-South) Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of certain citizens of the Northern Territory of Australia shows:

1. That the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of South Australia entered into an agreement on 7th December 1907, requiring the Commonwealth of Australia to construct the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway from Darwin to South Australia;
2. That the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway has not yet been constructed ;
3. That the construction of the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway is the linchpin for the further development of the Northern Territory of Australia;

4. That the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway will provide employment through construction work, steel production and manufacturing and it will assist in ensuring the defence and security of Northern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth of Australia commence and complete construction of the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the citizens of the city of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holden, respectfully show:
1. That the management of General Motors-Holdens have failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
2. That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:
'The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site', end of quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
3. That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holdens to retain its operations at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The serious implications for the Treasurer's economic strategy posed by the evident collapse of the Government's wages accord.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no more important matter for the national Parliament to debate today than the total ruins and disarray of the Government's wages policy. There is no issue which is more relevant to the success of the stated economic strategy of the Hawke Government than the successful implementation and maintenance of a wages policy. There is no area in which the failure of this Government to give an adequate lead in economic policy is more evident and has been more demonstrable. I quote and rely on no better authority than the speech delivered in this chamber by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the National Economic Summit Conference on 11 April. If one goes through this document carefully, one finds reference after reference to the central importance of wage restraint in terms of controlling the growth of unemployment, reducing the level of inflation and speeding up the volume and rate of economic growth. In that speech the Treasurer said, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Our principal strategy is based on expansionary fiscal policy, with our prices and incomes accord as a major anti-inflation instrument, supported by firm monetary policy.
He then went on to say:
. . . it is clear--
I ask the House to ponder these words carefully--
that at one level the prices and incomes accord is firmly in place.
He said:
An explicit agreement has been reached with the trade union movement . . .

On 11 April, the Treasurer in the Hawke Government said that an explicit agreement had been reached with the trade union movement on the question of prices and incomes and that an implicit agreement had been reached with the Australian electorate. I put aside for one moment the references in the Treasurer's speech to the expansionary fiscal policy. We will no doubt hear a lot about that tonight and we will be able to judge the performance against the rhetoric when we hear the speech of the Treasurer tonight. I also put aside for a moment-not because it is unimportant-the Treasurer's reference to a firm monetary policy, when it is already apparent that the Government is desperately trying to buy short term and unsustainable reductions in interest rates by running too loose a monetary policy. I leave those two things aside for a moment and concentrate on the central issue of this matter of public importance, and that is: Where does the Government's much vaunted, much celebrated, much talked about prices and incomes accord stand today, 19 May 1983, a bare 2 1/2 months after the election on 5 March? I take the House back to the election campaign and I once again quote the Treasurer, in a Nationwide interview, in which he said:

They say they cannot get on with the unions. They say the unions are bad boys, they are this and they're that. I just make this point Mr Howard, if you cannot get on with the unions and you cannot get income agreements you cannot legitimately parade yourself as a party with an economic policy which is believable . . .

I ask the House: What income agreements does the Labor Government today have with the trade union movement? What agreement does it have with the trade union movement today which enables it to come into this House and say, in the words of the Treasurer, on 10 February of this year that we have an economic policy which is believable. He went on to say:
The prices incomes agreement policy is a co-operative policy whereby the Government sits down with the people making income claims and looks at it in the totality of the economy.

How can the Government, how can the Treasurer, how can the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say that they are sitting down with the people who make the income claims when in reality the President of the body that makes the most income claims says : 'Mr Hawke did not talk to me about 3 per cent or 4 per cent. I don't know anything about 3 per cent or 4 per cent. He has not sat down and talked to me about 3 per cent or 4 per cent'. What a total gap, what an utter void between the rhetoric, the commitment, and the actual reality under this particular Government.

It was the overwhelming view of the National Economic Summit Conference, not only of the people from all sections of the Australian community who participated in it but also the economic evidence presented to the Summit by the Treasurer on behalf of the Government that the major domestic cause of unemployment in Australia at the present time had been the excessive rate of increase in wages. Although there is disagreement between political parties as to the causes of that excessive rate of increase in wages, there is certainly no disagreement that that is the major domestic cause of unemployment and the level of unemployment that we have at the present time. That was the view that was adopted by speaker after speaker. All of the economic scenarios presented to the Summit by the Treasurer had a number of common threads. One of those common threads undeniably was that the greater the wage restraint, the better the inflation outcome, the better the employment outcome and the greater the economic growth. That cannot be denied on any objective analysis and reading of that material.

The Labor Party's constant theme since its election and before its election has been to say to us: 'Leave it to this special relationship that we have with the trade union movement. Leave it to us. We will get them all around the table and we will get these problems sorted out'. I say again: What sort of special relationship has the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions with the Labor Prime Minister when he said as recently as a couple of days ago that the Prime Minister had never spoken to him about a 3 per cent or 4 per cent increase in wages? Quite clearly, the ACTU and the Labor Government will argue different cases to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. What evidence does that constitute of accord, agreement, understanding and consensus with the trade union community in Australia? Indeed, there are so many quotations from the President of the ACTU one hardly knows where to begin. But, perhaps I can begin with Mr Dolan's quote of yesterday. He said:

Ah well, I don't think we had any consensus with employers and (um you know) the Summit communique did not indicate a consensus with employers on the amount of wage movement or when that wage movement would take place.
I repeat that-
. . . did not indicate a consensus with employers on the amount of wage movement or when that wage movement would take place.

The President of the ACTU said that on 18 May. Where does that leave the much vaunted accord, understanding and consensus with the trade union movement? Where does that leave the special relationship between the Labor Party and the trade union movement? On 21 April he said:
The whole accord breaks down if the Commission goes back to some discounting systems or some 80 per cent arrangement . . . Then that busts the accord.

That of course, demonstrates very clearly that the trade union movement has never, does not and never will accept, under its present leadership, the great economic reality of 1983 that if we try to maintain real wages we will produce higher levels of unemployment. It is the unwillingness of the Labor Government and the trade union movement to face that reality which is the most daunting aspect of their economic policy at present. Not only has the Government settled for a second-best wages policy-a wages policy that will condemn us to higher levels of unemployment than we need otherwise have-with its adoption of scenario A; even that second-best wages policy is quite unacceptable to the ACTU. It is quite impossible to reconcile a 3 per cent to 4 per cent wage adjustment in respect of calendar year 1983, which is the stated position of the Government, with the claim of the ACTU for the March quarter consumer price index rise of 2. 2 per cent and full wage indexation for the remainder of 1983. Not all of the contortions and twisting and turning and the attempts at rationalisation by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister can reconcile the irreconcilable. Those two positions simply cannot be reconciled. No amount of posturing from the other side can persuade the Australian community otherwise.

Not content with adopting an unrealistic attitude and not content with confronting the Government's own second-best wages policy, the President of the ACTU has resorted to intimidating the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. When he was asked a question the other day about some of his comments, he said:
Well they will put themselves out of business as far as I see it. There will be just no role for the Arbitration Commission because unions will seek to achieve that consensus.
He was then asked the question:
Is this the industrial free-for-all you were talking about?
He answered:
That's right.

Later, when questioned about his reference to a free-for-all, Mr Dolan admitted using the expression but, he said, not in an adversary sense. How on earth can one have an industrial free-for-all without there being adversaries? Perhaps one can in the same way one can have a consensus without ever having reached an agreement! The disarray and confusion about the Government's wages policy is widely recognised throughout the Australian community. Look at the newspaper headlines of yesterday, 18 May. The Australian has 'ACTU warns: Pay up or it's free-for-all'; the Age, 'Unions defy PM on pay rises'; the Melbourne Herald, ' Warning on ACTU pay push'; Sydney Morning Herald, 'Free-for-all pay warning'; the Australian Financial Review, 'ACTU pay ultimatum'; the Daily Telegraph, ' ACTU demand for pay boost'; the Daily Mirror, 'ACTU claim stuns Hawke'. This is the utopia of industrial peace promised by the Australian Labor Party a bare two and a half months ago! This is the consensus. This is the bringing together of Australia for which the Prime Minister was elected on 5 March. This is the special relationship which the Australian Council of Trade Unions has with the Australian Labor Party.

This is the fraud that has been practised on the Australian people. The disarray is not only widespread but also very deep. That is understood and accepted by the Australian community. Yet against this background the Government has the sheer indecency to spend $1m of taxpayers' money to advertise the consensus that was allegedly reached at the Summit on 11 April. It has the sheer effrontery to talk about galvanising the support of 15 million Australians to move mountains, yet it cannot even get its house in order. The Government cannot even bring to fruition its much vaunted alleged special relationship with the Australian trade union movement. Today, on the morning of the making of the first major economic statement to this Parliament by the Treasurer of the Hawke Government, we really have the worst of both worlds. On the one hand the Government has squibbed it and, by embracing scenario A, has adopted a wages policy which without question will condemn us inevitably to higher levels of unemployment. That assertion is based not on Liberal Party propaganda but upon the Treasurer's own evidence--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. I draw the attention of the House to Standing Order No. 82 in relation to the notice given by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for General Business Thursday No. 1.
—There is no point of order. I call the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—The Government has opted for a wages policy which will condemn us to higher levels of unemployment in 1983, 1984 and 1985. This is a second-best wages policy-a wages policy that not only is clearly rejected by a wide cross- section of the Australian community but also on the Government's own evidence, as presented to the National Economic Summit Conference, will condemn us to high levels of unemployment. Even worse, this second-best wages policy, this unacceptable wages policy, this high unemployment wages policy, is under attack and subject to confrontation by the ACTU. So on the morning of the making of this economic statement we have the worst of both worlds. We have a weak, irresolute second-best wages policy being pursued by the Government and even that second-best solution confronted and condemned by the very body with which the Government claims above everything else to have a special relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will not give the Treasurer the call until the House comes to order. I call the Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have to say one thing for the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard): He has more hide than a team of elephants to have the temerity to come into this House with a matter of public importance, on the day on which the Government is to announce major economic initiatives, and talk about the implications of anyone else's economic policies. Here is the former Treasurer, who surveys every week the ruins of his work, the ruins of those five years of unsurpassed failure as Treasurer of this nation- indeed, a record of failure unsurpassed by any post-war Treasurer. He talks about the increase in unemployment in prospect as a result of the Government's wages policy. The first point I make is that the former Government never had a wages policy and no greater deterioration in unemployment could have occurred than occurred when 270,000 persons were relegated to the employment scrapheap by the honourable member for Bennelong and his cohorts, who sit beside him with smug faces but now sit in Opposition where they belong.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the former Government's record in respect of unemployment over the years. In 1975 it promised to turn on the lights and restore economic health to the Australian nation. Unemployment doubled from roughly 5 per cent to 10 per cent over the period. Let us consider inflation, the principal evil, the reduction of which the former Government was committed to-indeed it was the central focus of its economic policy. The reason for its very existence was to drag inflation down. The consumer price index for the year ended in the March quarter was 11.5 per cent. In 1975 it was 12.3 per cent. That is the sum total of the former Treasurer's work, not to mention, of course, his contribution to interest rates. Interest rates are the highest in Australia's post-war history-I think the highest in Australia's history full stop.

More damning is the former Government's record in respect of economic growth. The former Government was supposed to be the government of economic managers, the people in the pinstripe suits who understood how the business community worked, whose mere presence in office would transform the commercial landscape of Australia which would take us all into the land of milk and honey. What was the end result? It was a miserable 1.6 per cent growth of gross domestic product per person for the seven years, which was half the average of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. That is the sum total of the former Treasurer's work. He should not come in here to lecture us about how to run an economy or about wages policies. He handed us a poison chalice and it is this Government's job to get over the difficulties which it has inherited. The former Treasurer talked about his right to criticise us and talk about the implications of our economic policy. Tonight I intend to bring down a statement dealing in part with the fiscal inheritance which he left us. The former Government left $9 .6 billion of fiscal irresponsibility about which it was so silent in the election campaign. Let me quote what the Department of the Treasury told us on our first day of office about the former Government's work. The Department said:

The magnitude of the fiscal imbalance is unprecedented in Australia during peace time as is the level of Government spending. The Budget balance is projected to deteriorate from near zero to more than 6 per cent of GDP in a two year period. The speed and magnitude of that deterioration is almost without precedent among the major OECD countries in the post-war period.

That is the former Government's legacy. It is not a piece of Australian Labor Party propaganda. That is the careful, measured assessment by the Department of state principally involved in economic policy, the one in which the former Government placed its trust. That is the Department's condemnation of the former Government's work. I cannot for the life of me understand how the Liberal Party can propose as its economic spokesman a person with a record of failure unsurpassed in this country. Because we are all supposed to be able to take a joke I suppose that we will be continually subjected to the rantings of the honourable member for Bennelong in respect of the economy which he proved he could not manage. I reject absolutely any credentials he has to assess economic trends or to criticise this Government.

If the former Government talks about credibility in quoting my remarks in the election campaign I remind honourable members of the cruel hoax which the honourable member for Bennelong played upon the Australian community in the vital last couple of weeks of the election campaign. The former member for Wannon, the former Prime Minister, took part in a critical debate about the size of the Labor Party's program and the fact that it was central to the course of the election campaign. He tried to influence the decision of the Australian public about who should next govern Australia. The former Prime Minister was badmouthing the Labor Party about a $10 billion deficit about which the former Treasurer knew from when the election campaign started. On 19 January he was told that the deficit in prospect for 1983-84 would be roughly double that in prospect for 1982-83. He knew that the likely deficit would be in the order of $ 9 billion. He was told that on 19 January. On Monday, 28 February, less than one week before the crucial election day, he was told by the Department of the Treasury that it was likely to be in the order of $9 billion. So for one week the Australian public would have had the opportunity of being apprised of the truth of the state of the finances of the Commonwealth of Australia under the honourable member's Government. Yet, the honourable member, in a conspiracy with the former Prime Minister, sat on that vital piece of information which was critical to the election campaign. To lie to the Australian public by having the former Prime Minister say that he thought someone had spoken about $6 billion when it was quite obvious--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the Treasurer has been meticulous in the language he has used. I think he used the word 'lie' in the sense--
—Well, to mislead us, shall I say, Mr Speaker.
—The Treasurer withdraws the word 'lie'?

—I withdraw. To mislead the public. There was talk about the fact that the figure would be $6 billion when the former Treasurer and the former Prime Minister knew it was to be $9.6 billion or very close to $10 billion, which they were accusing the Labor Party of proposing.

SPEECH.PARA: On that basis, Mr Speaker, I do not want to hear any mealymouthed talk from the honourable member for Bennelong about my credibility on the public record in respect of economic policy. I will leave it to the Parliament and the public to judge his actions themselves. The honourable member came in here today and talked about economic policy and wages policy. This former Treasurer presided over the biggest wages blowout since the early 1970s. Indeed, a lot of the problems in the economy today stem from the fact that in 1980 the former Government talked the economy up for the purposes of its own miserable political skins. It talked about a resources boom involving projects of $30 billion and $ 40 billion and virtually invited the union movement to come and take a piece of it. That is the absolute truth of the position. Right through 1980 the then Opposition talked in measured terms about the need for a balance between the sectors in Australia. It pointed out that we should not simply put reliance upon the mineral industry. However, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony) in particular had a xenophobia about letting everyone develop mines when they felt like it. We can now see the result of that. We have so much over- capacity that prices will be depressed for years. That is the sum total of his lunacy. All we ever heard throughout that period was a promise about projects involving $30 billion or $40 billion.

What was the end result? The end result was that the unions were virtually invited to come and take a share. We then had this naivety about wages policy. This country has operated under a centralised wage fixation system for nearly all of its Federal history. That system involves hundreds of interlocking awards and relativities. Honourable members opposite thought that all of a sudden that practice could be pushed to one side; that we could have a decentralised system where only the strong prevail. The strong certainly prevailed. They prevailed all right. They hopped into the big juicy areas and grabbed wage increases which trickled right through the economy. If there is to be any blame apportioned in respect of wages policy and inflation, the blame is on the other side of the Parliament, not this side. The former Government destroyed wage indexation. It destroyed the only system of wage fixation which held wages at or below the inflation rate. It went for a decentralised system of wage fixation which destroyed the previous arrangement and which took no account of the practice of 70 years of wage fixation. This action resulted in a surge in wages and a surge in inflation and ultimately, with the world economy, the collapse of the Australian economy. So I say to the Opposition: Do not come back and lecture us about wages policy. We reject absolutely the honourable member's views about where wages policy should go.

I am not going to take the opportunity presented by the matter of public importance raised by the honourable member to talk in the broad about economic policy because the honourable member is simply trying to jump the gun on tonight 's statement. I will leave that until then. But I say this in respect of our incomes policy: I repeat, as I repeated yesterday and as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) have repeated, that there are three elements to our approach to incomes policy. The first is a return to centralised wage fixation, which was the subject of agreement at the National Economic Summit Conference. The second is small increases for wages in the current year. The third is an acceptance of the Summit principle that any increases outside of national wage cases must be strictly confined. They are the three principal elements of our incomes policy. I repeat what the Prime Minister and my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations said yesterday. The Government remains committed to no more than a 3 per cent to 4 per cent wage increase this year. We said that yesterday and I repeat it today. Nothing the Opposition says will deflect us from this course. I also indicated yesterday that as far as the catch-up is concerned, there can be no increase in real wages until there is a clear capacity of the economy to afford it. I mentioned it yesterday and I will mention it again today for the benefit of honourable members who do not seem to understand. Scenario A proposes a movement in the catch-up beyond 1985. I make it quite clear and it should be understood that the catch-up is on the back- burner. This Government believes that there can be no future in respect of progress in the Australian economy without restraint on all sides. We have not demurred to that. We have not changed from the principal policy expressions made by the Government at the National Economic Summit Conference. Neither will we demur to that when we go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I make it clear that as far as we are concerned, we will not be lectured on wages policy. The Opposition had no policies in Government and has none in Opposition. The honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) is adhering to his view of a centralised system of wage fixation and the honourable member for Bennelong is adhering to his view about decentralised wages. All we do not have now is the former member for Stirling talking about his enterprise unions- one union for every company around the country. In being rid of him we are at least rid of that piece of industrial relations nonsense.

The final point I make is that there is not a shred of credibility in the matter of public importance proposed by the honourable member for Bennelong. I suppose he figured that if he could make a nuisance of himself today and annoy me this morning when I have more important things to do, then he would take the opportunity of interrupting my day. I do not mind being interrupted by this tomfoolery, particularly when it has no basis in fact, policy, record of performance, incomes policy, or any consistency of policy on the part of the Opposition. The Opposition never had a wages policy and it never proposed to have one. It never will have a wages policy or any relationship with the Australian trade union movement. The Opposition deserves to be where it is and where it will remain for a long time-in Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Carlton had moved by way of amendment:

That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not opposing the Bill, the House notes the failure of the Government to fulfill the Prime Minister's policy speech commitment to abolish the Pharmaceutical Benefits Declaration'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not want to get a name as a knocking Opposition. When something constructive occurs, we as an Opposition will support it. In relation to the National Health Amendment Bill 1983, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will . . . honour an important election commitment to abolish the declaration that pensioners and concessional beneficiaries must sign when they receive pharmaceutical benefits. As honouring this promise involves legislative change, the Government is taking one of the first opportunities in the new Parliament to honour its election pledge.

Last night the former Minister for Health, the honourable member for Mackellar ( Mr Carlton), spoke in this debate. He is a friend of mine and a man who I believe constructively set about the difficult task of restructuring the health policy of the previous Government. He ran into a little flak sometimes because of occurrences beyond his control. Just before the election he came into a fair bit of flak from the pharmacists of Australia. He said in a constructive way that he would overcome the problem. He was working towards that end but unfortunately history, as we know, did not give him the opportunity to do just that. The previous Minister was sensitive to and aware of the problems that the elderly faced in filling out this particular form.

I think it should be noted by all members that as people get older it becomes difficult for them to do anything that is just a little bit different. Tonight, when they hear about certain things in the mini-Budget, they will probably get even more confused. The former Minister for Health tried desperately to amend that declaration to make it far simpler to fill in for the elderly in an effort to stop all the confusion and to stop all the worries of the elderly. Unfortunately, time ran out. The new Minister for Health said that he would abolish the declaration. He sent a letter to all the pharmacists of Australia in which he said:

The pharmaceutical benefits declaration is an unnecessary bureaucratic imposition which will be scrapped by a Labor governemt. Any required details for identification purposes will be completed by doctors when they fill out the prescription form.

I should like to point out to the House what has actually happened. In the first paragraph of the second reading speech of the Minister for Health he claims to have met this firm and unequivocal election commitment. He stated:

This Bill will, among other things, honour an important election commitment to abolish the declaration that pensioners and concessional beneficiaries must sign when they receive pharmaceutical benefits. As honouring this promise involves legislative change, the Government is taking one of the first opportunities in the new Parliament to honour its election pledge.

We agree with that. The previous Minister for Health said that if the Liberal Government had been returned to office he would have changed that declaration. He said that he would have abolished it. He, like many other members on this side of the House, was appalled that our elderly citizens were experiencing so much difficulty in completing that declaration, that it caused so much confusion . But solving the problem took time. Of course, politics came into it. The pharmacists of Australia waged a fairly concerted campaign against the previous Government. We talked to them and said that given a little time we would change the declaration form, but things do not happen overnight. The current Minister for Health said that he would abolish that declaration but he has not abolished it. That is precisely what the Government has not done. It has abolished the old declaration but replaced it with a new declaration. In his second reading speech the Minister for Health stated:

The new prescription form will simplify the present complex declaration form in four ways. First, all the required information will be provided on one side of the form. There will be no requirements on the reverse side of the form. Second, the information for beneficiaries status will be simplified, making it easier for beneficiaries and pharmacists, yet still meeting the necessary demands for effective departmental monitoring.
We all agree with that-

Third, a single signature will indicate both receipt of the prescription and claim to free or concessional entitlement. Fourth, doctors and, if need be, pharmacists will be encouraged to assist beneficiaries in completing the form. However, I would make it clear that responsibility for the accuracy of an entitlement claim rests, as it rightly should, with the beneficiary.

Clearly, the election undertaking has not been honoured. The form, in effect will still create complications for the elderly. The Government was going to abolish the form but it has not done so. That is the reason the Opposition is asking the Minister for Health: 'Can't you abolish it?'. We are not accusing the Government of breaking promises because we do not want to argue about the elderly people of Australia. I hope that the Minister has heard my words and the words of the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Mackellar, who said that the Government is in breach of a particular commitment that it made. We are running into a lot of difficulty with elederly people having to go into nursing homes. It is becoming very complicated for them. One could talk at length on this subject. We support what the Government is doing because it will simplify nursing home funding. It will assist the elderly of Australia. In that regard the Government is moving in the right direction. Again we are proving that as an Opposition we will be constructive at all times, especially when it concerns the elderly of Australia. If the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —We need to do far more for the elderly.

—We need to do far more for the elderly, as the honourable member for Braddon has said. I hope that tonight the Government will not introduce a means test for the over-70 pension. That will be a retrograde step. Some Government supporters are going white in the face because, if the rumour is true , that is what the Government is going to do. It would be a travesty of justice. We must support the elderly of the country at every opportunity. As one gets older, and over 70 years of age, everything worries one. Elderly people who have put aside a little money with which to keep their homes maintained at a particular level need that extra money and should not be penalised. Unfortunately, the Government seems to have a rule that if one is down and out then one needs all the assistance in the world. I agree with that to a degree but that does not mean that a person who has worked hard all his or her life, and has put aside a little with which to maintain his or her standard of living, should not also be given support. I hope that the Government hears my words quite clearly and does not tonight introduce a means test for pensioners over the age of 70. If it does we will launch a concerted attack on it day after day to make it feel that it should be ashamed to put the elderly in such a situation .

SPEECH.PARA: We support the Bill but also support the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Mackellar. We believe the Government has breached a commitment that it gave the elderly people of Australia, as well as pharmacists, whom I would mention particularly. Unfortunately, to a degree they have been conned by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather interesting to follow the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and hear him start off by saying that he does not wish to knock the Government, then spend 15 minutes doing just that. It is clear to everyone that the Government is fulfilling an electoral promise by introducing these amendments. To hear the rather carping speech yesterday of the previous Minister for Health, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), makes one wonder why he did not do these things some months ago when he was the Minister. As he very well knows, the reason is that he was terrified of fraud taking place. When he became Minister he inherited an inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee which showed that doctors, as was clear from the medifraud case, had been ripping off to the tune of $1,000m the system that his Government had implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar panicked because he thought that there was a $20m fraud annually in the pharmacy area. As happened following a number of the decisions of the previous Liberal Government, panic caused everyone else a whole lot of trouble. The previous Minister for Health brought out a form which one needed a legal degree to find one's way around. It cost chemists a lot of money to implement and it cost people not used to filling out forms a great deal of inconvenience. What did the previous Minister for Health do about that? He did a lot of breast beating and made a lot of speeches but never withdrew the form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simplified the form.

—Simplified it! My goodness, if the form the honourable member brought out was simplified, I would be terrified to see the original form that he was going to inflict on chemists. The Government is now providing a simple form of recognition so that when persons receive medicine from a chemist they have only to sign their name at the bottom of the form, in the same way as anyone who receives a benefit under the national health service does, a procedure which has been in effect for many years. People have to sign to get drugs. That has been done for years and years.

SPEECH.PARA: The change proposed in the National Health Amendment Bill will go a long way to help pensioners, migrants and many others in this country receive their benefit from the Government with a great deal less inconvenience than they suffered when the previous Government was in office. The Government's action will also remove from them the feeling that there is something rather shaky in having to sign all this documentation. It will also make the chemists much happier, because they will not have the massive problem that they have had in the past with deciphering the forms-which the previous Government never even got printed but sent out with a rubber stamp; it was typical of the type of bureacracy that it wanted to develop-which made it very difficult for everyone. I commend the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for introducing this legislation, which will implement one of the Government's election policies.

The next issue to which I address myself is the amendment regarding nursing home fees. As the Minister quite rightly pointed out in his second reading speech, the area of nursing home fees and accommodation is an area that for far too long the previous Government just let run along and did nothing about. It has always seemed to me scandalous that in this financial year the Commonwealth Government's expenditure on institutional accommodation for the aged will pass $ 1,000m and the Commonwealth's contribution under the guidelines set out by the previous Government for domiciliary benefits for those pensioners and frail aged people who wish to stay in their own homes will account for only about $150m. This shows that the previous Government had absolutely no approaches in the past to planning for care of the aged, and that they were at the mercy of nursing home proprietors who allowed this form of government expenditure to escalate through the roof.

I am pleased to say that the present Government has a very compassionate approach to the care of the aged. It will allow old people some dignity in their retiring years. It will allow old people, for the first time in Australia's history, to have a choice about what to do when they reach the stage when they are frail and old. Until now, under the provisions of the Liberal Government, the only choice was to go into a nursing home. The present Government will be implementing in the next two years proposals which will allow people to receive nursing assistance in their own homes and a whole range of benefits and services , which will allow aged people to stay in their own homes rather than seek institutional care.

I have not found very many people who want to go into nursing homes if they have a choice. It is like suggesting that people want to go into hospital when they can be treated at home by their own doctors. We shall be taking steps to see that that choice is brought back into the Australian system and to see that the frail aged can be cared for by their families and that the families will not be used as free assistance as they were under the previous Government's policies . I used to find it rather disconcerting to listen to the previous Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, and the previous Minister for Health, saying ' We must rely upon the family more'. All that does, if the Government wants the family to provide all these services for free, is to place intolerable burdens on many families and, in many instances, contribute to family breakups. The previous Government wanted to try to shift the thrust of government expenditure off the Government and on to struggling families. That was a reprehensible thing for any government to do.

I am assured by the present Ministers that the Labor Government will be giving assistance to families to care for their relations, and not just saying 'You have just got to do this out of family love or Christian charity', or out of goodness knows what. We shall be providing assistance for people to make those choices and to help them care for their relations in their own homes. We will not say, in the cavalier fashion of the previous Government, 'You had just better do it because it is your responsibility'. A central issue in the present Government's approach to aged care will be, for the first time, looking at a genuine assessment system. In our election policy speech we said that we would fund a number of assessment teams throughout Australia to ensure that people are given guidance, for the first time, about the facilities available to them, and that they are given medical assessments, so that people are not placed in institutions when there is no specific need for that. Honourable members will recall that the Auditor-General some years ago, when he undertook an inquiry into the nursing home function of the Department of Health, suggested that 25 per cent of the people who are in nursing homes did not need that level of medical care. The family and the aging project conducted at the Australian National University, which was funded by the Commonwealth Government, had suggested recently that in the order of 19 per cent of the frail and aged in institutions do not need that level of care. In the past they have had to have that level of care because there has been no other option.

We will be bringing in other options. We will have assessment teams to help people through the labyrinth of services which were provided in the past by the previous Government and which will be built upon by us. There has been a feeling abroad among a number of people that the Commonwealth will be implementing these new assessment teams on everyone without their consideration. I should like to put that idea to rest here today. The Labor Government will not be implementing 50 new assessment teams around Australia, teams which will just fall off the shelf and come in and tell people what to do. The Minister for Health has made it quite clear, in the Labor Party's policy speech, during the election campaign and since, that we will be funding assessment teams through State governments- they are the people who have the constitutional responsibility for this matter- and that we will be building upon the many embryonic assessment teams which exist in the States at present. There will be a building up of the services that are there now and the members of those services will be able to play their role in ensuring that people, when they become old and frail and have to look for assistance, will be shown what the choices are and be assisted in those choices.

In conclusion, I should like to address myself to the domiciliary nursing care benefit which is also mentioned in this legislation. I have only one worry about the present domiciliary nursing care benefit and I hope the Minister will take it on board when considering future amendments to the National Health Act. It has always seemed to me rather an inequity that when people receiving the domiciliary nursing benefit go into a nursing home or a hospital for a day or two for some health reason their benefit is stopped. That usually saves the Commonwealth Government about $6 to $12. The administrative cost of stopping and starting that benefit must be $50 or $60. This, once again, is a system which was put in place by the previous Liberal Government which was so keen on having bureaucracies regulate everything. It was a Government which said it was for free enterprise but it brought in more regulation in this country than we have seen since Federation.

It has always seemed to me that that provision should be amended so that if a person goes into a hospital or a nursing home for a period of less than a week the benefit continues. Even if these people may not have been entitled to the benefit for those one or two days, the cost of stopping and starting the benefit far outweighs the saving to the Commonwealth by stopping it. I think it would also be of great assistance to many aged people and their relations if they did not have to go to the effort and trouble of this form filling to stop and start the benefit, worrying that they may somehow be defrauding the Government. The tax dodgers had no compunction about taking thousands of millions of dollars out of the economy, the previous government implemented a whole range of bureaucratic procedures to stop pensioners and other people receiving a dollar or two that it felt they should not get. I must say, Mr Deputy Speaker-and I am sure you are well aware of this in your electorate which is somewhat the same as mine-that those old people worry terribly that they may be getting a dollar they are not entitled to. They have a conscience about these things and we should be doing something to ensure that they do not have to worry about it. The domiciliary nursing care should be paid in weekly lumps. If a person has to be in hospital for a day or two, that person should still get the benefit. I hope the Minister will take that on board.

I compliment the Minister on the amendments that he has brought into the Act. I know that they will be welcomed by the pharmacists and I know that they will be welcomed by the aged people to whom they will be of most assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with the express purpose of commending the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for his constructive actions in meeting a commitment made before the election. In doing so, I feel it is necessary to correct some of the things that have been said by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) which were quite untrue and which distorted the whole position of the Government . For instance, the honourable member for Franklin said that the honourable member for Mackellar, as Minister for Health, tried desperately to amend the form. I would not have brought this up if the Opposition had not gone full pelt into an unnecessary and unjustified attack on what we are doing in rectifying this form. Anyone can make a mistake. I believe that the former Minister for Health, the honourable member for Mackellar, made an honest mistake. He thought that, when he began his term as the new Minister, he would flex the ministerial muscles and show that he would crack down on all those pensioners who were abusing the system. But he decided this, despite the fact that when the matter was brought up in this House, there was no evidence on record that such abuse had been occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Franklin said that he tried desperately to amend the form. How desperate can one get? It must have been soon after the middle of last year that the then Minister decided that he would bring in a form which was so complex that it was to prove, in time, to add many hours of work to pharmacists and to put the ill and the aged-people in a state of trauma-into an even greater state of trauma. The existing pharmaceutical prescription form had all the information that was necessary on one side of the form. I make it clear that the new form that was brought in entailed turning the prescription form over and filling in, as has been mentioned by the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), a very complex form on the back. It involved the ticking and crossing of a number of little boxes. Then there was a duplication of the need to sign so that a pensioner who had already signed on one side of the form in the presence of customers in the shop-these people had already gone through the humiliation of going through the social security system and having to declare every last little cent that they earn-had, in front of those other customers, to turn the form over and, with the pharmacist, fill in an additional unnecessary form and sign it. At the bottom of that form it is stated that any error could result in six months imprisonment or a penalty of $1,000. That is what this Government is on about and that is what it is rectifying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I took it off.

—Yes, but that is precisely what I wish to mention in questioning the credibility of the Opposition. It was October that the Bill justifiying this prescription form was introduced into this House. From October onwards then Opposition members, one after another, put their cases forward and asked for a change. I point out that the form was printed before the Bill even came before Parliament so keen was the then Minister to introduce it and to crack down on these pensioners. When the form was provided a huge rubber stamp was ordered and sent out to all pharmacists. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia notified the then Minister that he should not proceed. The pharmacists, Queensland pharmaceutical association, consumer groups and organisations, and the Australian Pensioners League all put forward the view-this was in October and November-that it should be withdrawn. After that advice was received the former Minister pushed ahead with it. When, eventually he decided that it was to be introduced this year and that there would be a change, he still insisted on having the pensioner duplicate the whole process of signing on one side. I understand that then another rubber stamp was ordered and was to be distributed. Meanwhile, people were lining up in pharmacies across Australia, which caused hours of extra work and great distress. The whole point is that it was unnecessary distress.

SPEECH.PARA: Considering the previous Government's long history when no basic change was made, I find it unbelievable that the Opposition and the honourable member for Mackellar can now say that in the time slot leading up to a possible election, and then in a campaign for a definite election, he was saying that he would do something about it at some stage. That was not trying desperately. It is certainly questionable whether anything ever would have been done. In fact, the honourable member's distortion of this Government's action is typical of the twisted outlook of the Opposition when commenting on Government performance. That is worth noting when we consider the Opposition's credibility. It can nowhere be seen more clearly than when the Opposition comments on the management of the mess in which it left this nation.

Opposition members say that we use the deficit as an excuse for inaction. What twisted logic. If they had not left us with this enormous debt, but had left us with some flow of money, there would be no need for an excuse. The depleted state of the Treasury coffers is a reason, not an excuse. We on the Government benches would rather have the money that we and all Australians were led to believe was here. The relief and pleasure of a government which believes in Australia, is concerned about its welfare and which was so enthusiastic to implement immediately policies to help Australians, would far outweigh any negative pleasure-in fact no pleasure at all-at being able to say that the deficit was the cause for our not being able to act fully at this stage. The question to be asked is: What did the Opposition intend to do if it had regained office?

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I think the honourable member has had enough licence and is straying totally away from the substance of the Bill.
—It has been a wide-ranging debate in respect of the principal issue involved. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I wish to point out that I am answering the claims and the attacks made on the Government during this very debate by the very honourable member who has just complained. Again this shows the extent of the cynicism of some honourable members on the Opposition benches. I was saying that the question to be asked is: What did the Opposition intend to do if it regained office, given the fact that it made promises which it knew it could not afford to keep and that it had set in train actions as from the August 1983 Budget that it also knew it could not carry out? It based all of the predictions of that Budget on shonky figures. It was a deceitful Budget and the then Government obviously had to go to the polls as soon as possible which is no doubt why the then Prime Minister was so anxious to go to the polls in November. The Opposition in government deceitfully did this. It is my contention that the Opposition, if it had regained government, of need would have had to cut its policies, and the existing policies-the ones that it had set in train-to the further detriment of the Australian people. Without the Australian Labor Party's policies for unemployment we would have been in an irretrievable position. The honourable member for Mackellar dares to criticise--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. What possible relevance could these matters have to the National Health Amendment Bill?

—I remind the honourable member for Mackellar that this is a Bill for an Act to amend the National Health Act 1953 and for related purposes. Such being the case, the honourable member has a right to cover the ground that she has encompassed so far in her speech.

—I feel that I have now made the point that I wished to make. It is really to register my concern at the lack of credibility of the Opposition. I felt it should be brought to the attention of the public which has to listen to this drivel. The fact is that this Government is again moving to honour an election promise. In doing so, it is relieving the anxiety and trauma of the aged and the infirm in Australia. I am proud to be part of a government which has taken that action. We have reversed what was a bad decision. The shame of the situation, as it was, was the suffering caused those least able to bear it. It is because of the relief of this suffering, which will ensue from the Federal Government's humane and eminently sensible action in withdrawing this insult to the human intelligence, that I take the greatest pleasure in supporting the Government in the fulfilment of its promise to so legislate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted also to support the words of the honourable member for Grayndler -that justice is now being given to people in their later years who have enough to concern them without being tied up in bureaucratic tape at the stage at which they are deciding which nursing home they will enter. The form on the back of the prescription, which is to be abolished, doubled the work unnecessarily. It added to the chemist's work load. I am glad to see the end of that form. I take pleasure in commending the Minister for Health for his excellent work in his portfolio and on behalf of the aged and the infirm of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First I wish to thank supporters of the Government-the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells), the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) and the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay)-for the comments they have made in this debate. I am afraid that I cannot say the same for the two contributions that were made by the Opposition. It is rare, in my experience , to encounter an amendment which is at once so cynical and contemptible.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what has happened to the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) since he fell into Opposition, but quite clearly it has affected the way in which he behaves in this House. I have heard him speak now on three occasions in Opposition. On the first occasion he came in here and said that he spoke for the unemployed, after having been a member of a government which had seen the greatest unemployment in this country since the Great Depression. His second performance was to weep crocodile tears for an exaggerated 5,000 persons who would supposedly be unemployed under the medicare scheme, when he had never wept at all in the seven years that he was a member of the party in government.

Thirdly, last night he posed as an authority on the rectitude, the rightness, of political promises. I would be perfectly happy to have the promise which we made during the election campaign regarding the pharmaceutical declaration form, and the action we have taken within eight weeks of government, compared with the great health promises of the previous Government. I remind honourable members of the promise of the former Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the electorate in November 1975 when he said: 'We will maintain Medibank'. I ask honourable members: How was that promise honoured in the health field? Let me turn to another Minister for Health in the previous Government. During the election campaign of 1980 the then Minister for Health (Mr Mackellar) said:
There was absolutely no truth in the statement that the Government was planning to restrict patients' free access to public hospitals by reimposing a means test for hospital care.

Six months later that access was restricted and that means test was imposed. I am perfectly prepared to be judged on the promise which we made and the actions we have taken on pharmaceutical benefits in comparison with those classic performances by the Opposition when it was in government. Both in spirit and in fact we have honoured the pledges made at the time of the election. What the honourable member for MacKellar-buttressed by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck)-tried to do was to make a pedantic argument about a particular point to suggest that in fact we have not honoured that promise. I will deal with the pedantic point second because quite clearly it can be dealt with, although it is a level of argument which I do not think is relevant to the concerns of the electorate. When we made that promise to the electorate, what did the electorate expect? I think that people expected that the form would be greatly simplified. I do not believe that anyone in the electorate thought that there would not have to be some kind of pharmaceutical prescription form. I believe that they thought it would be very much simplified. They thought that the whole notion of having a reverse side declaration quite separate from the prescription on the front could be removed. They were concerned about the fact that they were forced to fill it in themselves. They know that we were going to get doctors and chemists to help them fill it in. These are the kinds of expectations that people had in relation to the promise we made. All of these expectations have been honoured in this measure.

The form has been made far simpler. It is now printed on a single side. Doctors and pharmacists will be encouraged to help provide information requested on the form. We have reduced the necessity for two signatures. All that is now required is one signature which is needed anyhow to receive the prescription. The former Minister is trying to make a case around that one single signature. I think he would certainly agree that we have to have a number on the pharmaceutical benefits declaration form. I do not believe that anyone thought that a number would not be required. We have to have an indication somewhere on the form that the beneficiary is paying $2 or nothing. Those basic requirements clearly have to be shown on the form. We would all agree with that. The former Minister has tried to build his whole argument on the one fact that the signature still involves some commitment to the accuracy of the facts. To take up the honourable members pedantic point, if he looks at the Bill he will see that the declaration is to be repealed by proposed new section 84AA. The requirement of the patient to fill in and sign a declaration in that strong and legally binding way is abolished.

Last night the honourable member correctly said that he was a bit worried about the legal status of that process. We do not have to worry about the legal status because the declaration basis has been removed. The signature for a prescription is also a certification that the information is accurate. I admit and confess that that is at a far lower level than a declaration and it has in many ways less legal significance.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has some legal significance.

—It has some legal significance but less significance than a declaration. We accept that weaker statement, in that weaker certification, because we believe that it is a quite sufficient deterrent against the problems of fraud that might be in this area. Therefore, I think I have dealt with the pedantic point that was raised. The legal declaration has been abolished. We have replaced it with a certification. This is a weaker system but in our view it is quite sufficient to prevent problems of fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, having gone through this issue, let me repeat the point I made at the beginning of my speech. Compared with the promises the previous Government made in the field of health and the way it honoured them, I am completely confident--

TALK.START.PARA: —Dishonoured them.
—That is right. In the judgment of the electorate I have no doubt that we will be seen to have fully honoured our promises immediately in relation to this matter.
