TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering the Customs Amendment Bill 1983, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill 1983 as they are related measures. Separate questions, will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to proceed along those lines? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Customs Amendment Bill 1983, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill 1983 which are before the House at the moment. Indeed, I particularly welcome the changes that are brought about in these Bills because I, in no small way, recommended them. On 30 April 1981 I signed the application to the Industries Assistance Commission for investigation into the by-law system in Australia. I took this action because I felt that the whole by-law process raised more doubts than answers. Because of that, I felt that the name itself seemed to be misleading. It is a difficult area. When by- laws are granted the question that is always raised is: 'Why do they do this or why was that done?'. Sharp, personal interest is taken in the entry of certain goods from time to time. It seemed to me that a more appropriate name could be found for by-laws. A by-law suggests that something strange is going on around the law. Therefore, the name 'commercial tariff concessions' seems to be a much more appropriate and understandable title.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the enormous difficulty that the Department had in administering the by-law system. I consistently used to marvel at the patience of Mr Luckman, who had the responsibility for adjudicating in these areas. Although the ministerial determinations are issued in the Minister's name, he was the one who had to carry the problems.

I very much welcome the initiative of the Government in bringing forward these amendments to the by-law system. The introduction of the main commercial tariff concessions, and the way in which they will now be judged-not on the suitably equivalent criteria but more on a market-based test as to whether they are items which do conform with Industries Assistance Commission policy guidelines-has extensive support from all sectors of the business community. I am sure that because of these decisions the guidelines will be embraced by the industry which is so heavily involved. It is worth mentioning at this stage that the cost of administering the by-law was some $2m per annum, with a staff of 67. This was a very substantial part of the Customs office. I am sure that those officers who are now charged with the responsibility of implementing the guidelines will welcome the new market-based test. I think they will find it far easier to implement the criterion, which has now been put into law, on which the assessment will be made rather than to rely on judgment, which was the original case. All determinations will be put out in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. I recommend the proposed publication to all of those involved in this field.

Along with the main Bill are two amendments. One deals with import quota, which I think is also desirable. It came about, as I remember it, particularly during a shipping strike in 1981. The quota for a particular year, because of the shipping strike, was actually landed in Australia after the date of quota. The amendments now before the House will allow those quotas that come in after the period to be entered at no penalty. This is a vast improvement and certainly one which will help those involved in the import trade. They will now be able to administer their businesses by taking goods into and out of bond and entering them after the due date. I am sure that those in the footwear, clothing and textile areas will welcome those changes enormously.

The other part of the Bill which I think is significant is the extension of the benefit to Papua New Guinea in relation to the forum countries. We provide special concessions of entry into Australia from the forum country group. This will include Papua New Guinea in terms of its access to the forum area. I commend those additions to the House.

The other two Bills are purely related matters and I do not propose to go into them. They flow on as a consequence of the IAC findings. I repeat that I have great personal satisfaction in supporting the measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too, like the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), wish to speak in support of the Customs Amendment Bill 1983 and the consequential amendments to the Industries Assistance Commission Act and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Act. Customs is an area of policy which is usually ignored by politicians and the public generally as being too complex, or simply about social issues such as drug imports or pornography. It is certainly about those, but Customs performs a major economic role as well. Unfortunately this economic role has never attracted the attention or parliamentary scrutiny that I believe it deserves.

SPEECH.PARA: When consideration is given to the economic aspect of Customs many of us tend to see it in terms of the amount of revenue collected, and that is a substantial amount-something between $3,000m and $4,000m. While revenue raised as a result of the operation of the Customs Acts is, indeed, important, Customs is mainly about protection of Australian industry rather than about raising revenue. Even revenue items such as those covered in the list of Excise Tariff and Luxury Goods-for example, furs and jewellery-generally have some protective incidence. While the economic role of Customs is largely ignored by the Parliament, it is certainly very much part of the day-to-day conduct of the large manufacturing, retailing and importing industries. Every large company in these areas has a section devoted to Customs work or employs a Customs agent or consultant to work on its behalf in this area. A large proportion of approaches to Government in Canberra by the business community is related to questions on Customs.

Within Customs we are looking at tariff classification, by-laws and dumping as well as the administration of bounty and excise. This particular legislation deals with what was formerly known as the by-law system, which in future is to be known as the commercial tariff concession scheme. Broadly speaking, under the old by-law system, where an importer brought in a product which was not manufactured in Australia he was able to get it free of duty under by-law. The logic of that was that since the good was not manufactured in Australia, there was no Australian industry to protect and, therefore, to charge duty was only to impose extra costs on the importer and ultimately the consumer.

The test which was used to establish whether by-law would be granted was whether a 'suitably equivalent' good was 'reasonably available' and produced in Australia. The goods imported into Australia under by-law would, in the normal course of events, be worth about $3,700m per year. About $600m in Customs duties is forgone by grant of by-law. In other words, goods which would normally attract duty of some $600m are admitted free. This compares with $1,600m collected in Customs duty.

There has been interminable dispute about whether Australian made goods are suitably equivalent to the imported goods-understandably so, because the judgments are frequently totally subjective. I understand that in times of high economic growth there is a much greater willingness to grant by-law than in times of economic recession. I am not suggesting that officials do not attempt to play the same rules, but it is a fact that pressure from local manufacturers is much greater during times of economic downturn. Because of widespread dissatisfaction among both importers and manufacturers with the existing by-law system, a reference was sent by the previous government to the Industries Assistance Commission asking it to review and make recommendations concerning the operation of by-law. The IAC reported on 2 July 1982. The thrust of its report was that the commercial by-law system should be retained in a modified fashion. Specifically, it made the following recommendations:

A. The 'suitably equivalent'/'reasonably available' criteria should be dropped and replaced by the criteria that there were no goods serving similar functions produced in Australia. In addition concessional entry should be refused where the imported goods would have a substantially adverse effect on the market available to goods produced in Australia.
B. That where commercial by-law was granted the by-law should be notified in the Commonwealth Gazette.
The IAC recommended that the term 'produced in Australia' should be interpreted as:
1. requiring significant transformation combined with substantial local content ; and
2. including the capability to produce in the normal course of business in Australia.
Among its other recommendations the IAC said all ad hoc by-laws, that is, by- laws for specific shipments, should be allowed to lapse and that retrospective by-laws should be abolished.

Under the previous system it was possible for an importer to land goods in Australia and pay duty but afterwards apply for a refund of duty on the ground that no equivalent Australian good was produced here. Where successful, this provided the importer with a large windfall profit equal to the value of the Customs duty refunded, while doing nothing to reduce the price of the good since it had already been sold and the duty passed on in general costs. There is, therefore, a strong case for objecting to retrospective by-laws and very little useful economic purpose served by granting them.

The IAC recommended also that 'fall-short' and 'short-fall' by-laws be terminated. 'Fall-short' by-laws are by-laws which are granted because, although there is an Australian producer, he is not able to meet normal market demands because of seasonal, cyclical, or other short term reasons. 'Short-fall' by-laws are those covering goods for which local producers cannot supply demand under normal circumstances. In future, 'short-fall' or 'fall-short' by-laws will be required to be referred to the IAC before they are granted. Following receipt of the IAC report and an interdepartmental committee report, examinations of the following provisions were accepted: (a) abolition of retrospectivity; (b) abolition of ad hoc concessions; (c) provision of an in transit provision; and ( d) definition of 'produced in Australia'.

The new system will come into effect from 1 July 1983. That is the legislation that is now before this House. However, I think a number of things need to be said. First, the legislation has been developed largely as a result of considerations which took place before the present Government came to office, as the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has outlined. Second, we have the option of introducing legislation to implement a system based on the IAC recommendations and presently administered in accordance with the recommendations, or of going back to the old and often unsatisfactory by-law system. Third, in those circumstances, the Government has little option but to proceed with the legislation and, if necessary, to make adjustments if experience indicates that adjustments are required.

I have reservations about some aspects of the new scheme. The Minister's speech indicates that appeals against decisions will be handled in several ways; firstly, by an internal review system within the Department; secondly, by seeking a reference to the IAC; and, thirdly, by using the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Let me make these observations: I am not really very impressed with the internal review system proposal. Basically, this will allow the aggrieved importer to appeal from a junior officer to a more senior officer and, ultimately, to the Minister himself. I think it unlikely that a junior officer would take a decision in a marginal case without consulting his superiors, and in that sense the appeal would be from Caesar to Caesar. Nevertheless, it does provide an opportunity for new or amended evidence to be lodged. Secondly, it is unreasonable to expect a Minister to review a decision of his department in what is a largely technical matter. No one has a greater admiration for the capacity of the Minister than I do. But it would be unfair and unreasonable to expect him to carry out the examinations necessary to reach a proper judgment in each case. In practical terms, it is just not possible for him to undertake the study necessary and he is forced to rely on the information given to him by his Department. Then again, knowing as I do the time taken up by Ministers receiving deputations to put different points of view, I believe that this would be an unwarranted intrusion on the Minister's time.

The right to seek a reference to the IAC runs into difficulties as well. Normally a reference would not be granted unless there were a fundamental issue of principle to be established. Again, it is hardly conceivable that a Minister would make a reference to the IAC unless so advised by his department or by an authoritative body such as the IAC itself. This brings me to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. While it is a big advance to allow appeals against decisions by the Department and the Minister and contrary to the IAC recommendations, I think the more appropriate tribunal would be the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Reviews under the Administrative Decisions ( Judicial Review) Act are conducted by the Federal Court of Australia and the proceedings are time consuming, costly and frequently extremely legalistic. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal is far better equipped to review decisions swiftly, cheaply and without excessive legalism. Basically, the questions to be answered and considered are not ones where great legal insight is required but where common sense and judgment need to be applied.

In conclusion, the legislation before the House, despite the reservations I have expressed, is a step forward in the rationalisation of Customs law and should provide a more equitable and predictable environment for users of the system. I congratulate the Government on conducting seminars throughout the country to inform manufacturers and importers about the new system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the Opposition supports the legislation. It compliments the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) for introducing these moves which will greatly assist manufacturers. I believe that a lot of credit is due to the previous Minister who initiated most of them. It is good that we have had a bit of coming together for the first time . It is good also that there is conciliation and a bringing of Australia together. This is about the first sign I have seen of it and I compliment both gentlemen. The difficulty that the Minister has, of course, is reconciling people who are employed, for example, in the textile and footwear industries who are dependent to a degree on what people will pay for a particular product. If people see other products that are far cheaper there is a scramble. We have always had the difficult problem in Australia of cheaper imports as against what is supplied in Australia and what people are prepared to buy. Of course, the unemployment problem enters the argument. If industries such as the footwear and textile industry restructure and put people out of work there are grave repercussions. The point I make is that there has to be a balance. Therefore, the Minister's job is terribly difficult. The public servants, the Industries Assistance Commission and others who are involved in Customs and tariffs have a difficult job in initiating programs that will be beneficial to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The IAC and other people have to look at an industry and worry about pricing, about whether it will be viable and about whether it will continue to employ Australians. This is a grave problem. When considering simplifying the entry of goods we can talk about the importation of crude oil. We can then take that a step further and consider the pricing of petroleum in Australia. I believe that petrol pricing, for example, should be one matter that governments and others in Australia who are skilled in this regard should look at very carefully. The Collins Royal Commission on Petroleum which was held in 1974 cost about $1.5m. It hoped to overcome some of the problems associated with the petroleum industry but it failed because the petroleum industry is ever-changing. Now we have a ludicrous situation in Australia where, in various States, there are different prices for petrol. Some governments have a freeze on the wholesale price and some have a freeze on the retail price. Of course, as a result of those freezes oil companies are finding it very difficult to expand, to develop jobs and to develop in Australia as they would like. On the other hand other States do not have any restrictions. Ultimately consumers in those States pay a higher price for their petrol.

If we are going to look at industries I believe that the petroleum industry should be considered by the Government. In the past I have criticised the IAC. I thought it included a bunch of armchair theorists. I take that all back. It has a job to do and hopefully it is trying to overcome some of the problems associated with changing industries and changing ways of marketing in Australia. We are importing 35 per cent of our crude oil, at the heavy end. We are 65 per cent self-sufficient. If we are to have a source of petroleum in Australia for years to come and if we are to be self-sufficient we need to take into consideration all the problems associated with the industry. We should consider the ludicrous situation that we have in Tasmania-I will name Tasmania because I come from that State and it is easy to talk about-where consumers pay about 48c a litre for their petrol.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would know.
—Yes, I would know because I probably know more about petrol pricing than any other member in this House. I very rarely praise myself but on this occasion I will.
—A constant spokesman.
—I thank the honourable member.
—Too modest.
—I am too modest.
—Pretty stupid too.

—I knew the Minister would say that. The oil companies go to the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. If they can justify an increase in the price of petrol, they get that increase. At the moment in Hobart with the major oil companies the wholesale price varies by up to 3c a litre. When the dealers put their margin on top of that they are at disadvantage immediately. There is confusion down there. There is criticism of the dealers, the oil companies and of course of governments. In Melbourne there is a fixed wholesale price yet in fact the oil companies are able to sell below that wholesale price, sometimes to the detriment of the dealers within the area, putting people out of work, et cetera. In Sydney there is the same sort of situation. There is a fixture on the wholesale price yet the oil companies are able to sell petrol below that wholesale price so the whole thing is in confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I make is that, if we are to help industries and consumers in Australia, we as a Parliament should settle a direct point and overcome these problems to a degree. We have the ability to do it. We are able to draw on the experts to look at these industries. We should look at the petroleum industry. People need petrol as much as they need the air that we breathe and the water that we drink. It has an effect on transportation, on goods and on the ability of people to move from point A to point B. It affects their livelihoods. It is a terribly important industry. Sometimes politicians are afraid to face up to the fact that we have to restructure the industry and look at it carefully. For example, we heard the manager of Ampol Ltd at the National Economic Summit Conference talk about petrol.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Gosper.

—No, it was the manager of Ampol Ltd-Gosper is from the Shell Co. of Australia-talking about the petroleum industry. Everybody wants to blame somebody else for it. I believe that we have the responsibility.
—Nationalise it.

—No, we will not nationalise it. Why should we nationalise it? If we did that the oil companies would not have the ability to expand or to develop in Australia. We have to look at it sensibly. But we have a unique ability to set up some committee here. Many back benchers sometimes sit and twiddle their thumbs because they do not have the initiative or incentive to get involved in something that will be terribly important to the economy of Australia. I hope we can join together in some way-perhaps with the great Mr Hawke with the albatross around his neck-and we could work together and restructure the industry, instead of leaving it to other people who are not elected to Parliament but who seem to have a heck of a great say in what occurs in Australia. We could join together in harmony and work for the ultimate goal of restructuring that industry in the best interests of all Australians. We could stop what is occurring at the moment with poor dealer against dealer, consumer against consumer and State against State. We could overcome that. Country people are disadvantaged as a result of all this argument. I hope that the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) will consider the petroleum industry in the way in which he is considering other industries and then I will give him the support that he would richly deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the Customs Amendment Bill 1983 and the consequential amendments to the Industries Assistance Commission Act and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Act. The commercial by-law system to which this legislation refers has been a feature of Australian tariffs since Federation. The system has progressively expanded since that time and now applies to between one-quarter and one-third of total imports. The estimated value of concessions provided under the system is more than $600m annually. As the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has commented, the system has extensive support from all sectors of the business community. Many Australian production activities depend to varying degrees on the concessional entry of imported inputs and the by-law system provides a means of reducing costs and prices while at the same time maintaining the general protective effect of the tariff on local industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industries Assistance Commission, in its report of 2 July 1982 on the commercial by-law system, concluded that the existing commercial by-law system was not operating in a manner fully consistent with the guidelines for assistance policy and recommended that a number of changes be made to improve the commercial by-law system. The main purpose of the Bill now before the House is to give effect to many of those recommendations by amending the Customs Act 1901 and introducing a new system for granting tariff concessions, to be known as the commercial tariff concession system. As a result of the Customs Amendment Bill 1983, consequential amendments are proposed also to the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975.

The adoption of these Bills will improve the administrative efficiency of the system, as well as providing a clearer framework within which importers and local manufacturers can operate. The establishment of a clearer and more predictable trading framework is essential to the fundamental goal of achieving sustained economic growth. In this respect clause 5, concerning sections 269B, 269C and 269E of the Customs Act, is essential to the establishment of this clearer and more predictable trading framework. I intend to deal with each in a little more detail. Section 269C provides for the issuing of a commercial tariff concession where the Minister is satisfied that no goods serving similar functions are produced or are capable of being produced in the normal course of business in Australia. Under existing legislation a commercial by-law may be granted provided that 'suitably equivalent reasonably available goods are not available for Australian production'. Such a definition is vague and somewhat cumbersome.

Considerable difficulties have arisen over a period, particularly in relation to the interpretation of the phrase 'suitably equivalent'. These difficulties were well documented in the IAC's report of 2 July 1982. Importantly, the legislation before the House removes that ambiguity and vagueness by providing a very clear definition of the key words 'similar functions'. The test of whether goods do or do not serve similar functions is specified in proposed section 269B of the Act as the degree of cross-elasticity of demand between those goods. Essentially this comes down to the question of whether the imported goods actually compete with, or have the potential of competing with, Australian produced goods. Such a definition is considerably clearer and less ambiguous than the previous definition 'suitable equivalents' and will ensure better protection for Australian industry as well as a more predictable trading framework for our importers.

Clause 5 of the Bill, dealing with section 269E of the Act, provides for ministerial discretion in cases where the granting of concession would be likely to have a substantially adverse effect on the market for Australian-produced goods, or if it is not in the national interest. The clause removes anomalies under the existing legislation and provides more effective protection for Australian industry. An example of difficulties arising under the existing legislation was the use of polythylane coated paper board for the packaging of milk. A commercial by-law for such paper board had been in existence for some years before local glass bottle manufacturers realised its effect on their sales . The new provision will allow swift ministerial action to be taken in such instances.

Similarly, situations have occurred in the past where already highly protected local industry has sought concessional admission on an essential manufacturing input, thereby receiving substantially greater protection than intended under tariff policy. Again, the new provisions will allow swift and appropriate action to be taken by the Minister. Further improvements to the existing by-law system are also provided for by the Bill in relation to the advertising of applications for new concessions in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. This new procedure will allow local manufacturers and other interested parties an opportunity to have their views taken into consideration before a commercial tariff concession decision is made. In summary, the legislation before the House does not provide for substantive changes to the tariff system, but does improve and modify the existing by-law system. The legislation was originally proposed by the previous Government. As I have indicated, it should provide a much clearer and more predictable framework in which our importers and local producers can operate. I commend the Bill to the House.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for the warmth of his welcome which is mildly exceeded by the depth of its genuineness. It reminds me that I often wish I had an uncomplicated and perhaps at times unnoticed presence in this place. All I can say is that I made some comments on the matter in Hong Kong. I do not propose to go beyond that except to remind the honourable member that in a few weeks time I will be going to Hanoi after speaking with our colleagues from the Association of South East Asian Nations at the post-ASEAN meetings. There I will be engaging in what will be quite obviously complicated and demanding consultations. I put it no higher than that.

ANSWER.PARA: I would be the first to acknowledge that the probabilities of success must be seen as rather low. It is, I repeat, a very difficult undertaking we are embarking upon and the risks are high in the sense, I suppose, that one's reputation swings on these things. In our sort of society commentators are interested only in success stories, not when one fails to meet targets one sets oneself. For all that, however, I think we have a responsibility to take risks. I am certain that on that occasion I will go with the good wishes and best hopes of the Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of the continuing misrepresentations of the Government's wages policy by members of the Opposition? Will he again make clear what the Government's attitude is towards the level of and machinery for settlements in 1983 and 1984 so that it can be open to no misunderstanding or misrepresentation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, there has been a continuing misrepresentation and, while I would not normally be an advertiser for the particular commentator in question, I would suggest that honourable members opposite should read the comments of one hirsute commentator in the Age today, who seemed to get it right. So that others can have the clarity of perception of that hirsute commentator, let me make clear again what the position of this Government is. It is that there shall be a return to centralised wage fixation; that the increase that comes out of any hearing by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the latter part of this year should be small. Everything that I look at, all the experiences that I have, confirm that that is a correct position of this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday I had the opportunity of speaking with representatives of unemployed young people, who have been in the vicinity recently. When honourable members understand that this Government and this country must have an overwhelming concern for those who do not have jobs above those who have the good fortune to have them after seven years of the policies of the previous Government, they will know that we must have a wages policy which at one and the same time is consistent with the industrial realities that wage increases of any kind cannot be stopped nor would it be appropriate to stop them. But any wage increases that occur should be minimal. If honourable members understand this they will see the correctness of the policies which I have outlined and which, as far as this Government is concerned, will produce that result. The increase that we see as appropriate in the latter part of this year is only 3 per cent to 4 per cent which, I repeat, will be significantly below what would have resulted if the policies of the previous Government had been allowed to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the high level of Aboriginal unemployment, estimated to be around 60 per cent in urban areas and up to 100 per cent in isolated communities. I refer specifically to the allocations under the wages pause program for employment projects in the States. Can the Minister advise the House whether he has ensured the allocation of a fixed proportion of those funds to Aboriginal employment? If so, what proportion of funds will be allocated? If he has not done so, has he taken action to ensure that the States include Aboriginals in their employment projects? If he has not taken any such action, will he do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I congratulate the honourable member on his appointment as shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I also congratulate him on asking his very first question ever on Aboriginal affairs. I am indeed pleased to see that the honourable member in his new role as shadow Minister now has a concern for the problems of Aboriginal unemployment, most of which were magnified and increased as a result of the policies pursued by the previous Government. The matter is of concern to this Government and it has formed the major part of the Budget submissions which we have endeavoured to put in place. At the appropriate time it will be made clear to the honourable gentleman and all honourable members that it is the policy of this Government in respect of Aboriginal employment to enhance those opportunities throughout Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The biggest single emphasis in our Budget allocations is first on Aboriginal housing, to try to come to grips with the problem and, secondly, on increased employment opportunities. At the first available parliamentary opportunity, I will make a much fuller statement on all the objectives of this Government in terms of the needs of Aboriginal people. The honourable member need have no fear that the neglect which characterised the policies of the previous Government of which he was a supporter is being remedied and will be attended to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to further allegations by the honourable member for Denison that the Prime Minister is aware that the expelled KGB agent, Ivanov, channelled substantial funds to local organisations? Is there any foundation to these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Chisholm for that question. Indeed, my attention has been drawn to the statements made by the honourable member for Denison. I preface my reply by saying that in respect of issues which are related to the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies which my Government has commissioned, obviously our general view is that those matters should now be considered by that royal commission. But I must say that in respect of the question by the honourable member for Chisholm, all canons of decency require that I make a statement at this point.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to say at the outset of my reply that the conduct of the honourable member for Denison has been beneath contempt. The honourable member, as reported in today's Press-I particularly refer to the front page of today's Age-made reference to three conversations that he had with me yesterday. He was reported as saying that he would not disclose the contents of those conversations but he then proceeded to make statements which he knows to be totally inconsistent with the contents of those conversations. Let me, Mr Speaker--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister is not entitled to quote from a Press report unless he is prepared to vouch for its accuracy. I suggest that he cannot vouch for the accuracy of what he is just about to quote.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Let me give the House the background to this matter-I will refer to proceedings which took place in the House yesterday-so that honourable members on both sides of the House can make their judgment about the conduct of the honourable member for Denison. What happened was this: There were indeed three conversations yesterday between the honourable member for Denison and me. I will recount them in order and in relation to what happened in this House. Before Question Time yesterday the honourable member sought to have time to speak with me. Of course, I granted him that time. He came to me and indicated that he was going to ask a question. I do not know why he put this point to me but he asked me to listen very carefully to the question that he was going to put. I listen carefully to all questions, even those coming from the honourable member for Denison. He said that I should listen very carefully to the question. I did listen carefully. I now go, in sequence, to the question and to my answer. The question put by the honourable member for Denison yesterday was in these terms:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question to the Prime Minister by making it quite clear that it is not alleged that he was personally aware of these matters at the time that they occurred. Has the Prime Minister now been provided with information that the expelled Soviet KGB agent Ivanov had provided, or had attempted to provide, substantial financial assistance to certain organisations in Australia? Will the Prime Minister pursuant to paragraph (d) of the letters patent, refer these matters to the royal commissioner, the Honourable Mr Justice Hope?

The answer that I gave-I make no apologies for repeating it because this matter is going to be nailed; so is the miserable conduct of the honourable member going to be nailed-to this House was in these terms:

In the light of the announcement that I made yesterday about the reference of all the circumstances surrounding Mr Combe and the expulsion of Mr Ivanov I believe it is not appropriate that I should, in respect of that matter or any matters dealing with the royal commission, deal with the question raised by the honourable member. But let me say this: I am sure that the honourable member will appreciate and, I hope, accept the answer that I put. If the honourable member has any concern-I do not understand the details of his question-about the issues to which he referred he should raise them with the royal commission. I give him this undertaking: If he should find in respect of the matters which apparently concern him that the royal commissioner indicates that he is incapacitated by any weakness or absence of specific terms of reference that would enable a consideration of such matters, I ask him to approach me and if any action is necessary to enlarge the terms of reference I will consider it.

Following that, the second conversation between the honourable member for Denison and me yesterday took place just behind your chair, Mr Speaker. In that conversation I conveyed to the honourable member for Denison, in respect of the issues he had raised, that to the best of my recollection at no briefing I had attended in regard to this issue had one single word been raised with me which gave any substance to the allegations or innuendo in his question. I said to him : 'I am relying on my recollection. I will go to my office and I will take steps to check whether in fact I am mistaken in my recollection, whether in fact I was informed at any briefing I have had about this matter'. I would have been surprised if that were the case but I said I would check. I did that. I checked with those who had briefed me and they confirmed that what I had said in the second conversation yesterday with the honourable member for Denison was totally accurate-that I had been given no indication of any kind that would sustain any suggestion of the kind made in the question by the honourable member for Denison .

The third conversation took place in the corridor outside this chamber last night when I bumped into the honourable member. I confirmed to him again that there was nothing that I had been told which would in any way sustain, in my mind, any belief in regard to the matters that he had raised. I have no knowledge from the briefing I have had, or from any other source, which would sustain the allegations that he has made. It is in that sense that I find totally repugnant this report in today's Press. I read from it. Mr Hodgman said- -

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Are you ashamed?
—I have nothing to be ashamed of. The Prime Minister has missed out one conversation. He has missed out the telephone conversation.
—Order! The honourable member should raise his point of order.

—My point of order is that the Prime Minister is again quoting from a Press report in respect of which he cannot vouch the accuracy, and the accuracy of which I dispute. He also has omitted the telephone conversation.

—Order! I will reply to the point of order to make the matter quite clear. It has been the practice of my predecessors in the Chair to allow members to quote from newspaper articles, and I see no reason for reversing that decision.

—I have not overlooked the other conversation. After I had had the confirmation from my security sources and from those who had briefed me in regard to this other matter, I rang the honourable member and told him that. The information which I told him then in the telephone conversation after my recollection which I had given to him behind your chair, Sir, had been confirmed . Again in the third conversation out in the corridor I conveyed that to him. Now, in this morning's Press, we find this statement:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Hodgman said outside Parliament last night that he had spoken with Mr Hawke three times yesterday about the matter: once before question time and twice after question time.
I have conveyed that to the House. The article continues:
He said that Mr Hawke had phoned him about his allegations during yesterday afternoon, but Mr Hodgman refused to disclose what was said in that conversation .
Marvellous! The article goes on:
Mr Hodgman said: 'If the Prime Minister does know of these matters, he should tell Parliament. If he does not know, it indicates a very serious situation indeed'.
This is in quotation marks, Mr Speaker:
'I would find it incredible if he did not know'.

So what this House now has before it is a situation where the matter was raised in the House, I gave my answer and spoke to the honourable member behind your chair, Mr Speaker, and told him directly that as far as I could recall there was nothing to sustain his question. I checked with those who had briefed me and was told: 'No, you have been given no information'. I rang the honourable member and told him that and then again last night in the corridors of this House I told him the same thing. Then this man says: 'No, I am not going to talk about the conversations but I am going to say that I would find it incredible if he did not know'. I leave all honourable members of this House to make their judgment about this man.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industry whether he is aware of fears of the United Dairy Farmers of Victoria that up to 20,000 dairy factory employees and 17,000 dairy farmers could lose their jobs because of the continued dumping on the Australian market of highly subsidised cheese from the European Economic Community? Given that the Minister has just visited Brussels, did he raise this issue with EEC officials? What is he doing to stop this dumping activity and to protect those 37,000 jobs?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt somewhat the magnitude of the honourable member's figures, but what he points to has also been pointed out most strongly by the honourable member for McMillan, and that is that the rising level of cheese imports, particularly from the EEC, is causing a real problem to Australian dairy farmers . In the last year imports of cheese from the EEC rose by about 54 per cent and in the first six months of this year they have risen again by another 25 per cent. The industry has taken an action before the relevant authorities. It is pretty clear in my mind that it is in a position to show, if not damage, then that it is being very much prejudiced by the action of the EEC in putting cheese into this country often at subsidised prices, because the EEC is paying export restitution on the cheese that is coming in.

QUESTION.PARA: This matter is before the relevant authorities. It is a matter of which I am very well aware. It is a matter that I raised with the EEC officials in Brussels . As a matter of fact, it took up as much time as did sugar. It is a matter that is under the closest consideration by me and my Department, and we should have some decision on it within days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware of the remarks made yesterday by the honourable member for Denison in response to the Minister's announcement of the Government's migrant intake policy? Is the Minister concerned that such remarks might cause grave concern within the ethnic communities, especially the allegations that the Government's immigration policy is 'authoritarian' and is moving towards an 'anti-English-speaking' policy?

—Yesterday-I note that this received some publicity in the media-the honourable member for Denison replied to my statement on the new immigration intake policy by suggesting that we were implementing a bias against English- speaking people. This is in line with his usual capacity for misleading and outrageous statements. What I said was that, within an overall parameter of a maximum of about 90,000 visaed migrants, this Government will be giving a very high priority, as it should, to family reunion and to refugees, and that under the former Government family reunion was affected by admission criteria which were heavily biased in favour of English-speaking professional people with loads of money. That is the fact. That is what happened. Under the former Government some people were more entitled to family reunion than others. There are six million people in Australia who were born overseas or who have one parent or both parents born overseas. Family reunion should not be based on employment grounds alone, as it was almost, under the previous Government. There are humane social considerations. We believe that people, perhaps at the middle or at the lower end--
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker, the immigration policy that prevailed until yesterday was a bipartisan policy. It is not true--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—If it was a bipartisan policy, it is the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Denison, who is attempting to destroy that bipartisan policy. Arranged employment will still retain 10 points out of 60 in the sponsorship criteria. But what was happening before was that people who were fluent in English were getting two points more-that is not very much-than people who just had a capacity to learn English. I have removed that category-that is, removed the ability to get two points more. The honourable member is trying to misrepresent that very necessary move as a bias towards non-English-speaking people and a bias against people who speak English. That is incorrect. Employment will still receive just consideration. A person will get 10 points, out of 60, for pre-arranged employment. I conclude by informing the House that to remove an extraordinary bias against non-English-speaking people is not in itself a means of commencing a bias against English-speaking people.
—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. In view of the public disquiet about organised crime and the need for a national crimes commission--
—Order! The House will come to order.
—I ask the Prime Minister whether the Government--

—Order! The House will come to order. The right honourable gentleman is entitled to ask his question without interjection. It seems to me that there are interjections from both sides of the House. A reasonable degree of latitude can be permitted but we are getting beyond it. I call the Leader of the National Party to ask his question.

—I ask the Prime Minister whether the Government will proclaim the legislation passed by Parliament last year to establish such a commission? What is the position of Sir Edward Williams, who was appointed commissioner designate ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the honourable member asked the question that he did. I am in a position to inform the House of very concrete steps which the Government is taking, not to talk words but to translate into action the unqualified determination of this Government to ensure that everything that can possibly be done is done to smash organised crime in this country. I can assure the House that, in the very short time we have been in government, those steps make the relative inaction of our predecessors pale into insignificance.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently the Special Minister of State, the Attorney-General and I met in Melbourne with Royal Commissioner Costigan and senior members of his staff to be fully briefed on the stage which their work had reached. I can say to this House that a magnificent amount of detailed work has been done and we are so committed to ensuring that that work will be facilitated and moved to the point at which effective prosecutions can be put in place that, as I think the Special Minister of State announced recently in the House, we have made very significant increases in the financial support available to the royal commissioner, in terms of the request that he has made, to ensure that the work that that royal commission is undertaking will be brought to effective fruition.

As to what we are doing in respect of the legislation to which the honourable member referred, while ensuring that the resources available to Royal Commissioner Costigan- and I think the honourable member will appreciate the great work that has been done there-are increased, we are ensuring that, as a result of those increased resources, there will be a position in which there can be the most effective transition from the work of the Costigan royal commission to the work of the National Crimes Commission. We will see--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was in place already.

—I understand that the honourable member who asked the question is following the answer. I think he would appreciate and, I hope, approve the course we are following. What we are doing is to ensure that by increasing the resources of the Costigan royal commission the work of the commission will be increased and improved and that, at the beginning of 1984, we will be in place, with the proclamation of the Act, for the National Crimes Commission to take over, in the most effective way, the work of the royal commission.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the question that the honourable member asked with regard to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Edward Williams.

—I have not forgotten that part of the question. It has been indicated that we will not at this stage be requiring the services of His Honour because it will be appreciated, in terms of the answer that I have given to this point, that we just cannot keep him hanging around until 1984 when we will have the National Crimes Commission take over the work of the Costigan commission, work which we have increased. His services have been made available back to the Supreme Court of Queensland and the Government, at an appropriate and an effective time, will be making a decision as to who is most appropriate to head up the work of the National Crimes Commission.

—Has the Minister for Health seen an article in last Sunday's Brisbane Sunday Sun in which the Queensland Minister for Health, Mr Brian Austin, accused the Federal Government 'of leaving thousands of old people out in the cold while it dithered over a new nursing home policy'? Will the Minister say whether Mr Austin's statement was accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is extraordinarily difficult to establish co-operative relationships with a Minister who uses every communication simply for pretty base political purposes. Six weeks ago I informed Mr Austin, as an act of courtesy, of an investigation which was about to take place in a Queensland hospital. He immediately blabbed that information both to the Press and to Parliament thereby potentially imperilling that operation. Last week I sent him information concerning new policy guidelines in relation to nursing homes. He immediately sought to exploit that letter for the same cheap, partisan purposes. He made two allegations in the newspaper, both of which are incorrect. First of all, he said that we were leaving thousands of old people out in the cold. As a nursing home takes at least 12 months to be built, if there are any old people out in the cold in Queensland they are there as a result of the policies of the last Government. I do not believe that there are in that sense; I am not blaming the last Government. But, if they are out in the cold it is the responsibility of the previous Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The other charge he made is that we are dithering over our new nursing homes policy. The opposite is the truth. Immediately after coming to government we were faced with the recommendations of the McLeay Committee report, which was highly critical-Opposition members are aware of this-of the allocation, distribution and effectiveness of the nursing home program. Therefore, immediately, rather than dithering, we asked that new guidelines be prepared for determining the allocation of nursing homes and that, while those were being prepared, no allocations be made. Those nursing home guidelines have been completed and have been sent to all State Ministers. Of course, we are still waiting for a reply from Mr Austin. As soon as those replies are in we will initiate that new policy and there will be special instructions to the Department to deal quickly with all the applications which are now in the pipeline.

I think responsible members of the Opposition will agree that next year the nursing homes policy will cost us, in benefits, over $800m. A responsible government must see that that money is spent in the most effective way possible. We have taken immediate action, rather than dithering, to make that policy effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. It refers to a recent ruling by the Victorian Deputy Commissioner of Taxation that losses arising from the difference between income received and interest paid on investment properties are not tax deductible. Does the Minister agree that this ruling, applied throughout Australia, will be a disincentive to investment and lead to an increase in rental payments by Australians who do not own or who are purchasing their own homes? Further, does the Treasurer agree that the ruling will lead to a significant number of investment properties coming on to the property market, thus having serious ramifications for new housing demand in relation to his Government's plan to increase housing commencements? Will the Government take action urgently to rectify this matter?

—There has been some Press speculation and comment about the assessment issued by the Victorian office of the Commissioner of Taxation in respect of negative cash flows on properties. It is a matter which is causing some disquiet, I understand, in property circles. Of course, the assessment was issued last November in terms of the administration as the Victorian Deputy Commissioner saw it. The Government believes that clear policy implications are involved in the ruling. The matter is now under review. The Government will make a determination about it at the appropriate time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TEXTILE, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR ADVISORY COMMITTEE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of recent articles, particularly one which appeared in the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 10 May, purporting to be based on a confidential draft report of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee? Is it the Minister's understanding that this report is circulated to members of the committee on a confidential basis in order to promote informed discussion and comment on a wide range of issues and that the leaking of this information undermines the whole process of the committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Tangney for his question. It goes to the heart of a very important committee report. I think everybody in this House would share the concern that we all have for the continued viability of textile, clothing and footwear industries.
—Don't count me in that.

—The honourable member for Hume wants to be counted out of that so we will count him out. I am aware of Press reports purporting to quote extracts from the advisory committee's draft report. Members of this House, particularly members of the previous Government, will understand that the independant chairman of that committee is Mr David Elix, for whom I think there is widespread respect. I wish to emphasise that the report was in fact in draft form and was circulated, as the questioner has noted, on a confidential basis to members of the committee's advisory council in advance of the council meeting that took place on 13 May. Of course, it has been a long-standing practice to circulate draft reports in advance so that councils, with the benefit of draft reports, can involve themselves in meaningful and informed discussions at council meetings, the objective being that discussions be as constructive and as non-partisan as possible. I understand also that industry council members value this practice.

ANSWER.PARA: The advisory committee is now finalising its report on the whole question of continued support and protection for those three very important industries and will submit it to the Minister for Industry and Commerce later this month. On that account, therefore, it is not appropriate at this stage for me to comment on the draft report or its contents. But I say to the House that the Minister for Industry and Commerce is very disappointed that the very basis of advanced circulation has been jeopardised, as was pointed out in the Press reports, by the precipitate action of some rather unprincipled and unknown person.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister noted that the recent report of the Industries Assistance Commission on assistance to Australian agriculture has found that the overall level of assistance to that sector has declined significantly in contrast with the increased assistance to manufacturing industry? Further, has he noted the findings in paragraph 4.64 of the Balderstone report that Australian agriculture should receive more assistance than it currently obtains? In the light of his pre-election commitment to Australia's great primary industries and in the light of the findings of these two great reports, will his Government honour at least one of its election commitments and increase assistance to agricultural industries?

—The answer to the first part of the question asked by the honourable member is yes. I have applied my reasoning to it and have come to the conclusion that the fact that the IAC has made these findings in regard to the present state of assistance to the primary sector vis-a-vis the rest of Australian industry reflects the outcome of the decisions of the Government of which the honourable member was a member for so long. Whatever is the current misallocation of assistance, if there be such, between sectors, it is, as the IAC will have found, a result of the application of the decisions of the previous Government of which he was a member. In regard to the second part of the question, yes, I am aware of the Balderstone report. Thirdly, regarding what this Government will do about Australia's great primary industries, these are the things we will do: Firstly, we have provided them with a man who has already established his mark as the best Minister for Primary Industry that has been seen in this country for more than 20 years. He has the total confidence of every sector of those great Australian primary industries. I am very proud of the very effective working arrangements and understanding that exists between the Minister and the primary industries. Secondly, we have established close working relations with the representatives of Australian primary industry. As recently as this week I was honoured to open the national conference of the National Farmers Federation. I did this with great pleasure and conveyed to that conference the attitude and the policies of this Government, which I am very glad to say were welcomed by it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. In view of the high level of public interest in the maintenance and retention of Australia's lighthouses, such as Montague Island, Green Cape and Point Perpendicular, their importance as part of our heritage, and their considerable value not only as marine navigational aids but also as a key element of coastal search and rescue, can the Minister indicate whether the former Government's policy of demanning these installations and converting them to automatic operation is to be continued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the honourable member has been most assiduous in his representations to me on these matters. Lighthouses are an essential maritime navigational aid. Since our Government assumed office I have received a wide number of representations not only from the honourable member for Eden- Monaro but also from other persons and organisations covering aspects of the lighthouse demanning program, such as heritage considerations, search and rescue functions, their coastal surveillance capacity and, very importantly, the needs of local fishing communities and small boat operators. There are some 287 lighthouses-or light aids, as they are technically known-around the Australian coastline, 42 of which are still manned. They involve considerable expenditure- some $28m a year-in maintenance operations. Most of this expenditure is recovered from the shipping industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the wide public concern about the demanning program of the previous Government I have called a halt to the demanning program until such time as there has been an opportunity for full public inquiry and examination of all the issues and aspects I have mentioned. I was pleased to learn from the honourable member for Grayndler, who is the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, that the Committee has decided to undertake a public inquiry into what I see as a very important problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you know about the Budget?

—It is a Budget item. Considerable expenditure is involved. It does have an impact upon sea transport costs and a very important impact upon small fishing and local communities which depend upon these lighthouses, firstly , for navigational aids and, secondly, for safety and rescue operations. I understand that the Expenditure Committee will be advertising shortly to invite submissions to the inquiry. Through you, Mr Speaker, I say to the Chairman of the Committee that I hope the Committee will undertake the onerous task of visiting some of these lighthouses in their remote locations.
—You are junketing.

—It is not junketing. This is a very important service. I hope the Committee will visit the communities, meet the people of the communities and come back to this Parliament with a comprehensive and responsible report and recommendations.

—I refer the Treasurer to his answer on interest rates on 17 May and, in particular, his premature jubilation at the fall in Treasury note yields as a result of a tender held a week earlier. Applying the reasoning contained in his own answer, does the honourable gentleman now assert that yesterday's rise of more than one per cent in 26-week Treasury notes indicates a lack of confidence in financial markets in the Government's policies? Alternatively, will he agree that it was absurd of him in the first place as Treasurer to draw longer term interest rate implications from movements in the notoriously volatile area of short term interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I indicated in fairly measured and reserved terms, as distinct from those just described by the former Treasurer, the fact that there had been declines in interest rates across the board in a number of areas-in secondary market yields, in Treasury notes at the short term end and in both the short and the long term ends of the bond tender. I indicate also to the--
—Would the Treasurer--
—Just listen. You have asked a question. I also indicate, Mr Speaker, that--
—I am sorry to bother you Paul--
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is really trying the patience of the Chair.

—He cannot contain himself after the hammering he received a few minutes ago, Mr Speaker. I just indicate that in the last day or so the Australian exchange rate has started to level off in the appreciation which we had seen with it for quite some days. At the same time, coincidentally, there was a strengthening in the United States dollar. Quite an amount of money was left on an uncovered basis at the time. I think those institutions which had uncovered money sent that money off-shore the day before yesterday-something like $200m crossed the exchanges. I think that yesterday a very much lower figure was involved-$30m to $50m. Any movement in short term rates yesterday reflected a number of factors. The first is that perhaps there was a misinterpretation to some extent of why that money went off-shore the day before last. Secondly, there was some uncertainty about the prospects on the wages front after the announcement of the Australian Council of Trade Unions claim. The third factor is the general anticipation that there always is in money markets about a major government economic statement. However, I am quite confident that in the light of tonight's statement and the fact that, as distinct from our predecessors, the Government has demonstrated and will be demonstrating over time that it is prepared to run a disciplined fiscal policy in line with our stated policy, money markets will settle down in the period thereafter.

ANSWER.PARA: I take this opportunity of saying that I will be very interested tonight, after the Government's statement has been made, to hear the former Treasurer say precisely what he would do with the deficit in prospect, whether in fact he would accept a deficit of $9.6 billion. Will he say precisely whether and where he would cut programs and whether he would resort to taxes in fulfilment of the statement he made a couple of weeks ago that the former Government would have had a deficit far below $9.6 billion? So I invite the former Treasurer, after tonight's statement, to leave off the waffle and come on with some hard detail about what that group of so-called economic managers would have done in the circumstances.
