DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMMITTEE FOR THE EVALUATION OF THE YOUTH SERVICES SCHEME

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the National Committee for the Evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme. The report is entitled ' ''One Step Forward'': Youth Homelessness and Emergency Accommodation Services'. The Youth Services Scheme is a program providing joint Commonwealth and State funding for services providing emergency accommodation and support for homeless youth. The Commonwealth funding is being provided under the Children's Services Program. During 1979-82 the program operated on a pilot basis. Funding was extended for this financial year pending the completion of this report and the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, which was tabled last August.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government now has at hand two substantial reports on youth homelessness and is carefully examining them in the process of making decisions for future assistance in this area. The evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme was conducted by a committee of officials representing Commonwealth and State governments. It reported to all the Ministers involved. As required by the Committee's brief, the report focused entirely on the Youth Services Scheme and the assistance it was or was not able to provide homeless youth. It is not a general research document on youth homelessness as such, nor does it provide a comparative analysis of other methods of assistance to the homeless supported by other programs of the States or the Commonwealth.

The principal focus of the report is on the youth who used the services. It assessed their common situations, their needs, and the degree to which the Youth Services Scheme, as established within its guidelines, was able to meet these needs. The conclusions and recommendations concentrate on the type and level of demand, the needs of the youth, including preventive measures to reduce homelessness; and the features seen as required in future guidelines of any national program of accommodation services to improve the ability to respond effectively to the needs of youth and to make national administration more efficient. The recommendations are not drafted as a policy document ready for implementation but rather suggest parameters and essential features for inclusion in a future policy document.

The report itself contains a summary, on pages 2 to 7. Briefly, the main findings of the evaluation Committee are: The scheme as established was not able to meet all the continuing demand for emergency accommodation. Reasons suggested for this are the volume of demand and the number of youth remaining in accommodation for extended periods. The Committee estimated that for about half the users the principal need was for long term accommodation, that is, some form of independent housing. There is a significant demand from young adults in the age range 19-25 not covered by the guidelines for the particular scheme. A recommendation is that the eligible age range be extended in a future funding scheme. The youth predominantly lack support from their families for a variety of reasons and when this is combined, as it is almost invariably, with unemployment, the ability of youths to attain independence is hindered, rendering them homeless.

Recommendations cover the need for employment opportunities for youth, so they may achieve independence and for improved support for families with adolescents to help them provide a more supportive environment for the youth. A new expanded youth accommodation program is recommended and it is suggested that a program which can better respond to youth homelessness needs to have three components, in an integrated network on a regional basis. Those components are: First, a front line of emergency accommodation services; secondly, a secondary group of services, accepting referrals from the frontline services, providing medium to long term supportive accommodation and services providing assistance in obtaining housing; and, thirdly, a third group providing services directed at the needs of the younger and particularly disadvantaged, for example, those who are handicapped or who have health problems or institutionalised youth. Recommendations covering administration of the recommended new, expanded program suggest continued Commonwealth and State involvement in funding with the Commonwealth component provided through specific purpose block grants to the States.

The report emphasises the need for employment and adequate income for unemployed youth as a means of preventing longer term homelessness. As the House is aware, job creation programs are a high priority for this Government. We will be moving as soon as possible to get the programs under way. It is our hope that these will go a long way to redress some of the problems highlighted by this report. It is also Government policy that the young unemployed living away from home and all unemployed people renting privately should be paid supplementary rent assistance. The Government is concerned that young people should have the opportunity through schooling, or other technical and further education or community courses, to have appropriate training before attempting to enter the work force but, of course, for those unable to obtain work the income benefit should be adequate to allow them to live with dignity. This Government will be establishing a task force to examine the programs currently available which provide educational allowances and other income support for youth between 15 and 24 years of age. We see this as an area in need of urgent review. We will be examining this report and other information closely in this regard.

The Youth Services Scheme is presently being examined as part of a review of all Commonwealth crisis accommodation programs. This review was instigated by the previous Government in 1982 and it is being undertaken jointly by the Departments of Housing and Construction and Social Security. It is expected to be completed in August 1983. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) will also be consulting with the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) on matters which relate to her portfolio.

The recommendations contained in 'One Step Forward' and the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, 'Youth Homelessness', will be considered in the crisis accommodation review. The Government will not be responding separately to these reports until decisions are announced following consideration of the review. Pending finalisation of decisions relating to the long term, the Government is giving urgent attention to the immediate funding requirements of the services. As honourable members will be aware, current funding is only approved until 30 June 1983. The Government hopes to be in a position to make a statement about this shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Before lunch, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), representing the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), introduced a paper to the House which was the report of the National Committee for the Evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme. The report is entitled ' ''One Step Forward'': Youth Homelessness and Emergency Accommodation Services'. There is under way a major review of all Commonwealth crisis accommodation programs instigated by the Fraser Government in 1982 and it is being undertaken jointly by the Department of Housing and Construction and the Department of Social Security. It is expected that this will be completed in 1983. The Government has also a report on homeless youth from the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, 'Youth Homelessness', which I am pleased to hear the Minister and his colleagues are considering within this crisis accommodation review.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition welcomes the appearance of this report. I am sure that to be concerned about homelessness for youth is a bipartisan matter. I am sure that the Minister, although he makes ritual attacks on my supposed mindlessness and lack of interest in this matter, would in all truth and fairness concede that there has been a genuine interest on the part of both sides of the House in the effects on youth of unemployment in particular and the problems that lead to unemployment, some of them unassociated with economic conditions but, of course, made much worse by economic conditions. I have had some immediate contact with the establishment of a youth refuge, and contact with the Community Youth Support Scheme and associated groups that have tried to do something for the housing of homeless youth and have come to appreciate some of the particular difficulties of dealing with these problems. It was these kinds of concerns which led the previous Government to take a deep interest in these matters and I note that that interest is continued by the present Government. We shall certainly be looking forward anxiously to the result of this review, which will be completed, we hope, by the time of the Budget session.

The problems of those who are helpless-not just homeless but helpless-will continue to be with us even if we manage to get through the present economic difficulties and reach lower levels of unemployment. Regretfully, we appear, on the economic projections available to us, to be facing a continuing high level of unemployment, and that will mean that we shall have these problems of those who are the least able to support themselves and to cope in society for some time. I can certainly assure the Minister and his colleagues in the Government that we shall be approaching any proposals that they put forward with humanity and compassion. Despite any of the words that might be flung about in this House during partisan debate, I hope that a genuine approach to the real problems of these young people will continue.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, that is the Customs Amendment Bill 1983, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you have indicated, the House is continuing its debate on the Customs Amendment Bill 1983, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill 1983. This legislation is significant in that basically it is seeking to tighten up the approaches to dumping procedures, a matter that has caused concern both for importers, exporters and competing industries within Australia. However, I say in passing that the legislation draws our attention to the whole matter of protection for Australian industries. The by-law entry and the by-law amendments are just one aspect of the whole anti-dumping amendments and anti-dumping procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Over a period of years there has been consistent discusssion and debate on industries such as the steel industry, and that matter is before the Government at present. The Australian steel industry feels that it cannot continue at current levels of protection and it has sought from successive governments assistance, protection and a capacity to have a greater share of the market for particular steel products. Despite the claims of the current Government just prior to the election, I have to say that at this stage there is apparently no action or no decisions by the Government in regard to the steel industry. The Government claimed before the election that it would be able to solve these problems and provide for all Australians an effective, viable steel industry which would maintain employment, but the difficulties of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and of the Wollongong area continue, and they are continuing in such a way that people are still losing jobs and still having the same problems, because the problems have not changed. The whole of Australia waits with great anticipation for the decisions of the current Government on the Australian steel industry, when they are finally made. I should like to suggest that by postponing a decision the Government is allowing the problems to solve themselves. That is hardly consistent with its approach to this problem before the election.

In the textiles and footwear industries, in which many Australians have been employed-many on a part time basis; and many females have been employed in these industries-there has been, over a period, firstly an equal pay for equal work proposition, then further protection measures, and finally, when it was realised that these industries were not competitive by world standards or by any standards, a fairly dramatic shedding of labour in them. The structured downturn of protection-if I may call it that-over the last 10 years in Australia has now produced some fairly significant effects, both in the composition of the Australian manufacturing industries and in the composition of those who are seeking employment. In many instances, individuals who have trained for a lifetime in an industry find it difficult to replace their skills or to upgrade their skills to the type that are needed in the work force today. Probably one of the real tragedies of unemployment are the 50-year-olds who, through redundancy or lack of prospects, are now on the job market. But the current Government has decided that there will no changes in protection policies at present.

I should like to draw the particular attention of the House to the way in which some of the decisions on, first, the steel industry were arrived at, and then perhaps to decisions on some of the metal trades industries also, because I think that they are revealing and offer us some prospect for decision taking in the future. In regard to the steel industry, the previous Government considered a draft report from the Industries Assistance Commission. The report proposed to leave open the question whether the steel industry should be permitted to survive over the long term. Given that doubt, even the maintenance of a satisfactory level of activity in it over the short term could have been in jeopardy, and that is what we are now looking at. I quote from page 151 of the report:

The major company in the industry, BHP, says that without assistance comparable with the least efficient manufacturing industries, i.e. a sectoral policy, it will cease investment and will phase out of steel production.

The choices confronting the community are daunting, not only because of the gravity of the issue, but because they depend upon judgments involving certain major uncertainties, conflicts of policy and, ultimately, a choice between undesirable alternatives.
The report went on to state:
The Commission believes that the best course at this stage may be one which keeps the community's options open until the current uncertainties are resolved.

The two 'undesirable alternatives' between which the Commission posed its ' daunting' choice are the liquidation of the Australian steel industry and the granting of protection to the Australian steel industry to the extent necessary to ensure it long term survival. In fact, the Commission proposes to indicate to the industry the clear intention that the additional assistance should terminate and that it should be adjusting towards existing on the current long term rates of assistance.

The IAC considers that, even if the interim assistance period were extended to ten years and all other BHP requests were acceded to, there is a real possibility that, at the end of that period the industry would not be viable at the existing long term levels of assistance or even reasonably close to those levels and that, accordingly, the industry should be liquidated rather than receive further protection. These are serious issues. I know that the current Government is, as was the previous Government, applying its mind to the issues. It is a serious day for Australia indeed if we have to consider whether we should have a steel industry.

I shall quote from a letter from the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, a body which has sought extreme protection in some instances, but at the same time which has offered a point of view that should be noted both by governments and those making decisions. The Metal Trades Industry Association in 1981 drew attention to the appreciation of the Australian dollar and the fact that it had already created a significant rise in imports. It said that a further significant rise was expected as orders were placed overseas to take advantage of the appreciation of the Australian dollar which occurred over the 18 months prior to August 1981. The Metal Trades Industry Association points out :

Tariff reductions, reduction of preference for Australian-made goods, and the continued appreciation of the Australian dollar can only lead to serious economic and social problems, including increased unemployment.

Those problems, indicated at that stage when the whole Australian economy was buoyant, have been brought very much into focus as the Australian economy has turned sluggish and has failed to move. At the same time, a rundown in protection, geared over a period, has taken place. Much the same sort of thing can be said, of course, concerning the Australian textile industry.

What I wish to focus the attention of the House on today are the long term policies that are needed not only to create efficient industries-industries that are competitive in world markets, if that is possible-but also to identify what type of industries they should be. Should they be encouraged? Should there be continuing levels of protection? Are issues within the economic judgments now being made relevant to those long term decisions?

I think everybody is concerned about the shedding of labour that has taken place in Australia's great manufacturing industries. No one who is aware of the situation could be unconcerned. I think if we look at some of the competing factors in manufacturing industries there can be no doubt that the interference by government, whether it be to protect or to relieve protection, is a factor that is not considered carefully enough by governments and their advisers. It is a simple thing for the Industries Assistance Commission to write a report that recommends reducing protection. That body in fact has not with capital, with expertise, with skill and judgment in what it thought was a set market, had to make the decisions on investment that many of our manufacturers have had to make .

It is simple on a theoretical level to say that there should be free world trade, that there should be free trade by Australia with other countries. In fact, last year we saw the efforts of the then Deputy Prime Minister going into the world trading market and putting the proposition that there should be reduced protection by all major traders. They all agreed with that proposition without a single obstacle being raised. The only problem was-it did not matter whether it was Europe, the United States or Japan-not a single country was willing to follow the lead offered by the Australian Government. In light of that practical demonstration of the inability of major manufacturing countries, major producing countries, to open up world trade, it becomes extremely difficult for Australian governments and the Australian people to accept that they should be the only ones that move into the area of free trade and open their boundaries and their shores to the entry, on a non-protected basis, of the goods of any country-no matter what forms of protection, support, assistance or indirect support or protection those countries could offer or do offer to their manufacturers.

One of the most difficult things that I think Australian primary producers have had to cope with over the last two or three years is the fact that sugar refined from sugar beet has been dumped on our traditional markets by highly subsidised industries from Europe. These industries are inefficient and uncompetitive, yet they are highly supported. It does not matter what section of Australian industry we look at, whether it is our traditional exporting industries, our primary and mining industries, their activities and their success can be dramatically affected by the protection and support policies of our trading partners and the other nations which enter into trade.

I put the proposition to the House that it is not a one-sided matter as to what is the best future for Australian manufacturing industries. No careful work has been done on identifying those industries in which people can be employed successfully. We hear about sunrise, sunshine industries. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has entertained this House at length. He has produced only one piece of material, a section of a pipe, saying that this material offers great prospects. It is nothing more in fact that a refined process which employs some people but does not employ the number of people that the total Australian automobile industry can employ. It is an add-on industry. It is a part of the story. It is not the total story and it is not a substitute for the Australian manufacturing industries that we have scattered throughout the nation supplying high levels of employment and opportunities for training and expertise, skills and technology. I quote from a speech made by Sir Robert Cotton in 1976, in which he said:

The calendar year 1974 showed an unprecedented rate of increase in Australian wages. Hourly earnings in manufacturing increased by almost 35 per cent in that year, compared with 29 per cent in the OECD country showing the next highest rate-Spain-and with about 15 per cent on average over the OECD countries.
The first reaction of the Australian corporate sector to this surge in wages was to try to absorb the increased costs. Profits were thus eroded.
When further absorption became impossible, and wage rates continued to rise, firms began to react in other ways.
On the other hand, many firms attempted to reduce labour costs by retrenching staff, reducing production levels or moving from full manufacturing to the assembly of imported components.

These actions naturally affected employment. Meanwhile, the erosion of profits limited the ability of most firms to invest in new productive capacity and hence to create new employment opportunities; and the escalation of Australian construction costs made some firms which could have raised investment capital defer their decision to do so.

That is a situation that we have in Australia today. The same reasons and the same factors are at work in causing the problems of this nation at the moment. Over the last few years it has been obvious that there has been a real growth in wages. Over the last 20 years there has been a real growth in wages in all industries and in all employment. In particular, from the June quarter 1980 to the June quarter 1982-I am aware that that period ended more than 10 months ago- average male earnings increased by 32.4 per cent. During the same period inflation ran at a rate of 20.5 per cent. Average earnings increased over that two-year period by the inflation rate plus an additional 9.9 per cent. Those are the factors that make decisions on employment and the protection of Australian industry extremely difficult. Wage settlements at such extravagant levels make it extremely difficult to decide whether industries which are paying their employees such great increases should continue to be protected.

It is not always the role of the employer to decide these matters. In a speech which I made yesterday on industrial relations, I indicated the significant bullying and standover tactics that are adopted by various unions. That is a matter that is of concern to the Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) raises it during every Question Time, trying to convince himself, rather than the Opposition or members of his Ministry, that the accord and the National Economic Summit Conference have solved the problem. Yet, the community knows and we all know that in the metals industries, the oil industry, the building industry and the transport industry-major employing industries- there are problems about whether people will accept moderation of their wage claims.
In the 1920s and 1930s the protection of Australian industry was important but it was possible in those days for people to understand what was a reasonable return for their day's work.

TALK.START.PARA: —The blue collar workers aren't getting away with it.

—Blue collar workers are some of the most highly paid people in this country. Those in the oil industry, the coal industry and the building industries which I have mentioned, are among the most highly paid, and the honourable member knows it. They are the very people who will bring the manufacturing industry of Australia to its knees. What is needed is wage moderation, careful understanding by union leaders of their responsibility to employment and to the nation and sensitive, well-planned protection and support policies by the Australian Government, directed to these major employers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed because what looked like being a bipartisan approach to this issue has been shot down in the last five minutes. I am disappointed also that the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) sought to apportion blame or responsibility. If he is looking for responsibility certainly the last seven years has been indication enough of where it lies. That kind of simplicity of thinking, that kind of polarisation of thinking, has for the last 20 or 30 years bedevilled discussions in Australia as to the future of our industries. It is as a result of that kind of black and white attitude, that kind of shallowness, that the Australian public does not understand the issues. Nor, I suggest from political debate over the last 20 or 30 years, do speakers from the Opposition side of the House understand them. They seek to paint the issue as one of trade unions forcing themselves out of the market. The ironical thing is that the unions mentioned by the previous speaker are non-import competitive industries. The building industry and the transport industry have a very marginal effect on imports and exports. Therefore , they do not fit into the protection situation to anything like the same degree as do the genuine manufacturing industries. These unions are, in many cases, as honourable members know, very weak.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not my intention to speak today in defence of unions or in criticism of the previous Government. To do either of those two things is to carry on the shallow, simplistic kind of attitude that has taken us nowhere for so long. One can go back over speeches and Press statements made by Ministers of previous governments over many years. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) last December, in speaking on protection and dumping, pointed out the very great problems involved. He pointed out the difficulty of the situation. So there has been a long history of members of the Opposition speaking in very strong terms about the problems that Australian industry has faced in this regard. In those speeches they were not talking about unions, or engaging in the kind of drivel that we have heard this afternoon.

As one who has only recently ceased to be a layman, I can say that what I have read in the Press and in the record of parliamentary debates about protection is very disappointing. Australia has had a free trade group and a protection group. To all intents and purposes those groups have been very polarised. The group that is in favour of protection is described as threatening loss of competitiveness and so on. The group that is against protection is described as threatening loss of employment and the collapse of the industries concerned. Those attitudes have just not allowed the community to understand where Australia stands in relation to today's economic conditions. The theory of import competition is quite straightforward. By allowing minimal duty and imports to compete with local goods, pressure is put on local manufacturers to keep their prices and wages within reasonable parameters. Pressure is put on the inflation rate and Australia's economy is assisted. That has been the theory, but for the last seven years it has been torn to pieces. In practice, the man in the middle does not necessarily pass on the advantages.

I suggest that what has happened in many industries is that, because of the marginal difference in the cost of imports in relation to market prices, advertising budgets have been that much bigger. If free market forces are allowed to go to work goods will find their own market level. They will not necessarily reflect the import price. The difference is made up in the advertising budgets, which make sure that those goods outsell Australian goods at marginally reduced prices. The fact is that the inflation figures of the last seven years have shown that import competition is not passed on, and reflected in lower inflation rates. The inflation rate has remained the same despite the massive increase in imports of manufactured goods.

This afternoon, I want to inform honourable members about a particular industry . It is not the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. It is one that is, technologically, very current. It has machinery and equipment which represents the state of the art in Australia and in the world. A single company produces all of the light globes and fluorescent tubes made in Australia. That company has been making submissions to the Industries Assistance Commission and the Temporary Assistance Authority on anti-dumping action for many years now. From reading its submissions and looking at its operation, I find it incomprehensible that the previous Government did not come to terms with it. I am optimistic that the current Government will. The company, to maintain technological levels of skill, reduced its staff from 629 in December 1979 to 522 in December last year and increased its productivity at the same time. In other words, as new machines became available, they were introduced.

The company had a market capacity in Australia of some 60 million light globes, whereas for European industries the market is so much larger and more capacious that the unit cost in terms of production is less. The major cost is the translation of silica into glass which process is a major energy user. This has meant that the Australian company's volume of production can never compete with the very large European plants. But in recent years there has been a downturn in the use of globes and fluorescent tubes, not only in Australia but also in Europe. People have become less able to buy tubes and globes when they have wanted them. Government departments have not replaced all their globes every year; they have waited until they have needed replacing. There has been a general contraction in market demand.

But in European terms, the need to keep the industry rolling and the furnaces moving to make the glass has meant that European manufacturers can afford to take a very much reduced level of profit. What has happened-the case is well and truly proven-is that the globes that sell at the best wholesale price of 22c in places like Belgium are being sold at a wholesale price in Australia of 16c. The company spent six months working on that project, it spent three months investigating what was happening in Europe and it then waited three months for the anti-dumping action to become mobilised. Six months is a very long time for a single company to try to probe the international market to prepare a case. When the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), Senator Sir John Carrick and many other members of the previous Government indicated their very real concern about anti-dumping mechanisms and the difficulties they had, they were correct. The whole procedure is almost incomprehensible.

The terms of the treaties of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade mean that we have to go to Europe and make inquiries in that market place about current prices. We cannot force those prices to be made known to us and we cannot establish with any real veracity what the market conditions are because, once a government does that, the organisations know about it. If it is hard for a government, it is even harder for a single private organisation. But we expect an organisation as one company to do all that homework to prove its case in advance of any action by government. A company can become bankrupt while going through those procedures. Even if the current dumping action against Belgium is proven, the same globes are also manufactured in Italy and France. It would be quite straightforward for the company to transfer its source country from Belgium to France with the same globes, stamped 'Made in France' rather than ' Made in Belgium', being exported. It would be another three, six or nine months before that case would be examined. If dumping action against France were then successful, the European company would switch to Italy. It is an impossible procedure because we are one country dealing with a whole community, the whole of Europe. We talk about dumping from country to country, not from economic community to economic community. We are an economic community and so is Europe. It seems to me that we are making a very grave mistake to treat Europe on a country by country basis.

If dumping action is successful, because of the integration of companies the potential for transfer pricing becomes paramount. We know what transfer pricing is and what damage it has done. We know how unfair it is not only to Australian industries but also to Australian taxpayers. The question on dumping then becomes: Where is the margin of profit taken? Is it in Australia or somewhere else? The potential then for a company to bring its price up to the current Australian price, but still retain a greater profit potential in the total transaction than it appears to be able to do, is enormous. How on earth can Australian companies continue to exist, particularly those that have done their best to maintain the current state of the art technology?

Having done all those things, if we look at tariff assistance and dumping assistance and consider the effect on prices, we find that it is marginal. European companies can absorb all of that and still be more than competitive and vastly undersell Australian companies. As Australian company's share of the market contracts, its unit cost increases. In other words, the costs become less and less competitive as fewer and fewer globes are made because the energy cost to make the globes becomes higher. Dumping is prevalent in high technology industries and capital intensive industries. Capital intensive industries are the most affected because they require great volume. If the volume is maintained , cost savings are involved. It is worthwhile to sell at an apparent loss to keep the machines going. That is what we find. As Europe is contracting, Australia is presenting itself with open arms but, with all the dumping actions and tariff actions, there is no way in the world that our industries can compete . Eventually the Australian company closes and we then become part of the European market.

I have raised these things because I have read and been aware that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) has announced that there will be an inquiry into dumping. I wanted to flag the kinds of things that should be looked at. I wanted to try to make sure that in the months ahead in this place we take a much more intensive look not only at dumping and protection but also at integration. As the honourable member for Mitchell said in his speech, and I agree with him, we need to examine industries to see which ones can survive and what kind of support is needed. We have to look at integrating dumping protection, government support and industry development in the industrial future that we have. If we do not do that, I am afraid that our industries will collapse one by one. I hope that in the months ahead we can produce a bipartisan approach. It looked to be emerging this afternoon until late in the speech of the honourable member for Mitchell. I hope that we can pick that up in the next few months. With an inquiry and a review of dumping procedures, we will approach the problem in a much more mature and profound way. I can assure honourable members that the industries that I know of cannot afford a parliament that is shallow about approaching this problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I close the debate by making a few comments that I hope are pertinent and intelligent about some of the contributions that have been made. Firstly, I pay tribute to my new colleagues, the honourable members for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and Bendigo (Mr Brumby), for their reasoned, obviously intelligent and interested approach to the Customs Amendment Bill and cognate Bills. It has long been my view in the Parliament, from when I was shadow Minister in this area, that the whole subject of Customs, tariffs, protection, dumping, et cetera has been largely ignored by honourable members, more to the detriment of the Parliament than otherwise. Parliamentarians have failed to realise that the Customs Bureau is responsible for the collection of over $12,000m in various duties, excises and other forms of revenue in a 12- month period. It has always struck me as odd that debates on the subject have been largely ignored by honourable members. I am pleased that some of the new members on this side of the House have made intelligent and reasoned responses and contributions to debates on Customs matters. I refer particularly to the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly, who has long been an intelligent contributor to these sorts of debates. She asked why appeals against concessional tariffs are not directed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal rather than to the Industries Assistance Commission. In answering that, I point out that the tariff concession system is basically part of the administration of industry assistance policy. Decisions obviously should be taken by the Government-that is, the Minister for Industry and Commerce-in that context, rather than referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In fact, this approach was recognised by the Administrative Review Council several years ago when it recommended that appeals should go to the IAC rather than to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, with the Minister making the ultimate decision. That is the view that this Government will take.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take one minute to refer to the contributions from the opposite side of the House. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Ryan, (Mr Moore) who is the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, contributed a rather short speech but I must pay tribute to him because the legislation being debated today is the fruition of attempts that he made when he was the minister to improve the whole system of the administration of by-laws. I pay him tribute for the intelligent piece of legislation that he brought forward before his demise, in rather unfortunate circumstances, from the Ministry. I am pleased to see him stage a resurrection because I have had the ultimate respect for the honourable member for Ryan for a long time. I felt that he was treated very harshly in the whole context. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) read us a rather curious little homily. He treated us to a peculiar little speech. It struck me as being rather odd. It is a pity that he is not listening to me because he might learn something.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had just started to be charitable too.

—I was being charitable but I cannot let his comments pass without some attention. It strikes me as being very odd that someone who sat on his hands for seven years as a member of a government that presided over the whole sorry state that Australia is in at the moment-it has an enormous deficit, incredible unemployment and a manufacturing industry which is in absolute tatters-can start lecturing this Government on what we should be doing about it. I found it rather curious that one of his last expressions was 'bringing Australia to its knees'. The former Government brought Australia to its knees and it is still on them. It is praying that this Government can do something about resurrecting the country from the mess the former Government made.

SPEECH.PARA: I found it very odd that the honourable member spoke about the steel industry. We had a little debate in the House the other day about the steel industry. Let it be recognised by the Opposition that this Government is producing a long term plan for the steel industry, something that it lacked for the seven years that the former Government was in charge of this country. During those seven years the former Government absolutely destroyed the steel industry. I think that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, for one, has confidence in this Government's chances of resurrecting the steel industry and making it strong and viable again . The Opposition might note that the decision taken by BHP a couple of weeks ago to stand down a large number of workers at Port Kembla has been reversed. Mr Loton, the managing director of BHP, was able to convince his company that under the present Government there was a chance for the steel industry. That stand down decision has been reversed. The Steel Industry Advisory Council, with which I had discussions the other day, is busily involved with the Government, the unions and the employers in bringing down a long term plan to resurrect and reconstruct the steel industry, which is very important not just in terms of its employment capacity but also because of its great importance to Australia's national defence policy and national image.

The honourable member for Mitchell also said something about the textile, clothing and footwear industries. He may have heard an answer I gave in Question Time in which I said that the advisory commitee concerned has produced a report which is now in the hands of the Minister. Hopefully, within the next month or two, a long term plan for that industry will be produced. I am pleased to say that the honourable member has a new interest in the fact that industries have been shedding people and that unemployment is rife. It became rife because of the lack of any leadership on the part of the previous Government in every form of industry, but particularly the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the steel industry, to which he referred in particular.

The Government is pleased to introduce this legislation although it was initiated by the previous Minister. We are pleased that we have developed a new system of handling concessional entry into Australia. The old by-law system which probably served us fairly well since Federation is now outmoded. We think that the new concessional tariff system which we have introduced is based on what is practical and realistic in the market place. The key factor will be competition, or the potential for competition, between various kinds of goods. Applicants will be obliged to look beyond their own immediate needs. This system should minimise the risk of inconsistent or inequitable decisions. Certainly, predictability will be improved. I am pleased that I have been able to introduce this legislation. I am sure the new system will serve Australia well.

Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Ms Fatin:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to pass on my congratulations to the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) on his elevation to the high office of Mr Speaker. I would like also to congratulate those honourable members who have made maiden speeches. I always find maiden speeches interesting as one can ascertain the mettle of new members. It is apparent that a large number of new members are thinking people. I have no doubt they will make a contribution in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I wish to say a few words on economic policy. As we know, this evening the Government is to bring in what is termed a major economic statement or, as it is called by others, a mini-Budget. I do not want to canvass in any way what may or may not be said by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) this evening but I do want to talk a little about what I think this country needs. I think it is appropriate that people contribute to debate in this Parliament about this important subject. There is no doubt that there is a need for a sound economic policy if we are to have any sort of recovery in this country. If the National Economic Summit Conference did anything it did expose much of what is needed if that recovery is to begin and if it is to take hold in Australia. Many eminent contributions were made in the context of the Economic Summit. It is to the credit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he was able to bring it off and that he was able to reach the level of agreement that was reached. I think that all sides involved in the Summit expressed willingness to co-operate. The Government provided information and displayed a willing attitude. Business-big it may have been-expressed a willingness to co-operate and the trade union movement at that time also expressed its willingness to assist in the process of economic recovery.

The tragedy of the Summit was that significant portions of the Australian community were not represented. Another tragedy is that the trade union movement has walked away from the Summit. Within a period of only a couple of weeks it has in effect knifed whatever achievements may have been made at the Summit. The announcements following the executive meeting of the Australian Council of Trade Unions the day before yesterday must have come as an enormous blow to the Government and its economic managers. Mr Dolan and his executive have signalled quite clearly that the trade union movement is not going to co-operate any more with Mr Hawke and his Government than it co-operated with Mr Fraser and his Government. I think that is something which all Australians, if they are going to be honest about it, would want to regret. I think everybody was hoping that the trade union movement would realise that there was a lot of merit in having some industrial sanity in relation to wage policy in this country. I think the fact that the trade unions, so soon after the Summit, have been prepared to walk away from and effectively kill it is a tragedy for all of us in Australia. As I said last night, the million dollar buzz phrase at the moment is that the Summit continues. I think the actions of the ACTU executive earlier this week have laid the Summit to rest. We have a million dollars worth of advertising perhaps but this is not going to change the reality that the Summit does not continue.

The Government which has a responsibility for economic policy these days has to achieve a slowdown in wages. If it does not, the effect on the economic recovery of this country will be devastating. It must bring about a significant change in the share of the gross domestic product which is going to wages and profits. If it is not able to bring about a significant alteration so that a greater percentage goes to profits, economic recovery will not get off the ground. There also has to be significant taxation reform in this country if the people are to support the sorts of initiatives that government might choose to take.

Recovery, obviously, is going to involve the availability of money and investment in the country to move to the areas where the return is greatest. Obviously, the same applies to labour. I listened with interest to many of the contributions that were made in the previous debate in which matters such as protection, tariffs and the problems of certain industries were raised. In that debate the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), as he did during Question Time today, made passing reference to the clothing, textile and footwear industries. If there are any industries in Australia which have demonstrated that they do not have the capacity to survive without massive handouts from consumers and taxpayers through the Government, it is that group of industries. These industries probably have received more protection per head than most others. Certainly, they have received far more than they deserve. Despite that, employment in this group of industries continues to decline and obviously will continue to decline further. Despite the extent of assistance that may be made available they are high cost inefficient industries. To the extent that these industries are in the manufacturing sector, they have no future whatsoever.

I want to express my very firm belief that we have to achieve some long term commitment to the reduction of protection in Australia. There is only one way we can achieve any sort of growth in Australia. We have to encourage those industries in Australia which are the efficient industries. There is no point whatsoever in going down the track and trying to prop up the clothing, textile and footwear industries, trying to prop up all the inefficient bleeding hearts around the manufacturing sector of this country that have no contribution to make unless they can operate under a very heavy protective umbrella. Yet there are efficient industries in Australia, industries which contribute to growth and development and to raising the standard of living in this country. I refer particularly to industries within the rural sector that survive with little or no protection. I put to one side for a moment those industries that cannot survive without massive doses of assistance. But there are, within the rural sector, industries-principally wheat, wool and meat-that contribute enormously to the economy of this country and which receive little or no protection. I think also of the great mining and extractive industries that survive without any protection and which have the capacity also to contribute enormously to our export earnings and the standard of living in this country. I think also of industries in the tertiary sector which survive very well without any protection or need for assistance. Also, there is no need for handouts or government support in the enormous small business sector of Australia. Those industries will provide growth as well as employment and investment opportunities. They do not need protection and should be encouraged.

There are obviously industries in the manufacturing sector that survive without handouts from government. They survive without having to bleed consumers and taxpayers as do so many others through the protection process. I would like to say that I did not always agree with the policies of the former Government in relation to these matters. I think the former Government responded too much to sectional interests in different parts of the economy. Perhaps it acted properly because of its honest and genuine concern about unemployment. But the fact of the matter is that the stage is reached where governments have no option. Government has to encourage growth and it has to ensure that the resources of the economy are being directed into those areas where growth will be maximised if the standard of living of the country is to continue to expand. I think this is of fundamental importance; it is something we must look at. I will be very keen to see the sort of attitude that is developed by the new Government. My belief at this early stage-without wanting in any way to be condemnatory before matters are introduced into this Parliament and before Ministers make statements -is that the realities are that the Labor Government will continue to support low growth industries that may have some employment problems at the moment but which in the longer term must face up to reality.

Future economic growth, job creation and innovation would be prejudiced by a recourse to the strategy of the 1950s which demonstrably failed in the 1970s. Higher employment levels can be achieved only by structural adjustment to changed conditions. It is fundamental that we realise that. Policies such as protection that hold up such adjustments are anti-growth and anti-job creation policies. It is still true that economic welfare and jobs would benefit in the medium term from a gradual pre-announced reduction in protection levels. That is something to which the previous Government in philosophy and in policy was committed and I hope that the present Government will continue to move down that track. Other things are of fundamental importance if recovery and economic growth are to become a part of this great nation again. It is import- ant that we reduce controls and intervention because all they do is perpetuate inefficiency. They restrict the freedom of movement of capital and labour particularly to those areas where they will do the most good for Australia. They inhibit economic growth. Anything that does this must not be allowed to become part of any economic policy in Australia.

It is obvious that we must reduce the level of inflation. I am bitterly concerned and disappointed when I look at the track the Government has chosen to go down as a result of the Economic Summit. I refer to this matter again and again because the figures that have been made available by this Government, which bear the imprimatur of this Government and which have been put before the country by this Government make it clear that this Government is not only a high unemployment Government but also a high inflation Government. That is what this economic policy that the Government wants to pursue is all about. If we are prepared to stand by in this Parliament and not be critical when criticism is deserved, we will fail as an Opposition. There is absolutely no doubt that the economy of this country is now in the hands of the Government. It is in the hands of the Treasurer and those behind him who make economic policy in the Cabinet of the Hawke Labor Government. I do not want to hear any more of this nonsense about economic policies being determined by John Howard or by Malcolm Fraser. That is over and done. Whatever may have been done or not done by Fraser and Howard in the previous Government, it is finished. It is now, as it has been for the last two and a half months, the responsibility of the Labor Government, of Paul Keating and his cronies, to develop the economic path that this economy will go down in the years ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I draw your attention to the fact that members are required to refer to members in accordance with the Standing Orders. The honourable member is not doing that.
—That is correct. I ask the honourable member for Hume to follow that course.
—This is the same speech as you gave last night.

—I inform the honourable member for Canberra that I will give it again and again. It is important that its message is emphasised to not only the people in this Parliament but also the people outside. The unemployed in Australia who voted for a new deal under the Hawke Government have been told in the papers from the Economic Summit that under the scenario which the Government prefers, scenario A, by the time we get to the end of the track, 1985-86, unemployment will be at a level of 9.7 per cent. That is what the unemployed of this country have to look forward to under this Government which was elected by the people of Australia in some sort of enthusiastic belief that they would get a better deal. However, I did not start off with the intention of speaking about unemployment; I intended to speak about inflation. That is at the core of everything-honest money and a responsible approach to monetary management in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It has already become apparent that the Government is not prepared to take the decisions that need to be taken if we are to have recovery, sound economic management, a return to profitability, the creation of jobs in the private sector-which is the only sector of the economy that can create them-and to have some sound economic recovery and growth. I wanted to speak about inflation because under this Government's best inflationary expectation, scenario A-which is the scenario that the Government thinks it is following; I say thinks because since the ACTU executive meeting earlier this week that has been shot down in flames-by 1985-86 the consumer price index increase will be 6.5 per cent. That is some reduction on the present position, but if we consider what is happening in the countries with which we trade, those economies with which we compare ourselves, we find that that is not a satisfactory result particularly if we take into account that under scenario C there was the prospect of having inflation by 1984-85 at 2 per cent and in 1985-86 at only 3.7 per cent. We have to look along that track, and that is the sort of scenario the Government must be prepared to adopt. When the Treasurer brings down his economic statement tonight, I hope that is the track he is prepared to follow.

If we are realistic about this, we have to be prepared to look at what will happen to scenario A after the ACTU's climb down from the Summit. What will happen? Inflation will be in excess of 13 per cent even if wage increases can be held down to the sort of figures outlined in scenario B. Scenario B will in reality be the economic policy that this Government will accept, because it is what the trade union movement will demand of it.

I come back again to the fact that the priorities for this economy and for economic management in Australia are being determined by this Government, not by the last Government. We will undoubtedly come to a situation of economic shambles. Honourable members opposite who have recently arrived in the wave of the 5 March election must remember that two or three years down the track- whenever it is that we reach the polls-the economy of this country will be in a shambles. It will be in a shambles because of the decisions that will be announced tonight by the Treasurer and those that have already been taken by this Government. It will be in a shambles because of the lack of capacity of the Government to hold the ACTU to the contents of the communique from the Economic Summit and its total incapacity to hold any sort of economic line in this country. When that shambles develops, honourable members opposite will not be able to point their fingers at us. The fingers will be properly and directly pointed at the Government because it takes the decisions. It develops its priorities and responsibility and accountability must be sheeted home to the Government. This Government has the responsibility; it is making the decisions. I throw out a challenge to this Government to rein in the trade union movement and to act responsibily in the interests of Australia. I challenge it to follow an economic policy that will bring about growth in this country and increase the standard of living of all Australians and provide jobs for those who want to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before calling the honourable member for Kingston, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and that he should be afforded every courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In this, my maiden speech, I take this occasion to ask you, sir, to congratulate the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) on his election to his high office of Speaker and to say to him that I am sure that he will serve the House with distinction and for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by thanking the electors of Kingston for placing their confidence in me at the election on 5 March. I undertake here that I shall serve them to the best of my ability-importantly, in doing my part to implement the policies of the Hawke Labor Government which received such resounding endorsement at the general election; and even more importantly, in making myself personally available to my constituents as their channel to their Government. I thank also the many hundreds of women and men in the Australian Labor Party who worked so wholeheartedly during the campaign. Words do not express thanks as well as deeds , and it will be on my actions in giving effect to these undertakings that I hope to be judged in the coming years.

Also, as is traditional, I pay tribute to my erstwhile opponent, Mr Grant Chapman, who represented Kingston from 1975 until this year. I wish him well in his present occupation and I am hopeful, if not entirely confident, that he will be my opponent again.

The division of Kingston, since its creation in 1949, has always been a marginal seat. It was held first by the Liberal Party, longest by the late Pat Galvin for the Labor Party-from 1951 until 1966-briefly again by the Liberal Party, by Dr Richie Gun for the ALP from 1969 to 1975, and by Mr Chapman from 1975. The present division is also in many respects a cross-section of South Australian society and of Australia generally. It contains a variety of important industries for South Australia: A major car plant; a number of manufacturers, including makers of components for the automotive industry; South Australia's only oil refinery; an important meat works; and not least, several industries based on innovative technology. A major university lies just outside Kingston and several other tertiary education institutions lie within it.

Kingston covers also the wineries of the southern vales where, I assure the House, the best wines in Australia are produced. It also has a developing tourism industry based on the twin attractions of the wineries and the best beaches in Australia. Its population is also mixed. There are a number of older suburbs, but the bulk of the population lives in newer and still rapidly growing suburbs and rural areas. The attractions of the area have meant that many young married people have gone there to buy their first home. Equally, however, many older people have gone there to retire. Kingston is thus a microcosm of Australia and, like much of the rest of Australia, voted decisively for a change of government on 5 March. This representative character of Kingston prompts me to spend a few minutes analysing why, as it seems to me, the Australian people voted as they did on 5 March.

I believe that the main reason was that the Labor Party was seen by people in all walks of life as caring about their problems. We did not just dismiss those problems by saying that 'life was not meant to be easy', or by promising simply more of the same policies which had proved so unsuccessful over the past seven years. In the areas that were most important to people in my electorate of Kingston we, as a party, not only showed our concern but also put forward constructive policies to deal with those problems.

We cared, to begin with, about the chaos in the health system in Australia. We cared that because under the Fraser administration health care had become so expensive and so complicated, some two million Australians had opted out of the health system entirely, taking the tremendous risks that that entails. We cared; and we promised, and we will deliver, a return to a universal health system-a cheaper and more efficient system which will provide the benefits of decent health care to all people, regardless of their incomes.

We cared about housing. The housing crisis in this country is nowhere more evident than in the new growing areas where young people are seeking to buy their first home. Kingston has one of the highest proportions of first home buyers of any electorate in Australia and, therefore, has suffered disproportionately from the massive increases in home mortgage interest rates under the previous Government, as well as from the previous Government's unconscionable slashing of funds for public housing. The South Australian Housing Trust, which is an excellent and innovative body which does a first rate job depends largely on Federal funds for its home building program. It has been forced to curtail its activities drastically in recent years, relative to the demand for housing, since things are rapidly reaching the ridiculous point where the Housing Trust receives less under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement than it has to pay back to the Commonwealth to service existing loans.

We cared, for example, that for every emergency housing place in the Kingston area there are 40 eligible applicants, that every night homeless kids are sleeping on the beaches or inside the used clothing bins which are placed by charities. We cared that so many people are being driven from their homes into second-rate accommodation such as caravans that many caravan parks in my electorate are now almost exclusively occupied by permanent residents. We cared: And the priority given in the Governor-General's Speech to greatly increased assistance to housing is, for those people I represent, the most welcome and practical indication of our determination to do something about this situation, and to do it quickly.

We cared about the situation of women, and about issues such as the availability of decent child care, accessible to all, which bear disproportionately on working women. Many of my constituents-people, for example , who depend on two incomes to pay off the first home that they are buying-are unduly disadvantaged because of the lack of accessible child care facilities, coupled with the fact that many have to travel so far to work. For the many supporting mothers in the area which I represent, accessible child care is an absolute necessity if they are to have any kind of reasonable existence.

We cared about the situation of pensioners. Those receiving the age pensions have seen the value of their pensions decline from some 25 per cent of average weekly earnings when the Whitlam Government left office to a little over 22 per cent now. We cared also for the situation of many other groups of Australians who are wholly dependent on social security. We cared about education and about the situation of young people driven to drop out of formal education to take some dead end job because they see their colleagues with a better education nevertheless leaving school to go on the dole.

We cared about the situation of small business. We in the Australian Labor Party know that it is the small businessman-the service station owner, the pharmacist, the furniture maker and a hundred others-whose enterprise provides the bulk of employment in this country. But small business has suffered tremendous difficulties over recent years from policies which at times almost seemed designed to drive them to the wall.

We cared about the situation of rural producers also. In my area there is an important wine industry, made up mainly of small independent grape growers and wine makers, who are battling past governmental neglect. They were fearful, with good reason, that the previous Government would further disadvantage them by imposing an excise on wine. Our Government has undertaken not to impose such an excise.

We cared too about issues which went beyond the Kingston electorate. I think particularly of the proposal to dam the Franklin River and of conservation issues generally. People in my electorate know, from direct experience of the many historic sites and unspoiled areas within Kingston-nearly 20 such areas are listed on the Register of the National Estate-that we have an environment and a national heritage which needs to be preserved, if there is to be anything left for our children and their children to wonder at in this beautiful country which belongs to us all. It is no wonder that the vigorous campaign pursued by the Tasmanian Wilderness Society in Kingston struck such a responsive chord.

Above all, we cared that people-young people, mature people-were unemployed through no fault of their own. That was the key difference between ourselves and the Fraser Government, which was responsible for bringing about levels of unemployment unprecedented for 50 years. Not only did the Fraser Government not care, but those levels of unemployment were brought about quite deliberately through the pursuit of policies which were the economic equivalent of the flat earth theory. In this most vital area we not only cared, but also offered a comprehensive and constructive plan to get the country back to work again. I am particularly pleased that we will not be waiting for the August Budget to start tackling this most urgent of the tasks before us.

But policies as such are not, I believe, the whole story of why Australians gave their confidence to the new Government on 5 March. Behind those policies and underpinning them was a deeper consciousness by people that only the Labor Party seemed equipped, seemed competent and willing to take on the active role they expect the Federal Government to play in tackling the problems of society and the economy. I believe it is fair to say that over the past several years the previous Government spent much of its effort in trying to persuade Australians generally that nothing was its responsibility, nothing was its fault . It claimed that the state of the economy was not its fault; the housing situation was not its fault; the level of interest rates was not its fault; and that the chaos into which the health scheme had fallen was not its fault. In fact, it was ready to blame everybody else but itself, and to wash its hands of the mess it had made.

The Labor Party does have a different philosophy. It is not a matter, and it never was, of pursuing some doctrinaire ideology, regardless of reality. Rather, it amounts to an acceptance that the Federal Government has a duty to play an active role, in co-operation with the private sector, with other levels of government and with individuals and groups, to ensure an acceptable standard of life to all Australians, whatever their circumstances. What that Federal role will be at any given moment differs with the times. John Curtin, for example, took over during the dark days of war from a conservative administration in paralysis. The great task his Government accomplished was to mobilise the unprecedented national effort required to bring Australia through those critical times.

Ben Chifley's task, by contrast, was to win the peace. His administration was responsible for the great era of post-war reconstruction in this country, the nation building represented by the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme, the establishment of major manufacturing industry in Australia, the introduction of a visionary scheme of mass migration from countries shattered by war, the foundation of a comprehensive social security system, and the acknowledgment, for the first time, of the duty of Federal governments to maintain employment in Australia.

But Chifley left office in 1949 when most Australians now living here either had not been born or had not yet arrived. For a contemporary exemplar of Labor philosophy in action at the Federal level one has to look to the governments of Gough Whitlam. I welcome the chance to do so.

It is my belief that no governments in the history of Australia have suffered so much unjustified vilification as those Mr Whitlam led. In speaking of those years, I do not want to be taken as saying that from 1972 to 1975 no mistakes were made; of course mistakes were made. But criticism of those mistakes has been so unbalanced as to obscure the many positive achievements of those years which changed Australia and the lives of Australians for the better-achievements which have largely endured.

For the first time in Australia, we had a decent and comprehensive health system, even though it has been vandalised since. For the first time, between 1972 and 1975, genuine attention was given to the situation of women. Equal pay for women was introduced. Women's refuges were established and the supporting mother's benefit was introduced. For the first time a voice was given to other community groups which were previously powerless or neglected. Particularly through the Australian Assistance Plan, small local groups were encouraged to approach the Federal Government for assistance for small scale, locally initiated projects of benefit to the community. For the first time, the Federal Government became directly involved in upgrading the standards and facilities of all our schools. It allocated increased funds through the Schools Commission set up for that purpose, on the basis of need.

For the first time, child care took its place on the agenda of governments and an Office of Child Care was established. For the first time, local government was given substantial and direct funding by the Federal Government. That led, in turn, to a great expansion of the role and relevance of local councils which had been previously confined to worrying about the garbage and the gutters. Now councils in my area such as those of Noarlunga, Marion, Brighton, Willunga, and Meadows are engaged in providing a much more comprehensive range of services which meet genuine community needs.

For the first time, during the Whitlam years, issues relating to the quality of life were taken seriously by the Government. The Department of the Environment was established and environmental impact legislation was passed. The Australian Heritage Commission was set up; so was a department dealing with urban and regional development; so was the Australia Council, to encourage development of the arts. For the first time comprehensive attention was paid to law reform: The Law Reform Commission was established which, under its tireless Chairman, Mr Justice Kirby, has carried out valuable work on the many references subsequently sent to it. There were major reforms in administrative law, particularly the setting up of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the introduction of legislation for an Ombudsman, to deal with a situation in which bureaucrats and bureaucracies seemed to be taking increasing power over the lives of individual citizens without being answerable through any court of law.

Finally, in an important area in which many Australians take particular pride, Australia in those years for the first time acquired a foreign policy which was genuinely independent and which genuinely reflected, in our stance towards other countries, the decency and fair dealing on which we pride ourselves as Australians. Within days the Whitlam Government ended the absurdity of 23 years by recognising China, which is now a major market for our exports. In the first week it ended Australia's involvement in the futile and tragically misconceived war in Vietnam, in which so many Australians died, and after which so many of those who survived were callously neglected by the very Government which sent them there. That practice of militarism was replaced by the active pursuit of peace and disarmament objectives, including importantly the proposed Indian Ocean zone of peace. Atmospheric nuclear tests in the Pacific were stopped after Australia took France to the World Court. Papua New Guinea was brought to independence in orderly fashion without bloodshed. Constructive relations with Third World countries were enhanced, particularly in our own region. And nowhere was the Australian philosophy of a fair go for all better expressed than in the firm opposition immediately undertaken towards the abhorrent policy of apartheid practised by South Africa. That particular foreign policy stance, too, was matched by a new attitude and practice towards Aboriginals in Australia.

Altogether, this record of the Whitlam Government, as I can affirm from my experience as a diplomat serving overseas, brought Australia a degree of genuine respect abroad which was quite unprecedented. It is a formidable catalogue of achievement which, as I have said, has largely endured, despite its being made the object of denigration and destruction by a subsequent Prime Minister with no such record of achievement of his own. By happy contrast those who now lead the Liberal Party have already displayed signs of a more fairminded attitude; not least in their graceful response in respect of Mr Whitlam personally on the occasion of his appointment as Ambassador to the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation. I hope and believe that this new attitude on the part of the Opposition is a step on the road back to decency in public life and towards constructive co-operation for the good of all Australians.

It is to this theme of co-operation that I address my concluding remarks. Nothing has struck me so much in recent years as the extent to which social divisions in Australia have been deliberately fostered: Groups of Australians set one against another, and a philosophy developed of open slather for the rich and powerful and the devil take the hindmost. Of course one cannot blame one man for this deterioration. But the fact remains that to a considerable extent ordinary Australians take their lead from the behaviour of politicians, and especially from the behaviour of the Prime Minister of the day.

I believe that by the time the last election came around Australians were absolutely fed up with this confrontational and divisive approach. They were sick to death of the back stabbing, the distortions and the spoiling for a fight , which seemed the only way the former Prime Minister knew to conduct the Government of this country. Indeed his behaviour reflected one view of the kind of country this is, the kind of people we are, which many people found profoundly depressing and distasteful. It is a view which sees Australia as a land in which the most powerful are free to plunder our resources for their private benefit, and sees Australians as a people incapable of vision, fit only to be exploited, lied to and treated with contempt. This view has a long pedigree and since Eureka it has prevailed more often than not amongst those who have governed us.

But there is a different vision of Australia, of the kind of people Australians are, which equally has been part of our history from the earliest days. It is a vision of a country which, starting out afresh, would not perpetuate the class divisions, the distinctions based on wealth and power and the stink of privilege of the old world. This new country would instead dedicate itself to a new degree of equality among people, would put its trust in the capacity of Australians to work together in a common cause, for the good of the whole country and all the people in it. The member who represented Kingston for longest in this House, the late Pat Galvin, caught some of this spirit when in his maiden speech in 1951 he concluded:

The time has come when instead of blaming the other fellow we all should take our share of responsibility . . . Let us all show more tolerance to the other fellow's point of view.
