That goes for honourable members on both sides of the House. I am certain that the people of today are awaiting good strong leadership , even if that leadership makes mistakes. They will not tolerate the Government or any other authority shirking its responsibility and seeking to establish an alibi by always blaming somebody else.

But perhaps Henry Lawson said it better and certainly earlier. His poem For'ard was written during a sea voyage from New Zealand when he observed the different conditions under which the common people lived crammed into the for'ard part of the vessel, compared with the luxurious cabins of the plutocracy aft. The poem concludes with these lines:
And we will meet amidships on this stout old earthly craft,
And there won't be any friction twixt the classes fore'n aft.
We'll be brothers, fore'n aft,
Yes, and sisters, fore'n aft,
When the people work together, and there ain't no fore'n aft.

In the end I believe that is the fundamental choice that Australians made on 5 March, between confrontation and the accentuation of conflict in Australia on the one hand, and on the other the vision of Henry Lawson, of the Australian people brought together to work for the good of us all. I pledge that my time in this Parliament will be spent in attempting to bring that vision to reality, for every Australian I have the honour to represent in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia today has a choice. That choice is between revitalised and expanded growth, bringing with it sustained economic recovery, or economic mediocrity. It may be that recovery in the international economy will have beneficial consequences for our economy through increased demand and better prices for our rural and resource exports. But the question which remains is whether an overseas induced recovery will overcome the disastrous unemployment situation in this country and whether such recovery will in fact lead to sustained growth in our secondary and tertiary industries. Certainly recovery in the international economy is likely to result in a lift in our export sales and prices which will flow on to other industries. But will we see a resultant growth in the gross domestic product such as we saw through the 1950s and 1960s?

SPEECH.PARA: Many people are now starting to realise that whilst we are a lucky country in relation to our rural and resource industries, we have fallen behind in many of our secondary and manufacturing industries. This is a matter of concern because these industries have historically been large employers in Australia. However, a significant change has occurred over the last decade or so. The net increase in employment has not been in these industries but in the service industries. In fact there has been a net decline in employment in the manufacturing industry. If this decline continues, where will the new jobs for the mass of unemployed be created? Will there be a resurgence in the manufacturing sector or has a permanent change taken place in our economy? Is the pool of unemployed more likely to be absorbed mainly into service industries? I suggest not. I suggest that our best hope for full employment lies in a different approach.

In the past the engines of growth in Australia have been firmly based in the initiative, ingenuity, incentive and entrepreneurial skills of the individual. I believe that the next resurgence of real economic growth will come from the same source. Some industrialists, when times are tough, come to the Government and say: 'We are in trouble. Either bail us out or tell us what we should be doing'. As has been said on numerous occasions, governments are incredibly bad at forecasting the future. Unfortunately, they invariably seem to get it wrong. As my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) made clear in his excellent maiden speech, the Government is only made up of individuals. If people in government knew better than those in the market-place which industries were going to be the boom industries of tomorrow, I would be very surprised if those same people would not soon be out in the market taking advantage of their wisdom rather than telling others how to make money.

Whilst government can help industry to a limited extent, through the provision of information, infrastructure, research and the like, if one accepts that governments have a poor record in the market, it must be the individuals in the market who are most likely to provide the engines of growth. It is they who are going to produce, market and use technological innovation. It may be that new industries will be established or old industries revitalised. There is no doubt that a technological revolution is taking place. Similarly, there is no doubt that it is the entrepreneur in the market place who is going to produce, use and market these technological innovations. This, to me, seems to be the path which offers the greatest hope for the resurgence in growth in our economy and a resurgence in growth of employment. The question then becomes: How can the Government help those in the market who are likely to create jobs?

The first priority must be to get the economic fundamentals right. We must get inflation down, interest rates down, money supply under control and profits up; and, of course, one of the most significant factors in achieving those goals in the current situation is wage restraint. However, there are other factors such as taxation, regulation and intervention which inhibit the entrepreneur. I am not one who supports the laissez-faire or total free market economy. The government does have a role in ensuring that those in the market operate under known and fair rules. The rights of the individual must be protected, for example, from the monopolistic powers of government, big business and big unions . Unfair trading practices, predatory pricing, and the like do not encourage the entrepreneur but rather inhibit competition. Whilst accepting the need for some government regulation, I am one who firmly believes in minimising rather than maximising such regulation which can act as a restriction on the entrepreneur.

Clearly, it is a fine balance between appropriate government intervention and strangling government bureaucratic regulation. There is little argument, except perhaps from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, that the market is the most efficient means of allocating resources to meet popular demand. I set aside the obvious needs for governments to meet other demands, such as defence, education, social welfare and the like. Opponents of the market as a means of allocating resources often point to market failures as evidence of the need for intense government intervention, but I suggest that failures in the exercise of government authority are much more rampant and, indeed, more damaging than any market failures.

This is one of the basic differences between the Opposition and the Government, because there is a thread which runs through the Government's policy and that is the belief that government knows better than those in the productive sectors of the economy what is good for them. It is a fundamental flaw which prevents this Government from solving the problems of the economy, because it cannot adhere to its philosophy and, at the same time, create the environment whereby those with the will, skill and ability will be stimulated to initiate innovative business enterprises, thereby creating the new jobs which are required to absorb our pool of unemployed.

This fact was clearly recognised by the scenarios which were put to the National Economic Summit Conference. None of them offered a satisfactory solution to unemployment but, rather, they were comparisons of policies which would result in different but unacceptable levels of unemployment. In the short term there clearly are not any quick-fix solutions; nor were they offered. But the fact remains that the Government is not offering employment. It is merely indicating a holding operation on unemployment at around current levels.

I thought that the Summit, in bringing together Government leaders, union leaders and business leaders and making them listen to one another, was a worthwhile undertaking. Obviously, everyone cannot be represented at such a conference. However, unless one acknowledges that, then we may get the wrong idea of the result of the Conference. Essentially, the Conference was a meeting of institutional leaders. The point has been made several times that many sections of the community were not present and were not heard, such as the unemployed, the consumers, the non-union labour force and so on. But there is another very important group, the innovators-the people out in the market who are, or are attempting, to get a new business undertaking or a revitalised business undertaking off the ground. Some of these enterprises will be the big businesses of the next decade, the new miners, manufacturers and engineers; maybe the new BHP, CSR, News Limited, Coles, Boral, Faulding, James Hardie, TNT, Ansett, Wormald-any large company one cares to mention.

The Government certainly obtained an acceptance of the inevitable; that is, the Economic Summit acknowledged that the Government would press on with its policies of price control and centralised wage fixing. These two areas are good examples of the concern I am expressing about the philosophy of Labor's policy. One of the consequences of price control will inevitably be to reduce and redirect capital out of profitable areas of investment. That action will be a great disincentive to those contemplating a new enterprise.

In relation to centralised wage fixing, let me say at the outset that there is no doubt that union action in demanding and obtaining wage increases beyond the capacity of this economy to pay has directly resulted in high inflation, higher unemployment, lower profits and lower investment. I also believe that it was a significant factor in bringing down the previous Government. The answer of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to that is to say: 'The previous arrangement allowed powerful unions to use their industrial muscle to obtain unreasonable wage increases. These increases flowed through to other industries and thereby brought the economy to its knees.' The answer, the Prime Minister says, is to have centralised wage fixing. But the problem with that is that by giving across -the-board wage increases one does not distinguish between those industries which can afford to pay wage increases and those which cannot. Those which cannot afford it will clearly shed more labour or go broke. Either way, there will be more unemployment.

In my view, such centralised wage fixing which institutionalises unemployment must be wrong, and the answer, of course, lies somewhere between the two poles. We just cannot afford to have the entrepreneur sacrificed by government, big business and the monopolistic unions. I willingly concede that to the extent to which the Summit produced an acceptance of the continuation of the wage pause, it was helpful. However, the measure of the success of the Summit lies not in rhetoric about consensus but in the actual wage increases which are achieved this year either through the arbitration system or outside it. I must admit that , on the basis of that test, the signs for our economy are ominous. Given the outburst from the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Dolan, they are ominous for two reasons. The first is this: If the wage pause were continued to about October this year, then I believe the economy could withstand a wage increase of 3 per cent to 4 per cent, representing the June and September consumer price index increases with no allowance for catch-ups. That is, of course, with some sensible arrangement for future wage increases in line with the October determination. However, Mr Dolan has indicated already that he wants the March 2.2 per cent increase as well as future CPI increases, as well as catch-up at some time in the future. What is worse, he said that unions want it both ways. If they do not get what they want in the arbitration system, they will go outside it to obtain their objectives. That will be the time when this Government will be able to prove to the Australian public the special relationship which it suggests exists between the Australian Labor Party and the union bosses, because large scale avoidance of the arbitration system will clearly not be able to be sustained by this economy.

The second reason for concern is the effect that such uncertainty regarding the future levels of wages has on confidence in the private sector. It is well known that there is a large amount of money currently invested in short term deposits, cash management funds and the like, because investors and entrepreneurs are uncertain as to the direction in which the economy is heading. One of the most important factors in investment decisions is projected wage costs and right now there is enormous uncertainty. Investment expenditure cannot be turned on like a tap. It will be produced only where there is a favourable economic climate, when there is confidence and when there is certainty as to future Government decisions. Unfortunately, to date this Government has shown itself to be a bad and incapable manager of government business, let alone the economy, and its performance has not instilled confidence in the market.

I conclude by referring again to my initial point. We need to encourage the companies and individuals in our society who are prepared to have a go, to innovate, to experiment, to upgrade. The opportunity must be given to the entrepreneurs of our society to come up with the new industries which will create jobs. Those opportunities will most likely be taken when the economic climate is conducive to investment, when government is encouraging rather than discouraging, and when government interference in the market-place is minimised. Finally, I quote from the book Liberal Thinking by former Senator Puplick and Sir Robert Southey.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be good.
—It will be good. The honourable member is quite right. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: Equality is not to be confused with conformity or uniformity. This confusion is very common in political debate. Conformity or uniformity can only be brought about in a complex society by oppression, by discrimination against those with talent, by treating people unequally to ensure that they fit into a common mould . The confusion of equality with conformity or uniformity runs through socialist thought. For that reason socialist states are based on discrimination and always tend towards oppression. The basic distinction is between liberalism's insistence on equality of entitlements to freedom and to civil and political rights, and socialism's enforced uniformity which inevitably reduces individual expression.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Eden- Monaro (Mr Snow) I would remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and ask that he be afforded every courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. May I congratulate you and your colleagues on your appointments as Deputy Speakers. I congratulate also the Chairman of Committees and Mr Speaker on their election. Twenty-five years ago I used to dispense Mr Speaker's medical prescriptions. I trust I will be able to observe his instructions in this House with the same devotion, but perhaps not the same accuracy. Walking into the House of Representatives on 21 April, I brought with me some mental reservations about the ability of any government to act on the vital questions of peace, of poverty and of efficient government. Those reservations have been weakened. The will of the Hawke Ministry to wade systematically through the economic slough for a few months, with the clear aim of acting on the issues of poverty, efficient government and peace, is so evident that I know I am in a House of Representatives which is prepared to plan and prepared to have a go. My reservations still have some basis. Legislators have got the troublesome job of sorting out what can be done, when so much needs to be done. The legislators have also to sort out which truth takes precedence over another.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to dwell on another aspect of this conflict between the obvious needs- the truth about our circumstances-and the old adage that politics is the art of the possible. Andrea Dvorkin said, in her book, Our Blood, that there is a difference between truth and what she called reality. Before Columbus, the reality was that the earth was flat. The truth was that the earth was round. Reality is often shaped out of ignorance but is nonetheless real at the time. The reality today is that we have up to four levels of government in Australia, which are there and which are difficult to change. In fact, when the Australian Labor Party is prepared to dissolve its State branches, I will believe that it is possible for Australia to exist with just local and national government.

The truth is that we are over-governed, that State governments are an anachronism and ought to go, in favour of a reformed local government. That does not mean that all State boundaries are unsuitable. Decades of government in Tasmania, on average, show that Government to be a pretty efficient local government. It is just that there are many powers which Tasmania does not have and ought to have. There are other powers which Tasmania has which are not appropriate to local government and the one perceptive thing that Milton Friedman said when he was in Australia was that we were wrong to put up with State governments. The Northern Territory Government is the sort of structure that we can put up with. So is the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, if it is given true local powers. The system would suit north Queensland and the rest of Australia. But for now we have to live with the reality. We have the States and, unlike Arthur Calwell, we must not stir the possum. Another truth was expressed by Dwight D. Eisenhower when he retired from the Presidency of the United States and fired a parting shot at the military juggernaut which had sent its tentacles into the Eisenhower Administration. He said:
Every gun that is made, every warship launched, every rocket fired, signifies in a final sense, a theft from those who hunger and are not fed, from those who are cold and not clothed.

That is the truth. The reality is that no country is prepared to go without and leave others in a position of military strength. It was on this conflict between truth and reality, the conflict about nuclear disarmament, that the preacher at the service held at the opening of this Parliament said, as I recall, that where the truth seems difficult, and even impossible, politicians ought not thereby dismiss it but always store it in the mind as a basis for action. He was talking about disarmament and there are few issues which require this continued perception of the truth more than nuclear disarmament.

No strategy is more important to the resolving of the problem of poverty than the acceptance of the truth about that issue. The failure to cope with the poverty created by the monetarist philosophy-a failure to cope with that weakest to the wall philosophy-would be a denial of social justice. The bypassing of social justice to the poor in the name of economic efficiency is now starting to create unstable forces in the community and, not surprisingly, is threatening economic efficiency. The bypassing of social justice is a denial of the heritage of the Australian Labor Party. Those nineteenth century moves in Australia by an unusual combination of humanists, protestants, atheists and catholics which is still holding together to this day and the pioneering of world democratic socialism here in Australia were dedicated to the elimination of poverty. The emotional claptrap which just voices sorrow for the poor or which, on the other side, voices contempt for those who do not pull themselves up by their bootstraps, will get the country nowhere. One does not have to cry crocodile tears or snarl to realise that poverty is a looming threat to the stability of our nation. Cry by all means if it moves one to action.

Eden-Monaro's statistics, not far from the average of all of Australia's electorates, brand the electorate as a microcosm of the whole nation, like most marginal seats. There are few areas which more reflect poverty than that of accommodation. Women's refuges and other voluntary agencies in Eden-Monaro will tell one that. In Queanbeyan, a place of residence for quite a few honourable members of this House during parliamentary sittings, government and voluntary agencies and refuges are trying to cope with the problems of unemployment, including family breakdown and the resulting crises in health, food supply and accommodation. In Goulburn young people on $40 a week unemployment relief are confronted with rents of $30 to $50 a week. The knockers say they all live in group housing. Only a minority of those living away from home live in group housing.

Then there are the new poor, the people who are not able to come up with the money to pay mortgages and people who are forced out of the homes for which they have skimped and saved. The stimulus now to come from the Hawke Government's new housing policy will help these people. Also, the Hurford-Hawke housing policy propagated and nurtured by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) will also revitalise jobs in the construction and associated industries. The policy will give soundness to the timber industry. Only six months ago timber mills along the south coast of New South Wales, on the tablelands and on the Monaro were reducing hours or retrenching staff. This added to the unemployment crisis. Economic crises in local industries and a rising number of bankruptcies in small businesses dealing in timber, fishing, manufacturing and the retail trade added to unemployment and, therefore, added to poverty.

To help primary industries such as fishing, Labor's traditional tack towards orderly marketing should continue. The great successes of Labor Governments since Federation have included primary industry. Ministers such as Reg Pollard, Ken Wreidt and now the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), guided by responsive local members such as my predecessors, Alan Fraser, Bob Whan, and in part of my electorate, Ben Chifley, never dilly-dallied through fear of backbiting from a limited number of corporate bodies or large landholders. They led Australia and even the world in their steady promotion of orderly marketing. Marketing, research and promotion will do more for our primary industries than all the subsidies in the world. But we must continually check the marketing systems so that they work for the national economy.

Eden-Monaro is a microcosm of Australia's march backwards in the past few years . Our primary industries, whether fishing, dairying, potatoes, sheep, cattle, deer, horses, honey or goats-I will not mention those in other electorates-among many others will join with the great tourist industry, light industries, small businesses and public works on roads and water supplies to become a microcosm of Australia's recovery. That recovery will not be based on only the economy and local infrastructures; social programs must also play a role. A carefully planned and well researched Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits policy will stop the disastrous, inconsiderate and costly policy changes which have occurred over eight years.

The secret of the Hawke Government's future success is that, for the first time since 1946, the ALP has a broad spectrum of support across Australia. Small businesses and primary producers have united with pensioners, the retired, the unemployed, and pay-as-you-earn taxpayers to vote in a democratic socialist government. Democratic socialism was pioneered in Australia but has never had a fair go in this country. Countries which have democratically practised this very successful form of government for many more years than we have-countries such as Austria, Sweden, Holland, Denmark, Finland and, until recently, West Germany- have a far better economic and social record than we have. It all started here in Australia. Those democratic socialist countries also have a far better employment record.

The Hawke Labor Government has started to build on the broad support given by the electorate and the broad backing given at the National Economic Summit Conference. I look forward to changes which will reduce the mounting disillusionment and lack of operative confidence in youth and will return breadwinners to work. I look forward to new confidence in the public and private sectors. We on the Government benches are well aware that economic, social- including health-and environmental issues have been at the forefront of every election since 1966. All the people in the Eden-Monaro campaign contributed substantially to a win by the ALP on those issues. This Government's success will be linked with its policies on the economy and on the social and environmental conditions of Australia. Eden-Monaro has a say in the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by congratulating you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your appointment and offer my best wishes to those honourable members of the House who have joined us here for the first time. I add that since most of the new honourable members come from the Government ranks, while I wish them a pleasant stay, I do not wish them a long stay.
—We are here for a long time.

—The honourable member says they are here for a long time. On the Government's progress thus far, it will go out of office at a quicker rate than any other government since Federation. I want to say something about the style and substance of this Government and also about its wages policy. I want to say something about the style because the style of a government reflects the substance. With this Government one must begin with the National Economic Summit Conference because that was the centrepiece for the Hawke Government. We know who participated at that Summit. I add that in many ways I think it was a sensible exercise because it provided a means for people to get together to debate issues and to be, one hopes, better informed. The participants at the Summit included, of course, Mr Dolan, although judging by his recent pronouncements, one can only say that he has forgotten everything that took place there. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, set the tone of the Summit when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The results we seek-and these must be regarded as only a minimum measure of our success-should be:
First, a heightened appreciation of the need to work constructively together to meet the great challenges now confronting our country; and

Second, an increased likelihood of all participants tailoring their expectations and claims upon the community's resources to the capacities of the economy, and the urgent need for a reduction in unemployment and a restoration of growth to an economy now in deep recession.

If those were the minimum measures of success, all the evidence is that the Summit has been a failure. Since the Summit and the high expectations that it engendered amongst many Australians, we have seen a catalogue of disasters in the way in which this Government has handled its business. One can commence with Tasmania and the strange means adopted by the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) and the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to gain evidence. It passes understanding how two senior Ministers could think that using military aircraft was an appropriate way to gain evidence in a civil case. It was neither appropriate nor proper.

What did we have next? Of course, we had the Combe affair. We all know what the version of the Prime Minister is of his handling of the Combe affair. He has told us that he has been moved by two considerations-the national interest and fairness. We all know the sequence of events and Mr Combe's version of what happened. What do we know? We know that the Prime Minister and the inner group which comprise the Cabinet Sub-Committee on National and International Security made a decision which effectively caused the greatest possible harm to Mr Combe and to his capacity to earn a living. That was done without bothering even to give him the opportunity of a hearing. Mr Combe was an old and valued colleague and, one would think, an old and valued friend of the Prime Minister and of those Ministers who were concerned in the making of the opinion that destroyed his livelihood. Yet he was not consulted. He was not asked to give his story until of course it all became public, when it was too late. It is perfectly plain from that that the Prime Minister regards friends and associates as expendable and that he belongs to the 'hang now and give them a fair trial later ' school of justice.

One of the astonishing things about the Combe affair was that, while Mr Combe had, I suppose, many friends and colleagues on the Labor side of the House, not one stood up to support him. When last year we had some difficulties and there was a disagreement as to what should be done, some of our members went public against the Government's decision because they thought that decision was unfair. Do we find that coming from the Labor ranks? We do not, because the truth is that they believe that justice is something that one has to alter according to the expediencies of the situation.

What happened after that? Within three weeks of the making of the decision to expel Mr Ivanov, the Prime Minister commissioned a royal commission, part of the terms of reference of which are into the Government's decision on that matter. It surely must be a record for any government in Australia or elsewhere that, within three weeks of making a decision of national importance-the Government is to inquire into its decision and has appointed a judge for that purpose.

After that we had the bizarre Kampuchean affair, with the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), formerly the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, speaking about Australian and Japanese troops going into Kampuchea. Then, of course, in the Parliament we have had the litany of promises thus far broken by the Labor Government. We will hear some more this evening.

We will be able to know the Labor Government by two epitaphs. The first will be the streaker's defence: 'It seemed like a good thing at the time'; and the second will be that dictum of Lenin's: 'Promises are like pie crusts-made to be broken'. Therefore, the conclusions one draws about the style of this Government is that it has thus far shown itself to be dangerously inept, and to have a selective view of justice to its closest associates. God help those who are not closely associated with this Government. That of course reflects the group ethic of the Labor Party, which believes that because a blueprint may have been laid down for the Government of the country, everyone should accord with that blueprint and if a few people get hurt in the process that is neither here nor there.

I turn now to the Government's wages policy. It has been stated by the Prime Minister to involve, first of all, a return to the centralised system. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) referred to some of the defects of that system, with the flow-on of decisions made in one industry to other industries which are less able to pay. Secondly, the Prime Minister said that in 1983 there will be a small increase in wages, which he has put at about 3 per cent to 4 per cent. Thirdly, he said that we will have a return to indexation, although he has been ambiguous as to when that return will be. He and the whole Government have either been ambiguous about, or simply do not know, whether there will be a catch-up in the end, although it appears from what one can understand from their answers that there will be and that it will be a part of Labor Party policy.

In my view, it is a fundamental proposition that the benefits of the wages pause will be lost unless there is a permanent reduction in the share of the national cake taken by wage and salary earners and a restoration of their share accorded to the profit makers. Some of the speakers at the Summit Conference made this fairly plain. For example, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, speaking on the subject of profitability of organisations, said:
By the end of 1982, all profitability measures were at historically low levels.
He said later, at page 26 of the record of proceedings, in reference to Labor's prices and incomes policy:
. . . it is clear that at one level the prices and incomes accord is firmly in place. An explicit agreement has been reached with the trade union movement.

So we have these two factors. The Treasurer, Mr Keating has said that profitability is at historically low levels, which it most certainly is, and that this explicit agreement is in place. Sir Roderick Carnegie, on the subject of profitability, said:

Today our companies are weak. They are earning low profits. Their debt position is high. Their competitiveness in world terms is poor. All too often they rush to the Government seeking to be bailed out when the going gets tough. The link between adequate profits and secure jobs is not well understood. The responsibility facing the leaders of companies and unions is to educate their members as to the reality of where their long term interests lie.
Another speaker at the National Summit, Sir Arvi Parbo, in commenting upon what Sir Roderick Carnegie had said, stated:

I believe it has been well established that the major cause of the low level of economic activity, and therefore the lack of employment opportunities, is the inadequate financial returns to enterprises. Sir Roderick Carnegie made a most important point on Monday, which I think was largely missed by the audience, namely, that the financial returns to enterprises are essential to service the money invested, just as all of us expect to be paid interest on our money deposited in the bank.

One might say there is general agreement between the Treasurer, Sir Roderick, Sir Arvi Parbo and others on the need for profitability. What then is the present position? Let us consider the accord and what has happened since the National Summit. Honourable members will recall that the accord, that is, the accord between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labor Party, very specifically provides:
The maintenance of real wages is agreed to be a key objective. It is recognised that in a period of economic crisis as now applying that this will be an objective over time.

From what one can understand it is certainly a key objective of the ACTU, but it seems to have forgotten that the accord stated the maintenance of real wages would be an objective over time. What did Mr Dolan say on the subject? As we all know and as the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 May reported he claimed, on behalf of the ACTU, a 2.2 per cent cost of living wage increase to cover the first quarter of this year, followed by similar full quarterly increases for the remainder of the year. In the same issue, in reference to a figure of 3 per cent to 4 per cent which was put to him, he was reported as saying:
This is a figure in the minds of some persons in the media.

According to the newspaper he said the Federal Government had never told the ACTU that it wanted pay rises for this year limited to 3 per cent to 4 per cent. That is the figure which the Prime Minister has put to this House on more than one occasion. He is perfectly clear about it. One can assume only that he and Mr Dolan are living on different planets because they are saying two different things. It is impossible to reconcile the views of the ACTU as expressed by Mr Dolan with the Prime Minister's often reiterated reliance upon a rise of 3 per cent to 4 per cent this year. Mr Dolan has made his position perfectly plain. It will not accord in any way with the policy that has been put forward by this Government.

In later interviews Mr Dolan has made his personal position and the position of the ACTU perfectly plain. He has been asked about his attitude if the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission does not agree to the claim for a 2.2 per cent award to cover the March quarter. On the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio program AM on 18 May the following question was put to him:
If the Commission then knocks back such a claim, will you accept it?
The answer was:
Well, they will put themselves out of business as far as I see it. There will be just no role for the Arbitration Commission because unions will seek to achieve that increase.

Mr Dolan has sought to say that that really did not amount to a confrontation, but that is very clearly his position. What does that mean? It means that we are returning to the days that existed towards the end of indexation when the tribunal was used for the purpose of getting rises within the indexation principles. When the powerful unions go outside the tribunal to get their own results-according to what Mr Dolan has said-it will be a case of: 'Well, fellows , it is business as usual because if the Commission does not give it to us that is the end of the Commission and we will get it anyway'. Where does that leave reconciliation, consensus and the Prime Minister's wages policy?

In the last one or two minutes let me sum up my views as to the Government's wages policy. The Government inherited a wages pause which has been the linchpin of the policy of this Government. The Prime Minister has said constantly that it is a policy of returning to a centralised system of wage fixation. Mr Dolan has made it quite plain that he will not accept that policy if it does not suit him or the ACTU. So much for the sanctity of the centralised system! The Prime Minister has said that there is an agreement, a consensus, between the ACTU and the Government. Mr Dolan has made it perfectly plain that he thinks there is no such consensus and that some media person-perhaps he had the Prime Minister in mind-brought up a wage rise of 3 per cent to 4 per cent in 1983. It would seem that the hopes of keeping wage restraint in place are not good. They can be made good only if this Government has the courage to ensure that they are made good; if it is willing to state a plain position from this point right through 1983, and if it is willing to involve itself in whatever difficulties may occur with the union movement.

Looking to the future, if we do not have restraint we will be living beyond our means. If we live beyond our means we will continue to lose jobs and become less competitive with all the misery that that entails. There will be further devaluation and this country could find itself in a downward spiral from which it would be very hard to recover. If, however, we take a more positive approach to the future we should remember just one thing: Profits are the motor for the recovery of this country. Until the Labor Party learns and takes on board that lesson the future of the Australian economy will remain in danger.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before calling the honourable member for Barton I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask that he be heard in silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I offer my congratulations to you. I trust that you will pass on my congratulations to the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) on his election to the post of Speaker. It is most appropriate that I should make my maiden speech after such a prelude from the honourable members for Hume (Mr Lusher), Barker (Mr Porter) and North Sydney (Mr Spender). I say at the outset that with such contributions from the Opposition's front bench it gives great heart to the new members on this side of the House to know that we will be here for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: On 22 November 1940 a predecessor of mine in the seat of Barton rose to make his maiden speech. He said that the people of Barton had honoured him by electing him to the national Parliament at a time of unparalleled emergency. That member was, of course, the great late Dr Evatt. He was speaking at a time not long after the commencement of the hitherto most destructive of wars, that is, World War II. Nearly 43 years later I rise similarly to thank the people of Barton for the faith they have placed in me by allowing me to represent them in the national Parliament at a time of another great emergency; for I arrive here not in the context of a military war, thank God, but at the commencement of what is in a sense another great war; that is, the war against the rapid and thorough improverishment of this great nation-impoverishment which manifests itself not just, albeit not the least, in economic terms but also in moral and political terms.

The economic impoverishment of Australia, now so full of momentum as this Parliament commences, is as obvious to the Australian people as the bankruptcy of policy and humanity of the last Government which now sits opposite and which created this great national emergency. May I say that the only relief of conscience for their deeds that members of the Opposition can look forward to is the axiom that after the Australian public has had an opportunity to compare our programs with theirs there will indeed be less of them here in the next Parliament.

After seven years of monetarist inflation-first economics the rate of inflation now stands at 11.5 per cent. In November 1975 it stood at 11.1 per cent. While history was moving through its cycle to 5 March 1983 the great cost of the national tragedy unfolded.

Today that cost in human misery is measured by two statistical comparisons. The number of official unemployed, itself deflated by the despair of many people resigning all hope of finding work, particularly women and the young, now stands at an official 10.3 per cent. Seven years ago it stood at 4.3 per cent.

In the electorate of Barton there are now 8,954 unemployed persons. The unemployed to job ratio for those under 24 is 13:1. In my electorate approximately 30 per cent of people are non-Australian born. When the first generation Australian-born children of migrants are included the figure is closer to 40 per cent. Unemployment falls particularly hard on these communities . I should point out that 27.1 per cent of Lebanese, 11.7 per cent of Yugoslavs and 10.1 per cent of Greeks were estimated to have been unemployed in my electorate as at November last year when the national average was 7.5 per cent. Now, obviously, it is much worse.

The proponents of the total private enterprise society in their text book assumptions of mobility within the work force from places of low labour demand to places of high labour demand forget the harsh limitations of youth and inexperience or of language and cultural barriers in that market. But the most telling indice of human misery is that three million Australians now live in poverty. The lucky country has faired badly in the Fraserism game of chance. Our standard of living fell from eighth to fifteenth amongst Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations between 1973 and 1980. All of this -all of this-in the name of efficient government and smaller government, which was revealed secretly, hidden from the Australian public only days before the last election, resulting in a record projected Budget deficit of $9.6 billion- the highest in Australian history and one of the highest amongst OECD nations per capita. The Opposition, limited in numbers, policies and compassion, now decries our stated inability as a government to pursue all the elements of our platform enunciated during the election.

On each occasion the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), and his colleagues smirk this irrelevancy I shall remind them of the editorial in the 11 March Australian Financial Review, aptly entitled 'The politics of Austerity', which states:

Any objective examination of the Fraser Government's deficit record can only lead to the conclusion that at no time did Mr Fraser make a serious effort to come to grips with the deteriorating state of the public finances.

Perhaps better still, I shall remind them of the editorial in the Australian of 10 March 1983 under the heading 'Lessons from the Budget Blow-out' which, comments in its second last paragraph on the deficit and on the honourable member for Bennelong, and the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who is increasingly becoming one of the Government's greatest assets, and who will be there at least until the inevitable challenge to the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Peacock). It concludes:
It will take a long time for him (Mr Howard) to live down his ministerial legacy of huge Budget deficits this year and next.
I will keep these editorials in my drawer in the chamber to remind those members opposite from time to time when their memories lapse.

It is the monumental legacy of economic impoverishment which the first Hawke Government must arrest and reverse. It is a battle that will be fought. It is a battle that will be won. Resulting from this economic tragedy is the impoverishment of the broad public morality of this nation. Under the guise of freedom of enterprise and the supposed liberalism of the individual, the basic tenets of the philosophies of the last Government, with their roots in the myths of the Menzies era, have set aside compassion for those less fortunate, the aspirations of the Australian family and, indeed, the basic rights for many Australians.

There is no freedom for the individual when many of the 17,000 pensioners in my electorate are individuals with scarcely enough to eat. There is no freedom for the individual when devastated health care, public education and child care services prohibit many individuals from pursuing their chosen role in society and fulfilling their potential in life. I note that my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) vividly mentioned the death of a young girl in the city's centre from a drug overdose.

I ask: Is there anything morally decent about policies or philosophies of government that have abandoned much of my generation to this, arising from sheer despair; or is there any decency in government when the hopelessness of groups of young, often homeless unemployed persons, forces them to sell their bodies on street corners in order just to eat? It is a nation on the verge of moral collapse, at the very least of moral impoverishment, that cares little for its young, its aged and its handicapped. That is the legacy passed to us. This must change. I am sure that under the Australian Labor Party in government it will change.

Every Australian has an inalienable right to the basic services and commodities of the modern society we have built. Every Australian has a right to a home. Every Australian has a right to health care. Similarly, every Australian has a basic right to an equal opportunity in life, and I say that especially with respect to women. A commitment to a rising standard of education for all is central to this. These tenets of our philosophy are the true reflection of the rights of the individual in terms of both needs and aspirations. They are the values that we must, and will, restore to Australian politics.

The third manifestation of the impoverishment of our great nation is the very great damage done to the political system by the deliberate manipulation and blatant devastation of the conventions and spirit of our democratic processes. There is no need to return to the precipice of 11 November 1975, a thin edge over which the conservative political forces were prepared to dangle this country for what is now seen exclusively as being due to their greed for power. But as I stand here looking over the vast empty wasteland of the Opposition branches, it serves to remind me that the precedent set then has been followed as ruthlessly by those opposite since, both in government and in opposition.

In opposition this has been shown in recent weeks by their shameful activities at the Australian Constitutional Conference, the implicit attempts at deception in their questioning in this House on the economy and their consistently divisive attitude, while we on this side strive to establish a national consensus on the common goals of the Australian people.

In government this warping of the political process was clearly shown in the blatant in-house use of the Government Information Unit by the Liberal Party, the cynical use of taxpayers' money for political advertising and the sustainment of the worst undemocratic features of the electoral system-features which include the insistence of full preferential voting to the disadvantage of ethnic minorities and the elderly, alphabetical listing on ballot papers to allow the deliberate stacking of tickets, as occurred in Barton at the last election, and the blatant gerrrymander of seats which produced a result in 1980 of the Australian Labor Party gaining only 42 per cent of the seats with 50.5 per cent of the vote. It is not surprising, therefore, that it is with a firm ideological commitment that I come to this place to play my part in ending the impoverishment-economic, moral and political-of this nation.

I am under no illusions that the people of Australia have voted for radical change. They have not. Years of myths, distortions and blatant political fabrication from the predecessors of those on the other side of this House have made the Australian electorate an essentially conservative one.

It therefore falls to a social democratic party such as ours to follow the path so successfully trod by our sister parties in western Europe; to change not only the substance of executive and legislative decisions to make our society more just, equitable and democratic, but also to change the political consciousness of the Australian public in order that the great reforms that this Government has a clear mandate to implement, not only materialise, but also have an opportunity to embed themselves in the national body politic to become lasting reforms.

The necessity for this is the measure of how little is left one decade later of the reforms of the Whitlam Government. No social reform, no matter how worth while and with no matter how great a mandate, can be guaranteed survival under the political Luddites of the conservative parties. A commitment by ALP politicians to remain in office is the most effective mode that can be adopted to help this country out of its current economic and social morass and its cyclical repetition.

The harshest measure of this is that much of our platform now, is a redress of what was sought a decade ago, for the most part won, and then lost between 1975 and 1983. Its re-establishment has become a harder task due to our prolonged absence from the Treasury benches.

Our political commitment remains, however, strong enough to stand on its own. Our commitment is the only positive alternative for this nation. While those opposite have an infatuation with the politics of redistribution of income and wealth under a philosophy which dictates a shrinking pool of social resources for Australians, our cause has as its strength an inherent commitment to expanding the potential wealth of our society for the benefit of all Australians , and particularly those most in need.

Our cause is unique because it alone has as its fundamental strength the commitment to the constant revision of our society and a mutual commitment to the democratic processes and a pluralist society. Doubtlessly, this Government will create enemies within the community as it makes the hard decisions for the greater good. But it is well worth remembering the words of the nineteenth century reformist journalist, Donn Piatt, that: 'The man who has no enemies has no following'.

The onus, therefore, is on each member of the Government not only to bring about those needed reforms, but also to guard against the distractions of a system which we seek to clean up; we need to ignore those distractions and pursue our course of action. As a direct derivation of this, it is my hope for the short term that some small amount can be achieved. In the formulation of policy and its administration, in the interests of my electorate of Barton, I intend to be as parochial as the best of them and on occasions, perhaps, unashamedly a little more parochial, just to spite those members of the National Party.

I hope that pay-as-you-earn tax relief and a decline in interest rates will appear in this first term of Government. I expect and, indeed, I will fight for the restoration of a proper level of income for pensioners-not only the aged, but the handicapped, war widows and others who are so much in need of help. I hope also that this term of government will see significant reforms for the benefit of women's rights in the work force and government service.

I hope that this Government will be able to proceed with those policies so suitably programmed for the benefit of the ethnic communities that are also so much in need of a wide range of support. I hope also that this Government can breathe life into the many still factories and small businesses of Sydney to give more jobs to Australians, particularly the young.

Finally, I thank all those who have played a part in giving me this opportunity to pursue these reforms and end the improverishment of my country. My family, particularly my wife, and our many friends and supporters inside and outside the ALP have given me a rare chance to participate in the implementation of many of the things that they have spent their lives believing in. I thank them for that and hope that I will not fail them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I extend my congratulations to all those new members of this Parliament who have made their maiden speeches. We have listened to some very fine speeches indeed. We on this side of the House are greatly concerned with the Government's present water resources program. Prior to 5 March, the Fraser-Anthony Government had allocated $640m for the establishment of water storages in Australia. This included the provision of funds for the building of the Split Rock Dam on the Manilla River and increasing the height of the wall of the Glenbawn Dam on the Hunter River. It was also to provide funds for increasing water storage capacity in various parts of Australia, with great advantage to the nation. Australia is the driest country in the world and preservation of water is an urgent requirement. With the unemployment situation as it is at the present time in this country, surely consideration should be given to building storage dams which will not only provide water for crops, grain and stock, but also have the twofold advantage of providing employment and creating national assets.

SPEECH.PARA: We were very disturbed to hear from the Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) yesterday in another place in answer to a question say that this Government's policy would probably be to provide $350m for water resources. Indeed, we will not know just what the situation is until the mini-Budget comes down tonight. But it does indicate to us that there is a lack of regard by the present Government for water conservation. Water conservation is essential not only for crops and the pastoral industries, but also for town water supplies of inland Australia. The towns in my electorate on the Namoi and Hunter rivers depend entirely on water from those rivers. So it is a very important matter indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the Burdekin Dam.

—My colleague the honourable member for Dawson has asked me to mention the Burdekin Dam in Queensland. We have visited this area and we know just what the dam would mean to the primary industries in Queensland and to the honourable member himself. I want to refer to the promises that were made prior to election day by the present Government. On 10 February 1983 the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said: 'We will not be devaluing'. Three days after the Government was elected, it devalued the Australian dollar by 10 per cent. This resulted in higher prices being paid by all Australian families. On 16 February in the Labor Party's policy speech there was a statement made to the effect that there would be immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australian taxpayers. Three days after the election, the Prime Minister said: ' We will have to consider the whole of our program'. On the Mike Walsh Show, 16 days after the election, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there has to be some delay of the tax cuts, it will not be because Bob Hawke has decided so. It will be because the community, through their representative bodies, essentially agree that it is part of what has to be done.

These promises were made; they have been rejected. If the Government had not made them, it may not be sitting on the Treasury benches here today. In the first two weeks the Labor Government launched a constitutional fight with Tasmania over the new hydro-electric scheme. It called the Economic Summit Conference. It refused to admit representatives from the Liberal and National Parties and the Australian Democrats which represent more than 50 per cent of Australians. We were denied the right to take part in that Conference. We feel that this should not have been the case.

The Government decided not to replace the aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne, without consultation with those most involved; namely, members of the Royal Australian Navy. These are but a few of the promises made during the election campaign-they contributed to the success of the Australian Labor Party at the polls- which the Government is not keeping. The people of Australia will soon find out these facts, to their detriment. The coal industry in my electorate of Paterson plays a very important part in the economy of the Hunter Valley, New South Wales-and, indeed, the nation. New South Wales is now exporting more steaming coal than the more traditional coking coal.

That is a further sign that the coal boom has arrived, but without any of the projected financial benefits. Figures on exports from the Joint Coal Board show that in the first 41 weeks of 1982-83 steaming coal exports exceeded coking coal shipments overseas by a comfortable margin. The figures show that 11.64 million tonnes of steaming coal was exported compared with 10.87 million tonnes of coking coal shipped in the same period. Steaming coal exports actually moved ahead of coking coal exports early in 1982-83 as new mines in the upper Hunter Valley, developed over the past two years, came into production or lifted output as contracted deliveries expanded.

However, one very serious situation has developed in this region. The Drayton coal mine was completed in early 1982 and cost $200m. The union is refusing to staff the mine. The Drayton mine, which is owned by the CSR company, was completed 18 months ago. The northern miners are refusing to man that mine. It has contracts with Korea, Japan and many other parts of the world. People in the Hunter Valley are very concerned and upset about this situation. Indeed, the areas of Muswellbrook, Scone and Singleton are very seriously affected by this mine not being manned. Miners are unemployed but the union will not allow them to work at Drayton.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government will not intervene.

—As the honourable member for Lyne said, the Government will not intervene. Recently in the town of Muswellbrook a public meeting was held and 4, 000 concerned people turned up to protest about the action of the northern miners in not manning this mine. What a ridiculous stand.
—It is no wonder they vote for you.

—That is right. We get a good miners' vote. There are unemployed miners in this valley, yet they are denied the right of employment. If this mine were manned it would be of great benefit not only to the people in the area but also to the mining industry, coal exports and the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the coal contracts to the countries which I have mentioned-Korea, Japan and others-will be lost if the mine is not staffed. Indeed, the latest information to hand is that contracts will expire in six weeks time. Valuable coal exports will be lost. That will be a national loss and will result in a loss of job opportunities for many unemployed miners. Pleas to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) have not brought forth assistance. This is a serious situation. It is beyond comprehension. Surely common sense will prevail and the mine will be allowed to operate.

Shipping of coal from the Australian seaboard is another matter of great concern. When I visited Korea and Japan I met the purchasers of Australian coal. The first question they asked was: 'Why can't you keep up your coal shipments and commitments under our contracts?'. They asked: 'Why can't we rely on your shipping?'. There are times when there are something like 40 ships lying off the port of Newcastle. People refer to them as Wran's navy. This does not enhance our reputation as a reliable supplier. We are not the only nation with coal to sell. Our great competitors, of course, are Canada, the United States of America , South Africa and Brazil. China also could become a competitor in the years ahead. We must tighten our shipping and export facilities.

I would like to say someting about China because it will become a very important trading partner of Australia in the years ahead. China, reporting a figure for its gross national product for the first time recently, said that the broad measure of its economy expanded by 9 per cent in 1982, to the equivalent of $499 billion. While outsiders have calculated and reported China's GNP in the past, the Chinese announcement marked the first time the Peking Government has given its GNP figure. Since 1979 it has been making an annual report on the economy. Previously, the Chinese, confined their reporting to more Soviet inspired concerns such as the output value of industry and agriculture, which does not measure much of the economy.

It is not clear whether the calculations China uses reflect GNP as it is understood by the rest of the world. China's GNP includes the output value of industry, agriculture, building, communications, transport, the supply and marketing of materials and equipment, and the public catering trade. Production of light industrial goods and consumer goods grew by 5.7 per cent, short of the 7 per cent target last year. Purchasing power increased by 15 per cent in 1982, to the equivalent of $136 per person. The output value of industry and agriculture rose by 8.7 per cent last year to the equivalent of $214 billion. There has been increased production in heavy industrial goods, locomotives, railway cars and ships and the construction of factories and other capital projects. The Chinese have been trying to control their spending and to concentrate their limited resources on production of consumer goods and development of transportation and energy. Spending on production of heavy industrial goods rose by 9.9 per cent to $125 billion, whilst investment in capital construction in State-owned units rose by 25 per cent to $24 billion.

China is on the march. It is a very important market for Australian goods. We export to China $670m worth of goods and we import only $270m worth of goods from China. We import mainly textiles, kitchenware, pottery, cotton articles and goods of that nature. We export wheat, wool, raw sugar, iron ore, tallow, steel wire and other products to China. The balance of trade is very much in Australia 's favour. This, of course, is of concern to the Chinese Government. We purchase from China mainly textiles and footwear-not a great item. The Chinese Government is concerned about the imbalance of trade. It believes that ways and means must be found to purchase more commodities from this area. Petroleum, of course, is a possibility. The Chinese have excellent quantities but their petroleum has huge wax and sulphur contents. Australian refineries are not able to refine this crude because of the presence of those substances. If we had ways and means of refining Chinese crude in Australia it would help to overcome the trade imbalance. It is interesting to note that a consortium of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and British Petroleum Australia Ltd have made arangements to explore for oil in the China Sea. If such oil could be refined in Australia our trade balance would be considerably enhanced.

A different set of circumstances operate in trading with the Middle East. The balance of trade is very much in favour of Saudi Arabia. We purchase from it approximately $1,032m worth of goods. Wheat, barley, cheese, live sheep and frozen meat, make up the bulk of our exports to that country. In February 1982, as a member of a parliamentary delegation, I visited Saudi Arabia and discussed trade with the top officials there. As a result, considerable quantities of chilled and frozen lamb are being exported to that country and to other countries of the Middle East.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were very impressed with you too.

—They like Australians and we have a great opportunity to expand our trade in that area. We have lost a lot of our trade with the European Ecomonic Community. It is pleasing to note that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is endeavouring to meet with the EEC to see if the position can be changed. In the middle 1970s we exported yearly to Great Britain 300,000 tonnes of beef and 200,000 tonnes of lamb. Now all we are exporting to that country is 5,000 tonnes of beef and, I think 20,000 tonnes of lamb. What a great blow that downturn in agricultural trade has been to Australia. Therefore, we must do all we possibly can to increase trade to that area, although the prospect of doing so looks bleak. Nevertheless, if we do not try, we will not succeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say a few words about the shearers' strike which, thank goodness, has ended. We pressured the Prime Minister to intervene in that strike but he said that it was best to leave it to arbitration. The shearers held the primary producers of this country to ransom. They have not been a credit to their families, to the industry or to the nation. Our primary producers have been through a devastating three years, with crop failures and no rain. To think that at a time when our primary producers could have got an income from wool production, they have been denied it! The strike also held up the shipping of our wool. Wool and coal are our greatest exports. The strike held up the arrival of our wool at the ports and consequently its being shipped overseas. That could have an adverse effect on the economy of our nation. It is good to know that the shearers are back at work. Let us hope that the unions of Australia realise the damage they are doing to this country by continuing to have strikes right across the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank God the rank and file turned up to vote.

—That is right. We are all Australians. What an opportunity we have in this country. Why does the work force not realise this. We would be a lot better off if it did. This is the greatest country in the world but how much better off would we be if we could get our work force producing instead of striking. The strikers are doing a disservice to their families, to the industry and to the Australian nation.
—Before calling the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr Staples) I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I request that he be heard in silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you upon your election to your most important office. I know that, without any valueless pretension, both you and Mr Speaker will bring to the Speaker's Chair the dignity and propriety that is always so necessary. I say this in the hope that through your example this Parliament, being as it is the fulcrum of our democracy, will uphold, indeed enhance, our nation's dignity.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that I would not be standing in this place today if it were not for the patience and support of my family and friends, the backing and campaigning of the members and supporters of the Diamond Valley Federal Electorate Assembly and the policies and members of the Australian Labor Party. I would not be standing here without the magnificent efforts of my good friend and campaign manager, Gary Greenway. I also wish to recognise the friendship and assistance of my comrades the honourable member for Casey (Mr Steedman) and the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe) and the members of the Batman electorate. I wish also to thank my many friends in the Greek community and the National South West Coalition for their trust and support. By this speech I wish to acknowledge the trust and responsibility that the 130,000 people of Diamond Valley have given me .

The 1981 census shows that Diamond Valley has a very strong bias toward the conventional family unit. The seat's age distribution is heavily clustered around the 25-year old to 44-year old age group. It has many people of migrant origin, of Greek and Italian descent especially. At least half of the Diamond Valley electorate would, by today's standards, be classified as a very affluent area. It has an extremely high proportion of home buyers and two car families. Mortgage repayments tend to be higher than the national average. By national comparison, the people of Diamond Valley are well educated and tend to have upper and middle white-collar jobs. The suburbs of Diamond Valley are comfortable and good places to live in and bring up a family. On the surface there seems to be little that should concern people too greatly.

But on 5 March 1983 the people of Diamond Valley changed their representative and embraced the policies and programs of the Australian Labor Party. In Diamond Valley, and indeed in many other seats throughout Australia, voters chose for the first time as their representatives in the Australian Parliament candidates who were clearly and unashamedly from the left of the Australian political spectrum. The conservative political desperates, who rattled their old beaten commie can as loudly as they could, can throw it away now because the people of Australia know that the year is 1983, not 1953. The red menace is now no more than a jaded electioneering paper tiger. Politically our nation is beginning rapidly to mature. On 28 May the voters of Bruce will accelerate that maturation by electing Heather O'Connor to this Parliament, and this place will be all the better for her presence.

As I have said, our nation is beginning to mature politically but it is also beginning to mature socially. The feeling of togetherness that filled our communities in the early 1970s, and which was submerged by the divisiveness, isolation and resultant introspection of the Fraser years, is beginning to re- emerge. It is abolutely vital that this process of healing and national growth be nurtured because this country is plagued by an insidious epidemic and Australians, young and old, are dying from its consequences.

It is not Legionnaires disease, genital herpes or tuberculosis. Perhaps if it had been a clear medical condition we would have been more concerned about curing it. Drug companies would be doing research in the hope of making more money and we would be doing all in our power to stop it spreading. Some people are well immune from this disease, often as a result of their birth, while others have little chance of avoiding it. To them it is almost hereditary. In the last few years its incidence has risen dramatically and more and more people of all ages, who thought they were immune and did not have to worry, are now feeling the symptoms. Many people still believe that if they are afflicted by the disease it is their own fault and they should cure themselves. Many others in this nation have been trying for years to help afflicted ones and their families, but with little support from Government. Cures are available for this disease. It just depends how much we, as a nation, want to rid ourselves of this curse. It has been spoken about in this place on many occasions. Hansard is filled with talk, excuses and figures, but words will never cure unemployment.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I waive my privilege to be heard in silence and I urge all honourable members in this House and all listeners to hear me because I am not going to be fettered by a well-meaning and gentleman's parliamentary tradition in what must now be stated. In the past eight years, the previous Government of this country used unemployment as an economic weapon, to control working people and their only real means of collective and individual protection-trade unionism . No consideration was ever given to the social cost of unemployment. Unemployment was used by the previous Government as merely an economic indicator , a measure of lost productivity, lost production, lost profits and lost business. Why are we afraid to investigate and examine the social cost of unemployment when we so readily tally up the economic cost? The reality is that the true cost of unemployment has been drastically understated, and, like Dorian Gray, we fear to look at the truth behind the mask we have put up.

The truth is that there are more than 750,000 people-750,000 human beings-in this wealthy country of ours, who today barely live on the subsistence level guilt expiator that we call unemployment benefit. One human being, one Australian, in every twenty lives on unemployment benefit. In reality, of course , that figure can easily be doubled to include the hidden unemployed-those who retire early with years of gainful employment before them, those who live on their savings and more so their pride because of the stigma of being a recipient of the dole, those like many in my relatively affluent electorate who support their children from their own pockets because they do not want people to know that their kids have not got a job.

More than two million of our fellow Australians live in poverty. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you think that I am angry about this situation, you are dead right. I state again: The former Liberal Government used unemployment as an economic weapon, without any real care, compasson or sense of obligation. The former Liberal Government did nothing about unemployment benefit for the under 18-year- olds for years. Now today, in the Age, we read that girls aged 16, 15 and 14 are having to enter into de facto relationships to get a few more dollars to live on . It is the height of arrogant duplicity for Opposition members to sit on the other side of this House now, and in the future, and to talk about the state of the economy and the plight of the unemployed, when they themselves had seven years to do something concrete about retraining, industry development, unemployment and poverty.

Millions of words have been spoken and written about our economic deficit, but it is difficult to find many in Hansard or in journals or in literature that can enlighten this Parliament and this nation about our social deficit, our human deficit. Our economic deficit can be easily calculated. As a society we have many ways and spend much of our time counting money and goods. We spend very little of our time counting the social cost of unemployment, which is just one aspect of our horrific social deficit of poverty.

What I say now may be challenged and argued, but the cold fact is that more than 1,500 Australians commit suicide each year. As a general guide, for every person who self-destructs, 17 others are hospitalised. In the past 15 years there has been a marked increase in the self-destruction of those aged between 16 and 25. Self-destruction by suicide is now the second most common cause of death among young Australians, second only to road accidents. Road accidents can often be avoided. Suicide can nearly always be avoided. A South Australian study in 1979 showed that the self-destruction or suicide rate-whicever one prefers- for unemployed men was five times greater than that for employed men. For unemployed women it was seven and a half times greater than that for employed women. These figures are well substantiated by overseas studies. For example, during the last two months of 1974 when there were massive lay-offs in the automobile industry in Detroit, the suicide rate doubled. I could go on to cite studies conclusively linking unemployment to death and sickness from heart disease, domestic violence, and violent and non-violent crime.

How many Australians, young and old, now occupy hospital beds because of illness associated with poverty and unemployment? Because of poverty and unemployment, how many people are admitted to mental hospitals? How many are spending their lives in an alcoholic or drugged haze? How many people are wasting their lives in prison because of crimes committed from desperation or anger arising from unemployment? How many women and children are beaten because of the frustration and self-hate of a husband who has lost his job? How many families are disintegrating? What effect is the fear and threat of unemployment having on the classroom behaviour of our young people? How many older people really talk and communicate with the youth of Australia? So many are angry, desperate and afraid. How many young men and young women, and how many children, find that prostitution is the only job that they can get? How many people, young and old, will be without shelter this winter? A report from the Youth Services Scheme issued by the Commonwealth and State departments only a few days ago states that demand for emergency youth accommodation exceeded supply by about 60 per cent.

In arriving at the economic cost of unemployment, has anyone included the costings for the hospital beds, medical treatment, cost of prison, foster care for children, or the loss of productivity and the production of a person who suicides? Apart from the human suffering, what is the cost to the dignity of human life, to hope and to the just share that every person has in the common wealth of Australia? How large is our social deficit, our total deficit, and what are we, as a nation and a parliament, both government and opposition, going to do about it?

The solutions to unemployment have always been there. They were continually proposed by the former Opposition and they were continually ignored by the former Government. Our educational base is weak by any comparison with equivalent nations. Our young people leave school too early, without expectation or opportunity to develop their skills. We are merely technological serfs in our own country. We have ignored our technology until it has been sold back to us. It is only then that we embrace it. We have many capable people who need encouragement, in many industries, in many technologies, both traditional and radical.

Despite record unemployment, the former Liberal Government almost totally neglected any effective work force planning. Only one in 200 unemployed people received training assistance.
