Last year, in real terms, 38 per cent less was spent on work force programs than was spent seven years before, despite the fact that unemployment had doubled. While 50 per cent of the unemployed are aged 24 or over, only 9 per cent of total training expenditure was directed to adults. For our youth, with 200,000 15 to 19-year-olds out of work, by December 1982 only 2,858 training applications were approved by the former Government. But the greatest travesty of responsibility of all was the continual refusal to put into practice effective job creation programs.

I am very proud to be part of a Labor Government that is now committed to equal and greater opportunity of education for all Australian children; committed to the active encouragement and development of new technologies and the upgrading of our traditional manufacturing industries; committed to the development of effective training programs for unemployed people and the instigation of so much needed job creation programs. We are a party, a government, committed to the restoration of dignity to the lives of so many people.

But that is only the beginning. We as a society must address ourselves to the realities of life today. Hundreds of thousands of people are out of work. Many have never had a job. Many will never have one again. For hundreds of years, whether it be in factories, in offices, on the farm or in the home, work has given us our self-esteem and our dignity. A person without work very quickly loses self-esteem. With unemployment, increased leisure time, advancing automation and loss of job satisfaction, we as a society must now start to redefine work.

We have to accept that people will not be able to be employed one way or another as they used to be in the past. There should be no distinction in society between those who work, as we define it today, for their money, and those who are unemployed, as we define it today, for their money. In an age of increasingly automated production, as a society we must now begin to learn to accept that a human being who does not produce goods and services or, more correctly, does not have the opportunity to produce goods and services, is no less a person than one who is part of the production system. Until we tax the machines which now produce the goods, until we remove from the unemployed the stigma of not being a producer of commodities, until we give those who do not have the opportunity to produce goods and services a dignified amount of money and services to live on, until those of us who do have jobs accept reality and forgo our own arrogance, greed and fear of other people, the social cost of unemployment will grow without check.

We have choices before us. They are choices to which we must address ourselves as a government, as an opposition, as members sitting here, and as an Australian community. Many of us are now beginning to realise that our nation's real wealth lies in the skills and minds of our people, not in the rocks and minerals of our land. We must greatly expand our education system so that all Australians have an equal opportunity to learn and to contribute their particular skills. We must stimulate our rational development by teaching new skills and by developing new industries.

I believe that it is meaningless to put some arbitrary figure on the economic deficit. Why do we do it? Do we do it to make the accountants and economists happy or to make things look neat and efficient, so that all of our sums add up to zero? It is not how big the deficit is that counts, but what we spend the money on. That is what is important. If we do not use our economic deficit to reduce our social deficit, and in the long run it is the social deficit which will really count, then we condemn ourselves and our children to growing economic and social upheaval. The crass ideological and inhuman use of unemployment as an economic weapon may, in the short and medium terms, be an expedient economic measure, but the long term consequences will be far more costly than Budget Papers will ever reveal.

If our bicentenary means anything more than some new roads, a bright new Parliament House and a lot of fireworks, flag waving and self-congratulation, then our economic system must now adapt to the needs of our society and not the reverse. If this is not the case, then we as a nation have wasted 200 years in an abundant land. For years now we have wasted the skills and potential of our people. That must cease. Our real challenge is not to dig everything we can out of the ground; not to allow Australia to be just the lucky quarry. The skills of our people are an unlimited and constantly renewable resource. We have to realise now, before it is too late, that we must have our national investment placed in our people because the investment of our wealth in our people will always give this nation its best return.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the maiden speech of the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr Staples). A maiden speech is a very important speech. It is one in which the honourable member and his family take a great deal of pride and in that spirit I extend to the honourable member congratulations on the fact that he has spoken in this place. I will not even dare offer the comment that Fred Daly offered to me about not wishing me many returns.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is timely to note that there is a practice in relation to maiden speeches. It is referred to in our new bible, the House of Representatives Practice by Pettifer. I would like to draw it to the attention of honourable members. Honourable members no doubt are familiar with the term 'maiden speech' which is described as the first speech of a newly elected member of the House. Pettifer states:

There is a convention in the House that a maiden speech is heard without interjection or interruption, and the Chair will normally draw the attention of the House to the fact that a Member is making his maiden speech.
The book observes, after that:
In return for this courtesy the Member should not be unduly provocative.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not. He was quite reasonable.
—It notes further, and this presents me with somewhat of a dilemma:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also customary not to make other than kindly references to the maiden speech of a Member.

I do not know why my colleagues are interjecting because I have said nothing in deprecation of the speech that the honourable member has made. I could all too easily agree with him and other honourable members who have spoken about the effect of unemployment in the community and the effect it has on individuals. A great deal of what was said in the speech today about unemployment, and has been said in the Parliament over the last few weeks, would probably be a repeat of speeches I made throughout 1974 and 1975 and on many occasions afterwards. The pain of unemployment is something that is of a great deal of concern to any human being who cares about his fellow human beings. But, in a sense, and without in any way casting aspersions on the honourable member, when from time to time comments have been made that honourable members of this side of the House would seek to use unemployment as an economic weapon-

TALK.START.PARA: —Your record confirmed it.

—I find that assertion not unkind. The expression I would use would be much more in condemnation of those who use such words and I very much object to them because I and my colleagues would in no way want unemployment to be used as a weapon in an endeavour to remedy the difficulties through which we have been going.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask honourable members to remain silent.
—You fought inflation with unployment.
—Order! The honourable member for Hotham will remain silent.

—On many occasions, the wheel does a full turn, and all too often we come back to examine the record of those who have gone before. I believe that I will have an opportunity to examine this present Government's record on unemployment and I suspect that as time goes on I will be casting through the many speeches of this week, drawing upon quotations, and pointing out the failure of the Government to be able to remedy the unemployment that I think its policies will leave us with.
—Just give it a chance.

—I am perfectly prepared to give it a chance. I am not here in any sense condemning the will of the people or complaining about that. But I am prepared to examine critically the policies of the Government, as honourable members would expect me to. I hope that they also will examine very carefully the way in which the Government is approaching these matters, bearing in mind the National Economic Summit Conference and the great deal of information that has been made publicly available. I hope they will look at the scenarios which have been painted realistically and ask themselves whether the proposals that they have in mind are likely to remedy that all-important problem of unemployment which has been referred to and which was referred to so eloquently by the honourable member who spoke before me.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last election I made the point over and over again that we live in a competitive world. Nobody else in the world believes that they owe us in the lucky country a living. All too often we think in a rather patronising way, I suspect, of what we can do for other countries and what support we can offer, without looking critically at our own national performance. That is what I think we ought to be doing. We look too often at the resources that we have and we assume that with our well educated community, our industriousness and our capacity we will be able to make a good fist of it. But I think, if we look at the performance of other countries in the region-countries such as Singapore and Japan which have no resources equivalent to ours but have only their industriousness to ensure that they are able to excel-that honourable members opposite would agree with me that for one reason or another our national performance is found wanting.

I do not know whether it is because we take matters all too easily, because we consider that we have all these opportunities, all these resources and collectively sit on our butts, but in a sense I think that we have smugly brought ourselves to the view that we can satisfactorily continue to live beyond our means.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever been on a production line? You are a lawyer. When have you ever had to work hard? How about the workers?
—The fact of the matter is that before the last election we went through a period in which the work force of Australia was paid a great deal more , directly, and in terms of conditions of service--

—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will please resume his seat. The honourable member for Hotham interjects. I remind him that the honourable member for Dundas, in common with every member of this House, has the right to be heard in silence. The Chair has the obligation to see that that requirement is observed.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I apologise, I just cannot stand a lawyer telling the workers to work harder.
—The honourable member's apology is noted. I call the honourable member for Dundas.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for your intervention. The point I was making was that there were very considerable wage increases over and above the increases in productivity and over and above increases in the cost of living.
—That was just a catch-up.

—It may have been regarded as a catch-up but it occurred over two years. I think the experience that we then saw of very significant unemployment where there was a shedding of labour revealed the result of those increases. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) said it was just a catch-up; a catch- up for some meant the jobs of others. We went through a very difficult period because of the drought. We also saw the onslaught of the world recession. Honourable members on this side stated that over and over again but obviously that message did not influence the 5 per cent of the electorate that was necessary to vote against us on this occasion to effect a change of government.
—There will be more next time.

—I suspect there will be more people changing their minds next time. I suspect they will do it very much the other way. I think it is important that honourable members appreciate the importance of wages and wage costs in relation to unemployment in this country. The Summit was designed to draw attention to our economic problems and to bring about a situation where people could sit down quietly and realistically and, we were told, in a non-contentious and non- confrontationist environment and talk about the problems we face. It really brought out, I think, more clearly to me the nature of the effect of wage increases on our economy and upon the jobs of so many people in this community. I mentioned the very significant loss of profits the very significant increases of wages as a percentage of gross national product. Of course, I should mention the wage pause which was initiated by the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The wage pause was beginning to work. The new Hawke Government will benefit greatly, I think, as a result of it. It was slow to have an effect on inflation. That must be acknowledged. But recent figures suggest that it has had some impact. It is important to note that notwithstanding the wage pause which has had a significant effect upon those for whom legislation has ensured that it operates-those in the Public Service and similar areas-it has ensured that for some people there has been a net reduction in their standard of living. But the wage pause obviously has not had that effect overall because some people in the community obviously have been able to bargain outside the system or bargain outside the effects of those arrangements. We have seen an increase of something of the order of 1.5 per cent or thereabouts in average weekly earnings at a time when one would not have expected an increase. Notwithstanding that I anticipate that we will see, as a result of the wage pause put into place by the previous Government, some benefit if it is allowed to operate as it was originally intended.

The Government, of course, before the Summit, put before us a number of scenarios in relation to wages which it believed ought to be brought to people's attention. The Government put arguments to us about each of those proposals, the extent to which they would affect the consumer price index and, ultimately, the effect they would have upon productivity and upon employment. I think it is important to state for the record what those scenarios were. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) outlined to the Economic Summit that scenario A assumed no catch up for the consumer price index increases prior to the current wages pause. There would be a 3 per cent wage increase during the latter half of 1983 followed by a return to full quarterly wage indexation early in 1985 with a return to annual productivity cases. Scenario B assumed an end to the wages pause in June with an immediate full catch-up to compensate for all consumer price increases then outstanding. There would be an immediate return to full indexation with quarterly adjustments with the first such adjustment occurring in August- September 1983 and a return to productivity cases in 1984. Scenario C assumed the continuation of the current wages pause, the one put in place by the Fraser Government, until April 1984 followed by a return to half-yearly partial indexation with compensation for consumer price increases in the September and December quarters of 1983.

Each of these scenarios was likely to have quite different effects, but the projections presented by the Government with those scenarios show that scenario C-the last one that I mentioned-with the maximum of wage restraint offered the most rapid course for recovery. Of course, scenario C provides the best outcome in increasing employment, decreasing unemployment and reducing inflation. It provides for the Government's stated aim of 550,000 jobs by June 1986. I think with that scenario so clearly pointing to the Government's objective of reducing unemployment by some 500,000 that it would be advocated so strongly by every honourable member of the Opposition, that every maiden speech would endeavour to persuade the community at large of the need for that scenario to be followed. My constituent, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, should stop sounding the retreat and accept that scenario C is in the nation's best interest.

Scenario A appears to be the one that the Government, in its fall-back position , is arguing. But there is no certainty that scenario A, which envisages a 3 per cent wage increase this year followed by a return to full quarterly indexation next year, will be achieved because the trade union movement, the natural ally, it is sometimes said, of the Government, is arguing that scenario B be followed. This assumes an end to the wages pause in June with an immediate effort to full catch-up to compensate for all consumer price index increases then outstanding.

This is of very considerable concern to me because I believe that wages policy, along with some of the other matters that were mentioned such as restraint on the part of employers, directors of companies and restraint in relation to private incomes-those matters were canvassed very fully at the national Summit- is absolutely essential if we are to grapple with this very important problem. I acknowledge that unemployment is a problem. It is a problem to everybody who is unemployed. I acknowledge it in the terms that have been mentioned so emotively by so many of the honourable members who have spoken before. But we have to look at what policies ought to be pursued by this nation if we are to come to grips with that problem.

The wage policy of the present Government will be a key to our national economic recovery. The Government will not be able to run away from it. It does not matter when an election is held, whether it is held in 18 months, three years or four years. Ultimately, if responsible economic policies are not pursued, unemployment will remain with us and will be the very basis upon which the Hawke Government will be judged. Mark my words, I will not let any of the honourable members opposite forget the words of their maiden speeches when they talked about the record of the previous Government in endeavouring to cope with these problems. I will certainly be directing the attention of the community to those words and those comments because it will be the very measure of the Government's record, of its performance on that question, as to how it will be judged.

There are many other issues that, if time permitted, I would like to discuss. The question of the deficit is important because the present Government is using it as an excuse for its prospective failure to deliver its promises. The Government has endeavoured-and will later tonight, I understand, in a statement- to sound its retreat on so many of the statements that were made to the Australian people in an election only a matter of months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know?
—I will be listening very carefully.
—Well, you don't know. You are just misleading the House.
—I suspect that it will very much sound the retreat. The Minister for Housing and Construction may care to look at his interjection tomorrow because he may well find-
—Order! I remind the honourable member that he should not directly address other honourable members but should address the House through the Chair.

—In the few minutes remaining I wish to say that it is not just the statement tonight that will be relevant in making that judgment about the sounding of the retreat. We already know that on the question of devaluation Mr Hawke promised, as reported in the Australian Financial Review of 10 February 1983, that he would not devalue. Yet three days after the Government was elected he and his Treasurer (Mr Keating) devlaued the Australian dollar by 10 per cent, resulting in significantly higher prices in some areas of expenditure for all Australian families. We know that in the area of tax cuts the Prime Minister made certain statements at the time of the election. In the Labor Party policy speech, he said that immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australians or taxpayers would be put in place. It may well be that I will have to wait until tonight to see what will happen but I suspect that that promise has already been devalued and the Government's record can be judged on that too.

—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the honourable member for Fadden. I alert the House to the fact that it is the honourable member's maiden speech and require the House to extend the ordinary courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I offer my congratulations on your election to your high office and ask you to pass my good wishes to the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) on his election as Speaker. I would also like to extend to all of my colleagues my appreciation of their entering the House to listen to my maiden speech. It must be quite a feat of endurance with so many maiden speeches from this side of the House. However, the standard of speeches delivered by my colleagues has been exceptional and I am honoured to be part of our Government. The election of 5 March was a watershed in Australian politics and for many of us a vindication of our stand in 1975. The previous Government was dismissed by the Australian people because once and for all the myth of competent economic management by the conservative parties of this country has been destroyed. After seven years of Fraserism, every facet of the economic fabric of our society was in tatters. The past seven years of Australian politics have been marred by division.

SPEECH.PARA: The campaign of my party at the last election was fought on a central theme of reconciliation. This contrasts greatly with that of our opponents. The proposition that we put forward to the Australian people was that we should all work together for the good of our country, for unless an attitude of reconciliation can be fostered in the Australian community at large no policies of any government can assist us on the road to recovery. The previous Government divided this country. It divided employer against employee and it divided management against unions. It had in its mind only continued electoral success and that was the only criterion for any decision it made. We on this side of the House totally reject that concept.

It was proved by the National Economic Summit Conference that all Australians can obtain consensus. I do not suggest that we are a society that has no differences but I do suggest that we are a society that can strive to achieve a common goal. The Australian Council of Trade Unions proved at the Economic Summit that it understands the need for wage restraint and with few exceptions this concept has been accepted by the union movement at large. It was also heartening to hear employer groups at the Summit accept the principle that we must fight both unemployment and inflation at the same time.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to turn my attention briefly to my electorate of Fadden. The campaign to win the seat of Fadden involved dedication and hard work from a large number of party members and supporters. My campaign began in 1978 and during the last five years that I have been the candidate the party organisation built up from just over 200 members to a position on election day where we had 500 people in the field.

In particular I would like to pay tribute to my campaign directors Peter Hamburger and Eric McGregor who, along with my campaign secretary, Hazel Hubbard , formed the nucleus of the team. I would also like to pay a special tribute to my wife, Patricia, and two young sons Aaron and Shannon, who have given me tremendous support over the past five years. The Federal division of Fadden is a microcosm of Australia with people of all pursuits represented. I have the unenviable distinction of representing the largest Federal division in Australia ; not in area-that honour goes to my colleague, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell)-but in voters. The information provided by the Australian Electoral Office gives enrolment figures of 103,671 for the seat at the end of April 1983.

A large proportion of my electors reside in Australia's newest city-Logan City. Logan City local government area was created initially in 1978 as a shire council and was incorporated as a city in 1981. Logan City has suffered greatly at the hands of the Bjelke-Petersen Government in Queensland. It was an Act by the National Party Minister for Local Government, Russ Hinze, which created the shire. It has been the National-Liberal Party Government in Queensland which has neglected it ever since.

There are few people in Queensland, let alone the nation at large, who realise that Logan is now the third largest city in Queensland. This tremendous growth since 1978 has placed great strains on this local authority and it is struggling to supply basic services to its ratepayers. The Queensland Government which created this authority has now turned its back upon it. A dedicated staff of aldermen and council officers have tried to make the best out of funds available , but are struggling after suffering enormous cutbacks in sewerage subsidies by the Queensland Government.

It is significant that this Government is the first Government in this country' s 82-year history to have a Minister for Territories and Local Government, my honourable colleague the member for Reid, Mr Tom Uren. Logan city and the electorate of Fadden at large are suffering greatly from the effects of the economic recession. My electorate has the largest unemployment levels in south- east Queensland, and tragically this is even more so amongst our young people. As has been said by many other speakers in this debate, the primary reason for our election was that we offered to the Australian people hope and not despair. We as a government will be judged on our record in job creation more than any other issue. This is why I would urge all members of the Ministry to work closely with local government in any job creation programs.

Apart from the Logan city area, other local authority areas which are wholly or partly contained within the Federal division of Fadden are the Beaudesert Shire Council, Boonah Shire Council, Albert Shire Council and parts of Brisbane City Council. All of these local authorities have been starved of funds for many years and are only too willing to work in close liason with this Government for the benefit of all the people in Fadden.

The great tragedy for Australia is that for the past seven years the honourable members opposite, whilst the Government of this country, abandoned the principle of long term government planning for short term political gain. Never in Australia's history has there been a Prime Minister so short-sighted as the previous member for Wannon. I think that it is indicative of the man that he took the easy way out and did not return to this place to be accountable for the legacy that he has left this Government. All the principles of monetarism that he espoused were thrown out the window in the last few desperate months of the previous Government to try to buy another term of office. The old saying 'it must be an election year. I feel a dam coming on' was only too true in relation to our predecessors.

Let me assure the people of Australia that this Government will not make decisions based solely on political considerations. We have already set in motion proposals for a referendum to have fixed three-year sessions of Parliament so that no longer can a Prime Minister-any Prime Minister-manipulate an election date to his own advantage. Once the Australian people carry this referendum they will know that on the third Saturday in November every three years the Government will be accountable for its actions.

The fixed term concept for elections is one that I wholeheartedly support and one that I am sure the majority of Australians in a majority of States will also support. We must always be conscious that the Australian Labor Party is a party of reform and vision. We have not been elected by the Australian people to maintain the position of privilege that so many powerful groups in our society have held for so long. It was the average Australian who elected this Government -men and women who struggle from day to day to support their families. It is the average Australian who has made this country great. The captains of industry would have no powerful corporations without the thousands of people whose toil produces the great wealth of this country.

There is also another sector of our society which was abandoned by the previous Government, that is, the small business sector. I had the privilege, before being elected as member for Fadden, of working with the diligent and enterprising people who make up the small business sector. The previous Government mouthed platitudes about the support for small business. That is all they were-platitudes. Honourable members opposite presided over the greatest number of bankruptcies of small business people that this country has ever seen. This was reflected in the last election campaign when small business rallied to support me. Both through financial contributions and physical help, they contributed greatly to my success. A vibrant small business sector is absolutely essential to any economic recovery in our nation, for it provides the jobs. Small business is the largest employer in this country. Many members would be unaware that businesses employing fewer than 100 people employ 61 per cent of the total Australian non-government work force. The small business sector needs this Government's help if it is to flourish.

My colleague the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has a great vision of establishing new Australian industries. I am sure he carries the full support of all members of this Government. The problems of small business involve more than deciding just what type of business to establish. There are two fundamental problems that most new businesses encounter. They are: Firstly, undercapitalisation and, secondly, lack of managerial skills. I would implore the Government to expand vastly the role of the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia so that those Australians who wish to commence their own business or expand their existing business do not suffer from the small-mindedness of some of our banking institutions. Too often, the only criterion that financial institutions use is security in terms of bricks and mortar. They do not have the vision at times to grasp a concept that may have tremendous economic benefit for our nation at large.

The Commonwealth Development Bank, with an expanded charter and a degree of Government funding, would be able to assist Australians to use their skills in what have been termed the sunrise industries, to create new industries which will in turn stem the tide of economic recession. Australia has sadly fallen behind the rest of the world in relation to the new technologies. It is tragic that many of our own people who have the skills to develop this technology have to go overseas to realise their potential. Many jobs have been lost to Australia forever because of financial restraints placed on Australian enterprises. Through lack of availability of long term credit, many businesses have floundered and Australia's opportunity of sustaining economic growth has faltered.

It is not just the financial constraints that bring Australian small business undone. Lack of management skills has often been the downfall of what should have been a prosperous business. Simply being a good tradesman is not enough to be a successful businessman. Such things as debtor controls and basic book- keeping skills are essential if a business is to survive. I do not suggest that this Government should become involved in the day to day affairs of small business enterprises but I do feel that it should expand its role in assisting small business to come to grips with the economic realities that guide the market sector of our economy.

In particular, the success of small business has a marked effect on my seat of Fadden. With the exceptions of the General Motors-Holden's Ltd plant at Acacia Ridge and the meatworks at Beaudesert and Beenleigh, there are few large employers within the electorate boundaries. During the past seven years of Liberal Government, many viable small to medium sized businesses have failed, further eroding the economic base. If employment levels in Fadden are to be raised, small business must be revitalised. I look forward very much to the programs that we hope will be implemented by this Government to stimulate the building industry, as this will be one of the few areas in my electorate that will create jobs immediately.

One area of great potential for small business people is the tourism industry. Labor governments have recognised the need for Federal Government assistance. There have been only two Federal Ministers for Tourism in Australia's history. The first was in the Whitlam Government, the second was created by the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) upon our election to office. This nation is, without doubt, the world's best tourist destination but unfortunately it is also the world's best kept secret. My colleague the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has tried valiantly over the last two months to stimulate a rational debate on tourism. Unfortunately, many sections of the media and certainly all sections of the Opposition have sought to trivialise this debate. Australia now receives only one per cent of the world's tourist trade; whereas if we could increase this to a modest 2 per cent we would be able to create an additional 100,000 jobs immediately and earn hundreds upon hundreds of millions of dollars in additional revenue.

I fully support the Government's Buy Australian program. I would also support a tourist industry program of 'See Australia First'. Approximately one million foreign visitors come to Australia each year but again, unfortunately, 1.3 million Australians leave this country each year either on holidays or business trips. While it is important for Australians to have contact with overseas cultures, it is also important to show off our magnificent country to the nations of the world.

The Labor City Council of Brisbane, in October last year, staged the magnificent Commonwealth Games. As well as attracting a large number of foreign visitors who came for the games, this was a magnificent promotion which introduced Brisbane to millions of television viewers throughout the Commonwealth.

The Government has already forecast that it wishes to introduce a one-price air ticket to be used by tourists whilst travelling throughout Australia. It is to be hoped that this meets with a warm reception from Australia's airlines so that we avoid the crazy situation where the majority of our flights are, at best, half full. I speak with some experience in the tourist industry, as I come from Queensland, which is undoubtedly the tourist destination of many Australians. However, this is not a matter for individual State considerations. This country offers the full range of tourist destinations from the magnificence of the Great Barrier Reef, to the hustle and bustle of cosmopolitan Sydney, out to the solitude of Ayers Rock. No matter what type of holiday tourists wish to have, they can come to Australia. Who can deny the charm of Tasmania or the awesome beauty of Australia's snowfields?

We need to develop a new attitude in Australia in relation to the way in which we treat foreign tourists, for a tourist who comes from the United States expects and even demands a standard of services that we are not used to producing. To give foreign tourists the 24-hour service that they are accustomed to in overseas destinations, we must strike an accord between government, unions and the tourist industry. This Government is not about imposing slave labour conditions on those who work in the hospitality industry, but if the industry itself is prepared to talk, compromise and agree to permanency of employment, we may be able to reach an accord on rostered shifts for this industry alone. It is not, as some see it, an outright attack on penalty rates, because we must understand that the penalty rates imposed on the industry are only to offset a very low base rate.

In my own electorate of Fadden, the Moran family has made an enormous capital investment in restoring and upgrading the Beenleigh Rum Distillery. This is a truly magnificient complex which has vast tourist potential. Many other projects could be undertaken in line with the Government's job creation program in providing bush walks and tourist facilities at some of our magnificient national parks. A case in point, again in my electorate, would be the upgrading of bush walks in the Lamington National Park. However, there is one large section of our society to whom the talk of tourism is just an abstract. Two million Australians living below the poverty line have no concept of what an annual holiday is. It should be a responsibility of this Government to provide low cost accommodation at tourist destinations. The construction of hostels similar to the youth hostels that are scattered throughout Australia would give these low income families the opportunity to break away for a short period each year. Again the construction of such hostels would be of great benefit to the construction industry. It would also provide a stimulus to the economy of those areas where such hostels were to be developed.

Although Australia is only a medium sized nation in the scheme of world events, it has an important role to play as an independent nation. Without abdicating its responsibilities under treaties, Australia can use its position as a free nation to influence the super-powers. As has been said often, we are one of only 30 remaining democracies in the world and with this we carry a tremendous responsibility. Whilst we do not have the military capability, and hopefully never will, to enforce our viewpoint on other nations, we have the capacity to influence other nations. It must always be remembered that it was an Australian who was considered the father of the United Nations, the former member for Barton, Dr H. V. Evatt. This tradition has endured through the years despite unfortunate lapses by Liberal governments, such as our involvement in the Vietnam War. Even the previous Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) played a world acclaimed role in the settlement of the Rhodesian conflict which led to the creation of the new state of Zimbabwe. Many nations from both the Eastern and Western blocs value Australia's opinion and we should use this goodwill to work towards global peace. For without peace, this small planet is destined for destruction. However, as a national Government we should never let the world stage divert us from our responsibilities to the underprivileged of our own society. While we talk of global peace and global conflict, many of our own people do not even have a roof over their heads.

Many parts of my electorate act as dormitory suburbs for Brisbane and as the Brisbane population spreads there is an ever increasing demand for both public and private sector housing. In particular, public sector housing in Queensland is in a state of almost total collapse. The Bjelke-Petersen Government has completely abdicated its responsibilities in the public housing sector and there are some 9,500 families now on the Queensland Housing Commission waiting list. Statistics do not tell the real story, however. I am sure many of my colleagues can recount harrowing stories. I recall that a 17-year old boy had to live in a park in my electorate after being turned out of the family home because he was not able to find employment. As I said, all my colleagues can recount similar stories and it is my firm conviction that these injustices must be rectified. It is only through this Government that there is any hope for our people for we must maintain our commitment to the creation of a just and equitable society. All countries should be judged by one criterion alone, and that is their attitude to the people in their society who do not have access to its wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to participate in the Address-in-Reply debate. At the outset I congratulate all the new members of the House, firstly, for their election and, secondly, for the excellent maiden speeches which have been delivered. We have just heard one example from the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Beddall). Of course, if he is as good as Don Cameron, the previous member for Fadden, he will be a very effective member indeed. One thing that worries me is that so many of the new Labor members look like young Liberals. Perhaps there has been some major shift in politics in this country. It is great to hear the idealism that has been displayed in the maiden speeches of these young members. That is an excellent thing. It would be great also if these members could retain this idealism beyond their first speeches. If they are concerned deeply about the issues on which they have spoken one would hope that they are prepared to criticise, if necessary, to stimulate discussion and debate and, perhaps, to bring issues into this House when their own Government is not performing as it might be. For example, if the Government is not effectively overcoming the great problem that we face at the moment-that is unemployment-I would hope that these members would be prepared to come in here and publicly express their concern about the lack of performance by their own Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk briefly tonight about the problem of unemployment. I believe that it is our number one national problem. It is true to say that the previous Government was not able to overcome that problem effectively. Of course, that goes without saying if one looks at the figures. When we came to office the unemployment rate in this country was about 5 per cent. Regrettably, when we left office it was in the order of 10 per cent. I do not mind admitting that- that is a fact of life and we should be frank about these things. However, that is not to say that the then Prime Minister, the responsible Ministers and the members who sat behind them were not concerned about unemployment. They were deeply concerned and they did what they could to overcome that problem. But, of course, there were forces at work which were, to some degree, beyond their control. Anyone who is honest would admit that it is not easy to overcome unemployment in this country or, indeed, in any other country. All the industrialised countries have suffered a similar fate. West Germany at present has a high rate of unemployment-a rate higher than that in Australia. Again, the rate of unemployment in the United Kingdom is higher than that in Australia. Even Canada, which is regarded as having quite a strong economy, has had a higher rate of unemployment in recent times than Australia has.

It is worth relating the figures because to some degree they indicate the tragedy that is unemployment. In April 1983, 707,300 people were unemployed in this country. That figure was 271,100 or 62.2 per cent greater than that in April 1982. This compares with an increase of 271,900 or 59.1 per cent over the year to March 1983. The present rate, as I mentioned, is a bit over 10 per cent- 10.2 per cent. This compares with 6.4 per cent in April 1982-that is a year ago- 5.6 per cent in April 1981 and 6.1 per cent in April 1980. So we have seen quite a rapid increase in the rate of unemployment in this country in the past 18 months to two years. There has been a very significant increase indeed.

One can look at the reason why the Opposition is now in opposition and the Government is now in government. I think that the answer very much revolves around the issue of unemployment which has affected so many families, not just those directly involved and young people in particular. This problem has pervaded the community at large. I think that many people were very frustrated. They were not satisfied with what was being done and they decided that perhaps they should give the then Opposition a chance to see what it could do. Now the Labor Government has the opportunity to see what it can really do about this very serious problem of unemployment. Emphasis on the problem of unemployment is given in the fourth paragraph of the policy speech of the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which he delivered at the Sydney Opera House on 16 February 1983. He said:

There are tremendous issues involved in this historic election of 5 March-first and foremost, the right of all Australians to a job; and whether the disastrous economic policies, the political opportunism and the divisive leadership which together have produced Australia's present catastrophic unemployment are to be changed.

For the sake of the one million and more Australians who face unemployment unless there is a change, those policies must be changed, and will be changed-by the Australian Labor government after 5 March.

I do not mind repeating those words. They were perhaps historic words. I think it will be worth while in two or three years time to look back to see whether the then Leader of the Opposition-the present Prime Minister-was really able to produce the goods to overcome this problem and significantly reduce unemployment .

There is no doubt that the Government was elected with a sense of optimism- certainly on the part of those on the Government side-and confidence that it would overcome this problem. But we have seen something of a change in tune since the election. Before the election the inference was that Mr Hawke as Prime Minister would be able to overcome the problem of unemployment, that suddenly we would see a significant reduction in unemployment. He talked about half a million jobs being created. He did not say they would be created immediately but that within a reasonable time he would create all of these jobs. He attacked the previous Government for its policies which he said were not doing enough. He said that his Government would do very much more. But, as I said, there has been a change of tune since the election. I think that the Government is now to some extent backing away from this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Running.

—It is running away from this issue and that is a very tragic thing. It is going very quietly and softly on the issue of unemployment. There is not the same strength in the remarks that the Prime Minister is presently making. If we look at the statements that were made at the historic National Economic Summit Conference that was held not so very long ago in this very chamber we see in the various scenarios painted by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) an acknowledgment that unemployment will remain at a very high level. One of the scenarios indicated that unemployment would increase significantly by 1984-85. The other two scenarios indicated that unemployment would remain at about the same level as it is now. So I ask honourable members to consider the fact that the Prime Minister , when Leader of the Opposition, said he would do all sorts of things to get unemployment down and get young people into work and, within a matter of weeks, he has acknowledged with the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) the fact that unemployment will remain at around about 10 per cent for a number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that a weakening in the stand taken by the Government is a most unfortunate occurrence for the country. If the Government is to overcome the problem of unemployment it has to attack it pretty swiftly and with a great deal of strength and resolve. It will not overcome it by giving any indication of weakness on its part. Already we have seen that the Government is not prepared to really bite the bullet. It is not prepared to acknowledge that the wage and salary levels in this country are a major cause of unemployment. Recently, we saw the President of the ACTU, Mr Cliff Dolan, effectively shoot down the ALP- ACTU accord and the Summit communique. The Summit communique did not mean very much at all. It was very much overrated; it contained nice words.

At the time of the Summit there was a very cosy situation in this chamber. Everyone was patting each other on the back. It was great to see the leaders of industry meeting with the leaders of the labour movement and the leaders of the Government and discussing their various points of view. But the communique was a pretty wishy-washy sort of document. It did not really tackle the problems this country faces. In particular, it did not acknowledge the very simple fact that the costs of employment are a major reason why there is not enough employment at present. There is absolutely no doubt that if, in a real sense, we were able to reduce the cost of employment by reducing wage levels and the various allowances that go to employees-I am referring also to people who earn salaries, because we are not just talking about wage earners-very many more job opportunities would be created.

Three or four years ago I had the opportunity of going to a Labor Ministers conference in Western Samoa on behalf of the then Minister. At this conference, Ministers and others from various countries around the Pacific region talked about unemployment. It is a major problem in so many of the countries in this region-indeed, as I have said, it is a major problem all around the world-and the common concern of those Ministers was the high levels of wages paid in their respective countries, particularly the junior rates of pay. It was generally felt that if we could somehow get wage levels down, particularly junior wage rates, we would provide so many more people-especially our young people-with a chance to work. What a tragedy it is that so many young people at present do not have the opportunity of experiencing work and its accompanying rewards or of having the confidence and self-esteem that having a job brings.

I referred earlier to some of the figures but they do not tell the full story. Figures do not take account of the human factor, the trauma that affects the individual who is out of a job for a long time or who may never have had a job. Such people see prospective employers, trying to get jobs, and time after time they are knocked back. They lose their confidence and self-esteem and wonder what their life is all about, what they are here for, and what they should be doing with themselves. In my town I hear stories and see young people wandering around the streets. Some of them go to the pub. Perhaps there is no harm in that , but they spend a bit too much time in the pub. They meet their friends there and have a bit to drink. This goes on day in and day out, which brings its own problems. Some turn to alcohol, some to drugs, and some become involved with petty crime. Honourable members on the Government side should not believe that people on this side do not have some understanding and feeling about the problem . We trust that the Labor Government has some answers.

As I said earlier, new members are idealistic when they first come to this place. They are full of idealism. It is a sad thing that the longer we stay in this place-I have been here for almost eight years now; many others have been here much longer-the more we become embroiled in party politics and lose that sense of idealism that the new members have displayed in their maiden speches. The problem of unemployment should always be focused upon in this Parliament. I hope that the Government might agree to set up a select commitee to look at the problem of unemployment. I recall that the Prime Minister, when he was the Opposition spokesman on employment, said that we should have a joint committee to look into this problem of unemployment-its causes, its effects and remedies, if any. What effect do wage rates have on unemployment? Can we reduce unemployment through job creation schemes?

TALK.START.PARA: —Junior rates of pay?

—The honourable member for Mitchell mentions junior rates of pay. He is very concerned about this problem as it affects his constituents and he has voiced his views on many occasions. I believe that it would be appropriate for this Parliament to establish a select committee on unemployment. We have committees on so many other important problems. We have had a committee on road safety, a very serious problem. It has been a very effective committee. It has made many important recommendations, some of which have been accepted by the relevant governments, particularly the State governments. Some of its recommendations have been ignored, but it has done some very good work. We have defence committees, foreign affairs committees, committees to look at this and that. Perhaps we need a committee to really consider the problem of unemployment . Many members of the Government side acknowledge that it is the major problem facing this country at present. If it is the major problem, surely Government members would support the honourable member for Mitchell, myself and others on this side who believe it would be appropriate to have a select committee to go around Australia and look into this problem, to find answers to it and, in particular, to oversee the actions or inactions of the Government over the coming months and years. The sooner that committee is established the better.
—That's real consensus.

—It would be real consensus. This is the Address-in-Reply debate. If we look at the speech made by His Excellency, the Governor-General on 21 April of this year we will see that he made a point about consensus. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: My new Government has pledged itself to the pursuit of national reconciliation, national recovery and national reconstruction.

Those objectives would be very much helped if we had members who, in a bipartisan way, approached this problem and were prepared to speak up and, if necessary, criticise their own party or government if it does not act in the right way, in a way which will grasp this problem and make sure that we provide real jobs for these young people. I do not know whether we can provide the answers. I certainly believe that there is a good chance that we can. If we look around the world we can see that no one has tackled the problem very effectively . That does not mean that we in Australia cannot do so. We should make every effort to tackle the problem effectively.

Members of this Parliament should not be underrated. As I said before, representatives at the Summit sat in this chamber and the Prime Minister called them the representatives of the people. But we happen to be elected by the people. We might be pretty ordinary, but we have been elected and we reflect the values of our electorates and constituents. We reflect, or should reflect, their desires and aspirations. This Parliament has to lift itself and become much more effective. At the moment I do not believe it achieves very much from day to day, except perhaps to create a few crises. That is not a good thing for the Government of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We occasionally get a stimulating half hour like this which sets us aflame.
—Order! The honourable member will ignore interjections and the Minister will remain silent.

—The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment is attacking me for the comments I am making. I am trying to make some reasonable comments about the problems that we have and, in particular, about unemployment.
—The country is in a mess because of your government.
—If the Minister is not concerned about unemployment what is he doing here?
—Your Government was in office for seven years.
—Order! The Minister will remain silent.
—You are in government now and you have to try to do something about it .
—The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair.

—I am suggesting that we should set up a select committee to really grasp this problem and to try to find some answers which could give the Government some strength because at the moment it certainly has had a bad start. It has gone to water on a number of issues. We have had all sorts of problems. It is very sad-this government was elected with a significant majority-that the Government has had such a bad two weeks. It has got the smell of decay about it already, after only a couple of weeks in this place. It needs to be beefed up a little. The Government needs to be given some good advice. I believe that the members of this Parliament can give the Government good advice, especially on this important subject of unemployment.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in attempting to interject made a remark which was decidedly unparliamentary. I ask him to withdraw it.
—I do not know what I said.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is now just over a month since representatives of governments, employers, trade unions and other sections of the Australian community met in this place, as participants in the National Economic Summit Conference, to exchange views on the serious problems facing Australia and to discuss how to deal with those problems. Since then, the Government has given intensive consideration to many of the major issues discussed at the Summit and referred to in its communique. Following the general agreement reached then for the establishment of an Economic Planning Advisory Council, we have had further discussions with representatives of other governments, of the trade unions and of business, and have decided upon the detailed arrangements for the Council. Legislation to give effect to those arrangements will be introduced in the House in the current session.

SPEECH.PARA: The Economic Planning Advisory Council will therefore shortly be a reality and through it we shall continue the process of information sharing and consultation initiated at the Summit. Similarly, we are participating, along with employers, unions and other governments, in conferences before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which have been called in accordance with the request in the Summit communique to develop the option of a return to a centralised wage system. In other specialised forums we have furthered the process of consultation with a view to reaching agreed solutions to the problems confronting particular industries or regions. Such processes must lead in the end to policy decisions by each of the participants, including by governments.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his opening address to the Conference, this Government cannot escape and does not wish to escape its primary and fundamental responsibility for the economic and social policies of the nation. Since the Summit we have been pushing ahead with the necessary policy decisions to give effect to our basic objectives of promoting economic growth and creating additional employment.

Tonight I outline the decisions we have reached on substantive changes to expenditure and taxation programs and associated monetary policy issues. We have been determined to act with speed so that any uncertainty as to the broad nature of our intentions should be resolved as soon as possible and the processes of recovery set in train. Equally, however, we have been determined not to rush into decisions which require more thorough study and deliberation. We have no intention of indulging in the wholesale reversals of policy which have been all too frequent in this country in recent years and which have done much to generate uncertainty and shatter not only the confidence of business but also the aspirations of thousands of unemployed Australians.

The decisions which I shall shortly announce should be taken as indicative of the directions in which we will be moving in the months and years ahead and, in particular, in the Budget for 1983-84 to be brought down on 23 August. We have of course also been guided by the nature of the economic problems highlighted in the Summit discussions-most particularly, the parlous budgetary situation which we have inherited. This background requires further elaboration before I turn to our specific decisions.
Agreements from the Summit

As reflected in the communique, widespread agreement at several levels was reached among Summit participants. First, there was agreement on the basic facts of the economic crisis. Naturally, individual perceptions and emphases differed somewhat, but there was broad recognition: That unemployment is unacceptably high and is still rising, and that the burden of unemployment has fallen unequally upon the various groups in our society; that inflation must be brought under control if the economy is to recover and lasting jobs are to be created, a view since heightened by the release of the March quarter consumer price index figures; that profits are depressed to historically low levels and that recovery must come here, too, if economic prosperity is to be restored; and finally that, particularly when the economic cake has been shrinking, moderation in claims for a share of that cake is required, a recognition that underlies the need for burden sharing which has been central to our decisions now to be announced.

Secondly, there was substantial agreement about the factors which had contributed to our economic malaise and which must be addressed if that malaise is to be overcome. In particular there was widespread recognition of the role of : Unrealistic expectations, generated for political ends, which had resulted in large increases in real wage levels for some and unemployment for others; high interest rates, resulting from erratic and inconsistent application of monetary policies in a high inflation environment; and the pervasive but largely unavoidable consequences of the recession abroad and drought at home.

Finally, there was agreement on the general approach necessary to deal with our problems. Sustained economic growth must be restored and, contrary to the policies of the previous Government, inflation and unemployment should be tackled simultaneously. That is, of course, a very demanding approach. The interrelationships between inflation and unemployment were widely acknowledged in the Summit discussions. To combat inflation and unemployment simultaneously cannot merely involve allotting one policy to reduce inflation and another to tackle unemployment. On the contrary, in these as in other regards policies must be complementary and mutually supportive.
The Economic Context

As I have said, participants at the Summit were in general agreement in their assessment of the current economic situation. Because of that agreement and because such a wealth of information was made public at the Summit, it is not necessary for me to repeat all that now. I should, however, note in passing the more significant information which has become available since the Summit and briefly review the economic outlook as we presently see it. Recently released statistics indicate that: Price inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, remained high in the March quarter; wage increases moderated in the March quarter and real wages declined slightly-however, average weekly ordinary time earnings for full time adult workers were still 2 per cent higher, in real terms , than a year earlier; employment continued to fall in April and, after allowance for seasonal influences, unemployment continued to rise; and the balance of payments has strengthened with capital inflow remaining high.

That latter point-the strength of capital inflow-appears to be associated, at least in part, with some strengthening of optimism and confidence since the Summit. In particular: The somewhat better prospects for the international economy have received further confirmation, including at the meeting of senior Ministers from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries held in Paris last week; widespread rains have broken the worst drought in many areas; the flow of housing finance has continued at the higher level established in February; and interest rates have fallen.

As I noted in my address to the Summit Conference, we expect some improvement in economic activity in the course of 1983-84 with the main impetus coming from: The fiscal stimulus implicit in the Commonwealth Budget for 1982-83 and in prospect for 1983-84; the improvement in the international economy; a marked slowing in stock decumulation so that a greater proportion of increased demand will be met from additional production; the improved prospects for farm production and exports; the pick-up in dwelling construction already under way; and finally, but of fundamental importance, the improved prospects for ongoing moderation of income claims as the prices and incomes accord is implemented. Private sector spending is not expected to improve within that time frame and business fixed investment is expected to fall substantially further before it picks up.

If the expected pick-up in total activity is to be sustained beyond 1983-84, it will be a central task of policy to ensure that this imbalance is corrected; that is, that growth spreads through the private sector as well as the public sector. The expenditure and revenue decisions we have reached have had that consideration very much in mind. We are aware that the improvement in demand will take some time to lead to additional job creation. Accordingly we have given particular emphasis to the early introduction of direct job creation schemes. At the same time our decisions, overall, have been directed to the ongoing requirement of improving the general economic climate. Given that approach, and the implementation of our incomes policies, we would expect the pick-up in activity to be accompanied by a significant reduction in inflation and an improvement in profit levels.
Budget Policies

I turn now to the general objectives we have pursued and the general principles we have applied in reaching our present decisions. At the broadest level, as I have said, the objective has been to frame our budgetary policies to contribute both to reducing unemployment and to winding back inflation. In operational terms, that means looking to fiscal policy to stimulate employment directly but without placing intolerable burdens on the conduct of monetary policies or distorting the general economic environment needed to support the prices and incomes accord. Achieving the right balance is, of course, no easy task.

The Government is well aware that if the balance were not right-if the Budget were expanded too rapidly-there would be increased pressures on interest rates and on the balance of payments. Should that occur, any direct increases in employment flowing from the Budget would be offset-perhaps more than offset-by indirect falls in employment as private sector spending decisions were curtailed . That said, we have come to the judgment that a substantial increase in Budget programs and hence the Budget deficit from 1982-83 levels can occur in 1983-84 without incurring those risks. Fundamental to that judgment is our determination to see the prices and incomes accord implemented along the lines agreed at the Summit and to see that the accord is adequately supported by appropriate monetary policies. I shall have more to say on that later.

We believe that inflationary expectations are already on the wane. It is critical to the success of our expansionary fiscal policies that they remain so. We have had to judge how large the 1983-84 Budget impact should be to meet the requirement of stimulating employment without detracting from our efforts to reduce inflation. And we have to do that in the context of a prospective deficit for next year approaching $10 billion on the basis of the ongoing programs of the previous Government. We have said categorically-and I maintain-that such an outcome is simply not on. It would entail too many risks for the policy of sustained growth that we have in mind, risks connected with interest rates and the balance of payments, and indeed with the safe conduct of the prices and incomes accord. In order to provide for productive job creation activities, while minimising those risks, we have therefore been obliged to offset the additional expenditures involved by rather greater reductions in the previous Government's programs.

In approaching that task we have been heavily influenced by the guidance given by the Summit. In particular, we have focused upon the central concept of equality of sacrifice and, where savings have had to be found, we have sought them in areas where those affected can most readily afford to shoulder the burden. In taxation, our long-standing policy has been to restore equity. We are committed to providing the Commissioner of Taxation with the legislation necessary to achieve that end. In the Budget sittings we will introduce further legislation and will continue to support the Commissioner in this and all other possible ways in ensuring that the tax burden is once again correctly spread across the community. Without this action we cannot expect the community to share with us the view that we all have an obligation to pay our fair share of taxes. Without this action the opportunities for taxpayers to opt out of the tax paying system will continue to grow as they began and were sustained under the previous Government. It is our overwhelming conviction that such a burden sharing approach is in the interests of the Australian community at large and particularly those most affected by the economic recession.
Policy Decisions

In this light the Government has reviewed many of the programs of the previous Government and is proposing a number of new programs. We have placed emphasis on creating new jobs, on increasing activity in the housing industry, on directing assistance to those in need and on removing unwarranted concessions. Many programs we have inherited are ill-suited to meet the current economic problems which Australia faces. They are also poorly designed to meet the needs of low income earners.

We found that a substantial proportion of the costs of tax concessions announced in and immediately prior to the 1982-83 Budget by the former Government-amounting to around $3,000m-first come to account next financial year . The Liberal Government which preceded us went beyond the limits of fiscal responsibility in increasing commitments to outlays and tax expenditures and reducing taxation through 1982 in a desperate attempt to retain office. But even more reprehensibly, it concealed the extent of the fiscal imbalances which it was creating from the Australian people, and arranged for the bills for its extravagance to be presented a year later, in 1983-84. When we have raised these points before, Opposition members have said that they would have changed their policies had they been re-elected. Perhaps they would have; the Australian people remember the fistful of dollars before the 1977 election which was taken back after the election. I have no doubt that the Opposition will find fault with some of the measures that we are announcing tonight. But they cannot have it all ways. If they say that they would taken steps to reduce the 1983-84 Budget deficit by as much as we will do in this statement, or more, then they accept our measures or propose alternatives. What would they have done? What would they have done for job creation and housing? What tax expenditures would they have amended? I look forward to hearing their alternatives.

I outline below the major initiatives of the Government from this initial review. Details of all affected programs are summarised in a paper I now table. Further information is to be provided to Parliament by relevant Ministers.
Retirement Incomes

Retirement incomes are heavily supported from the Budget, both directly through the provision of age and Service pensions and indirectly through generous tax concessions for occupational superannuation. On the outlays side, some of the assistance is directed to high income earners because of the income test-free component for pensions of persons aged 70 and over. On the revenue side, the $2 billion or so of assistance for occupational superannuation goes mostly to people who are neither needy nor poor and largely fails to achieve one of its principal objectives-the promotion of more effective self-provision in retirement. This is because benefits are principally being taken in the form of lump sums rather than pensions. The present tax provisions also facilitate tax avoidance arrangements under which an employee's pay is deferred so as to be taken in a lump sum termination payment at the end of his or her employment in a particular job.

Against this background, the Government has undertaken a comprehensive review of existing policies relating to retirement incomes and has decided to take three significant measures to rationalise the present system. These measures are designed to ensure that outlays on pensions are more effectively directed to those who need them, and tax concessions for occupational superannuation achieve their purpose of encouraging genuine provison for retirement incomes, and that retirement benefits provided in different forms are treated on a fairer basis than in the past.

First, the Government has reviewed the taxation treatment of certain lump sum payments which are presently exempt from tax entirely or are subject to tax on only 5 per cent of the amounts received. In general, and subject to certain exceptions detailed in a paper I now table, lump sum payments received after tonight for services after tonight will be subject to taxation-in most cases at the standard rate of tax of 30 per cent-unless converted into a pension or annuity or rolled over into another superannuation fund within a short time. In order to encourage retirees to use lump sum benefits to secure an income in retirement, such payments will be exempt from tax entirely if converted into a continuing retirement income in the form of a pension or annuity. That part of a lump sum which comprises a person's own contribution which has not attracted a tax rebate or deduction will also be exempt from tax. I emphasise that the proposed fuller taxation of lump sum payments does not apply to payments in respect of services up to the present time. This means that lump sum payments in the years immediately ahead to people who have been contributing to a superannuation fund for some time will continue to be largely exempt from taxation. It also means, of course, that employees need not consider retiring before they would otherwise have done so in order to ensure that the lump sum benefits they have already earned are treated according to the present tax rules . Lump sum amounts in respect of services up to today, whenever in the future they are made, will enjoy taxation treatment no less favourable than they would have received if paid today. The changed taxation treatment of lump sum payments is estimated to yield only $15m in additional revenue in 1983-84, but thereafter gains to revenue will increase by approximately $50m a year to a peak of about $ 420m.

Our second initiative in the area of retirement provision is that we have decided to take action to encourage people to convert assets, including lump sum retirement benefits, into regular incomes. To this end, we propose to amend the Life Insurance Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act along the general lines recommended by the National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry under Professor Hancock and the Taxation Review Committee, the Asprey Committee. This will make it possible for life offices and superannuation funds to sell annuities on more attractive terms than at present. We will also review present arrangements under which the return of capital component of an annuity is taken into account in the age pension income test. The changes we propose to the treatment of annuities, together with the proposed arrangements for exempting lump sum payments from taxation, if used to buy pensions or annuities, will assist retired people to obtain secure incomes during their retirement.

The Government expects that these reforms will help to ensure that tax concessions for superannuation achieve their intended purpose, and reduce present incentives for people who have the capacity to provide their own retirement incomes to arrange their affairs so as to become eligible for benefits intended for the needy. Some technical aspects of the new arrangements in relation to the taxation of lump sum benefits, such as the precise method of determining the portion of lump sum entitlements relating to service before the date of announcement, and the action we propose to take to facilitate the sale of annuities, will be decided after consultation with interested parties, including the life offices and superannuation funds. The consultations will also canvass the possible introduction of new types of securities, including indexed bonds, which could assist the institutions concerned to meet the needs of retired people in ways that are consistent with the Government's objectives.

The third major measure we have decided to take in relation to retirement incomes is to introduce an income test on the component of age and service pensions for persons aged 70 years and over which is presently paid free of any income test. Only persons with substantial private incomes will be affected. Single pensioners with non pension incomes up to $200 a week, and married pensioner couples with non pension incomes up to $333 a week, will continue to receive the same pension as at present. Above these amounts, the current income- test-free component will be reduced by $1 for every extra $2 of non pension income received. Entitlement to part pension will therefore continue for single persons aged 70 years or over with non pension income up to about $303 per week and for married couples with non pension income up to about $505 per week. The proposed new arrangements will come into effect from 1 November 1983 and are estimated to reduce Budget outlays by $167m in 1983-84. For decades successive governments have grappled with the problem of providing decent support for the aged. That problem has been almost totally bedevilled by the way in which the available resources has been sprayed around indiscriminately. The measure I have announced tonight provide a firm basis for the development of a secure system of retirement incomes that aged people deserve.
Repatriation Pensions

In addition, we propose some changes in the method of disbursement of repatriation pension payments. These are currently paid by cheque fortnightly in advance, or by direct credit to a nominated bank, building society or credit union account twelve weekly in arrears. The Government has decided that from 23 June 1983 all direct credits of repatriation pensions will be made fortnightly in advance. Letters outlining the conversion and explaining the arrangements will be sent to veterans.
