Health

The Government's election health policy statement made it clear that the rebate for basic health insurance premiums would be abolished to help finance the Medicare arrangements. It will be abolished in respect of contributions for basic health insurance coverage after 30 June 1983. Premiums paid in 1982-83 to provide coverage up to 30 June 1983 will attract a rebate in assessments for the 1982-83 income year. The resultant savings in taxation revenue are estimated at $95m in 1983-84 and $550m in 1984-85.

At present, the Commonwealth contributes to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund to assist hospital insurance organisations to help meet the cost of the insured chronically ill. The Government's election health policy statement made it clear that on the introduction of Medicare the Commonwealth would reduce its contribution to the Fund. In view of the impending introduction of Medicare, and the budgetary situation, the Government is to reduce by $80m to $20m the intended contribution to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund in 1983-84 .

Under the Pharmaceutical benefits scheme there are a number of multi-branded pharmaceutical products which bear different rates of subsidy. The Government has decided that for such generally equivalent pharmaceutical products, the price differential between the highest and lowest price brands should be reduced as soon as possible to no more than 5c. Savings in 1983-84 are estimated at $6m.
Education

An income test is to be applied to the living allowance payable to full time adult migrant education program students. This will bring treatment of such payments into line with payments to part time students of the program and other equivalent allowances. Savings in 1983-84 and in subsequent years are estimated at around $3m.
Industry-Transport

The maximum cost differential payable by consumers for the freighting of certain petroleum products, at present a 1c litre, will in future be indexed in line with increases in the consumer price index. As an initial step, the differential will be increased to 1.1c per litre on 1 June 1983. This measure will save about $10m in 1983-84.

In lieu of an increase in air navigation charges during 1983-84, the rate of excise on AVGAS and AVTUR will be increased by 2c a litre from 1 July 1983. This will ameliorate the sharp deterioration in the rate of recovery of costs incurred by the Government in the provision of aviation services. This increase will yield $15m in 1983-84. Proposed expenditure in 1983-84 on the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport has been reviewed and estimates have been reduced for 1983-84 by $20m to an estimated $50m. The target date for completion, 1987, has not been affected by this revision. The Government has decided to suspend and defer certain projects under the aerodrome local ownership plan and to institute a thorough review of the costs and benefits of the plan. Savings in 1983-84 are estimated to be $8m.

We shall provide $5m in 1983-84 to complete initial design and route identification works on the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. Commonwealth assistance to the Northern Territory is very generous. In 1982-83, total per capita payments to the Northern Territory will be about $5,600-about five times the average level of per capita payments to the six States. In the light of this , and the significance of the rail project to the Northern Territory, we believe the Northern Territory Government should share with us the cost of constructing the railway. We intend to proceed on the basis that the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory contribute 60 per cent and 40 per cent respectively to construction costs. Part of the Commonwealth's contribution would be funded by transferring about $60m currently allocated to upgrading the Stuart Highway in the Northern Territory. Should the Northern Territory not accept this approach, the Commonwealth would be prepared to provide, in place of the railway, a high standard road link from Alice Springs to Darwin by 1987 and additional rail facilities for Alice Springs to provide an efficient transport alternative. The Commonwealth is proceeding this way in light of the prevailing budgetary situation, and the fact that it is plainly uneconomic to proceed simultaneously with both the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway and the major upgrading of the parallel road link.
Communications

The Government has taken an in principle decision to sell up to 49 per cent of its equity in Aussat Pty Ltd to allow private sector participation in the ownership of the national domestic satellite communications system. The sale will be subject to an appropriate spread of shareholding and to the development of satisfactory arrangements being in place to protect the public interest, which may include regulation of satellite services to ensure co-ordination with terrestrial services. The Government is to increase the interest rate pay- able on that part of the interest bearing capital of Telecom Australia which is still subject to a 10 per cent per annum rate. The increase will provide $100m in 1983 -84. Telecom will determine-with the consent of the Minister for Communications -how to fund this additional payment and the need for an expanded capital program in 1983-84. As an illustration, in a full year the additional interest charge could be met by a one cent increase in the cost of local calls, a commensurate increase in short and medium distance subscriber trunk dialling charges and a $10 increase in annual telephone rental fees. As noted in the paper prepared for the Summit on price surveillance by the Government:

Public utility prices need, of course, to be high enough to cover operating costs, to provide an adequate return on capital, and to produce sufficient internal funds to finance new investment without undue reliance on loan markets: But the community would not expect prices to be raised to accommodate unauthorised wage demands or as an expedient to raise revenue for other Government purposes.
Moreover, when introducing the paper I said that the Government was:
Not seeking to encourage uneconomic pricing arrangements: Public utilities, like private corporations, must earn their keep.
Other Industry Measures

The Government has decided to terminate the special depreciation arrangements for storage facilities for petroleum fuel and the taxation concessions available in respect of conversions or replacements of oil-fired and liquefied petroleum gas-fired plant. These incentives were introduced to provide a short term boost to investment in these areas following the outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war in 1979 . That purpose has been achieved and the concessions will now be terminated.

Since the 1977-78 income year the primary producer averaging provisions have had the effect that tax is calculated at the rate on average income only in years when current income exceeds average income. Ordinary rates are applied in other years. Those arrangements-sometimes described as automatic in-out averaging-attracted criticism for several reasons. The most obvious objection is that they went beyond the objective of removing tax effects of fluctuations in incomes, and gave taxpayers with access to averaging a clear tax advantage over others. As well it became advantageous for those with access to averaging to have their taxable incomes fluctuate and disadvantageous to do anything to stabilise them. That made it impossible for the income equalisation deposit scheme to operate as intended; the in-out averaging threw the system out of gear . Commencing with the 1983-84 income year the rate on average income will be applied every year. The present arrangement limiting the amount of non-primary production income which is subject to averaging will remain. It is estimated that this measure will yield about $15m in 1983-84 and $20m in subsequent years.

There are some unsatisfactory features of the income equalisation deposit scheme other than those caused by the present averaging arrangements. The Government is developing a new IED scheme to provide an incentive for farmers to set aside in good years money for use in poor years. Approval of the Loan Council will be sought for its introduction, with its first application to deposits after 31 August 1983. Some features of the scheme will be outlined in a separate statement which I now table. The measure is expected to cost less than $1m in 1983-84; the budgetary effect in later years will depend on the response to the new scheme.

Under the depreciation measures announced by the former Government on 19 July 1982, depreciation over either 5 years or 3 years was to be allowed under the general depreciation provisions. As part of that package, the period of depreciation of certain primary production plant, including improvements for the storage of hay, grain or fodder, was reduced from 5 to 3 years. The Government this week introduced legislation to honour the previous Government's announcement last year that these provisions would apply from 19 July 1982. However, the Government considers that the reduction to 3 years goes beyond what is reasonable. It is clearly anomalous when compared to the deductions for capital expenditure allowed to other industries. Accordingly, the deduction period for those plant items is to revert to 5 years, with effect for plant acquired under a contract entered into after today or commenced to be constructed by the taxpayer after today.

The Government is mindful of the cash flow problems of many farmers this calendar year in the aftermath of the drought. The extension of the period of depreciation for primary production plant affected by this measure will not have a large effect until the 1984-85 financial year, mainly the first half of 1985. Revenue from this measure is estimated to be $9m in 1983-84, rising to $44m in 1984-85, $89m in 1985-86 and $128m in 1986-87.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Judging from the loud screams from cockies corner, quite obviously some of their money will be in those savings. Following a comprehensive review of the previous Government's water programs, we have decided not to proceed with the supplementary program of the previous Government's proposed Bicentennial Water Resources Program. However, in its preparation of the 1983-84 Budget, the Government will be considering a continuation of the previous Government's National Water Resources Program which has been in operation since 1978-79. We have also decided to allocate funds under our employment generation initiative for the establishment of a Country Towns' Water Supply Improvement Program, and we will be discussing guidelines for this important program with the States in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is seeking Loan Council approval to allow the Australian Wheat Board to borrow overseas to help finance its advance payments to growers. This will allow the Board to reduce hedging costs on overseas sales and to take advantage of any lower overseas interest rates. Subject to Loan Council approval , the Board will be able to borrow overseas up to an annual limit of not less than 50 per cent of its prospective net borrowing requirements. Approval will also be sought if borrowings beyond that level are judged to be appropriat in any year in the light of the prospective monetary situation, the prospective borrowing requirement and borrowing costs. Thus, there is no further need for the interest subsidy which has previously been provided to the Australian Wheat Board's borrowing. Accordingly no subsidy will be paid after 30 June 1983. Savings are estimated to be $19.8m in 1983-84 and about $30m in subsequent years .
Housing

Following discussions at the Summit, the Government has moved quickly and positively to ensure that housing will play a major role in economic recovery. We have been encouraged in this task by the strong co-operation from State governments, the housing industry and the financial institutions. Our plan is responsible. Assistance will be directed only to those in need. We will avoid the risk of overheating in the industry. After very careful consideration the Government has decided to seek to achieve house commencements at an annual rate of 130,000 to 135,000 in the second half of 1983-84.

The housing industry, including the building unions, have clearly indicated to us that this rate should be achievable without significant resource constraints and wage or other inflationary pressures. This will be sought by measures designed to lift both public and private dwelling activity. We will retain the option for the States to nominate part of their Loan Council funds for use in public housing under concessional terms and conditions. So long as we are confident that this does not lead to any diminution of effort by the States in this area of acute need, direct Commonwealth funding for public housing will be increased from $333m in 1982-83 to $500m in 1983-84, an increase of 50 per cent.

We will implement our election promise and introduce the First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme from 1 October 1983. This will provide, on an income tested basis, assistance of up to $7,000 for a family with two or more children, $6,500 for a family with one child and $5,000 for other eligible first home buyers. This subsidy will enable lower income home buyers to borrow more, thus reducing the deposit gap, or to reduce the repayment burden, or both. The new scheme will be subject to the same income test as that applying under the existing Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. The maximum grants will be available to home purchasers with a family income of up to 135 per cent of average weekly earnings with assistance tapering to zero at 155 per cent of average weekly earnings. The test applies to taxable income in the year before purchase. For those purchasing in 1983-84 the limits applying to taxable income in 1982-83 are $24,300 for a full grant tapering to zero at $27,900.

In deciding upon this new scheme, the Government has reviewed the operation of the existing schemes of assistance for home buyers and concluded that they are neither efficient nor effective in targeting assistance to those in most need and in providing a stimulus to the housing industry. In addition, because of the multiplicity of arrangements and their complexity of operation, the existing measures have proved so confusing to home buyers that, in many instances, benefits are not being taken up. The Government has decided therefore,with one important qualification, to terminate or phase out the operation of existing schemes.

The existing Home Deposit Assistance Scheme will be terminated from the date of commencement of the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme. Eligible first home buyers who purchase between today and the introduction of the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme will be able to apply for assistance under the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. Total outlays on the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme, until its termination, and the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme will be $120m in 1983-84, increasing to $165m in 1984-85.

Consistent with our policy of directing Government assistance to those most in need, we will be terminating from 30 June 1983 the housing interest rebate introduced last August by the Fraser Government. This was a highly inequitable scheme, the great bulk of assistance going to high income earners able to take out large loans. The losers were the prospective home buyers on a modest income who received little assistance if they were able to buy a home and none at all if they could not. They will gain from tonight's measures, which will have the effect of putting home ownership within the reach of many more Australians.

In order to meet our social commitments and obligations, we will continue the special home loan interest tax rebate introduced in March 1982 for low income first home buyers who enter the scheme on or before 30 September 1983. The scheme will continue on an income tested basis with the income limits set at the same level as the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme. This will ensure that the lower income first home buyers, who have entered home ownership at a time of high interest rates, will continue to receive assistance to the end of their fifth year of first home ownership. No new entrants to that scheme will be accepted after introduction of the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme.

The full or partial abolition of the previous Government's schemes will save $ 130m in 1983-84 and $420m in 1984-85. In addition to the steps taken to stimulate demand the Government is concerned to ensure that there is an adequate supply of housing funds at reasonable interest rates. We have received assurances from the banks and building societies that they will be able to increase their lending significantly in 1983-84 and against the background of our target rate of commencements, we will be consulting further with financial institutions regarding the availability of housing finance.
Other Tax Expenditures and Concessions

Under an anti-avoidance measure introduced by the former Government, unmarried minors currently pay tax rates of 46 per cent or higher on unearned income above $1,040 per annum. The original announcement indicated that the threshold would be $416, but it was later set at $1,040. The $1,040 threshold has come to be exploited in many tax minimisation schemes, and a reduction in it is necessary to control this. The threshold will be reduced to $416 from the beginning of the 1983-84 income year; the new shading-in range will be from $417 to $1,372. The measure will yield nothing in 1983-84 but $70m in the first full year.

A concessional rebate at the standard tax rate is available to taxpayers on the excess of expenditure over $1,590 on certain eligible items such as superannuation contributions, life insurance premiums, net medical expenses, education expenses and private rates. The rebate costs over $100 per annum but only about 10 per cent of taxpayers derive any benefit from it. It has been decided to increase the threshold amount of eligible expenditure for rebate purposes to $2,000 with effect from the 1983-84 income year. This is expected to result in a gain to revenue of $11m in 1983-84 and $70m in 1984-85.

It has been decided to abolish, as from 1 July 1983, the rebate available on up to $1,000 of dividend income of individual taxpayers which was introduced in the last Budget. While some features in the taxation treatment of dividends, resulting from the interaction of the personal income and company income tax systems, have been criticised in recent studies, such as the Asprey and Campbell reports, the Government does not believe that the dividend rebate introduced by the previous Government was an appropriate or equitable response. In some circumstances the rebate would aggravate rather than reduce inequities. Indeed, it has much in common with a measure which the Asprey report described as an ' unacceptable alternative to the present system'. Abolition of the rebate is expected to increase revenue by $75m in 1983-84 and $105m in 1984-85.

Friendly societies do not currently bear tax on investment income from their life insurance and disability and accident insurance business. This has placed friendly societies at a distinct advantage over life insurance companies and has been a growing cause for concern. With the assistance of tax exemption their business has grown rapidly in recent years, and has involved policies of a kind which are of concern from a tax avoidance viewpoint. The Government has decided that the exemption for friendly societies on life, disability and accident insurance business will be terminated in respect of 1983-84 and later income years. Measures will be introduced to impose tax at a level comparable to that on the non-superannuation business of life insurance companies. Further details will be announced at a later date. This measure will not affect revenue in 1983- 84, but will add to it in 1984-85 and later years, and preserve revenue which would otherwise be foregone.

Generally, interest payable to non-residents from Australian sources is taxable under withholding arrangements at the rate of 10 per cent of the gross amount. There are some exceptions to this rule, two of which were criticised in the Campbell report as having discriminatory and distorting effects. Those two are the 'Australian Entity' exemption and the exemption for interest on borrowing by the Australian Industry Development Corporation.

The Government has decided that interest arising on moneys borrowed under contractual obligations entered into after tonight by 'Australian entities' as defined in the present legislation and by the Australian Industry Development Corporation will be subject to interest withholding tax. Interest on existing loans will continue to be exempt.

Exemption will continue to apply to interest on widely held overseas loans of a 'bearer bond' nature, borrowings by the Commonwealth and State governments, and borrowings by Commonwealth and State authorities where the Treasurer is satisfied that the authorities are not in direct competition with private sector enterprises. It is estimated that this measure will yield $12m in 1983-84 and $ 26m in 1984-85. Under section 77 of the Income Tax Assessment Act losses from exempt activities such as gold mining may be deducted against the taxpayer's income from other sources. From the commencement of the 1983-84 income year those losses will not be deductible. The Government is concerned at the potential that this provision has for tax avoidance uses, of which there are already indications. This measure does not change the current exemption of gold mining income from taxation.
Labour and Employment

The Government is to introduce legislation in the current session of Parliament to establish for a period of three years a Community Employment Program. In 1983 -84 $300m will be provided for this program. It has also been decided to introduce a Private Sector Assistance Program to replace the Special Youth Employment Training Program and to increase funding for other manpower and training schemes. Overall, some $733m will be allocated in 1983-84 for these activities, an increase of $383m or about 110 per cent over 1982-83. The $300m provided for the Community Employment Program, together with $100m for continuation of the wages pause program in 1983-84, will be allocated to projects which have the capacity to provide new jobs, particularly for those most disadvantaged in the labour market.

The objective will be to generate a level of activity in 1983-84 consistent with supporting in a full year 70,000 full time jobs for an average duration of six months. It is intended that the projects supported will lead to improved local community facilities and services, including improved roads and country water supplies. All levels of government and community organisations will participate in the Program, and projects will be selected through joint Commonwealth-State consideration. Special arrangements will apply to projects in the Australian Capital Territory and projects to be conducted by Commonwealth departments and authorities. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will be making a detailed statement on the job creation initiatives by way of a second reading speech on the introduction of the relevant legislation.
Overview of fiscal measures

The new expenditure initiatives I have just announced will add an estimated $ 557m to outlays in 1983-84. The savings I have just announced on the expenditure and tax expenditure programs of the previous Government are estimated to total $ 985m in 1983-84. These decisions take into account the fact that we have a longer term structural Budget problem arising from the policies of the previous Government. We shall have to deal-and we shall-with that problem and, in this connection, I direct the attention of honourable members to the longer term savings involved in many of the measures announced tonight. In total the figures indicate that, on the basis of present estimates, gross savings on the policies of the previous Government will increase to-

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't complain about the level of the deficit.

—Order! The honourable member for Hume has been conducting a continual chain of interjections. I warn him. The honourable member for Hume tries my patience. When he has been warned by the Speaker he should not try to respond.

—I will repeat the figures for the benefit of honourable members. Gross savings on the policies of the previous Government will increase to an estimated $2,036m in 1984-85 and to $2,190m in the following year. Those are significant savings and represent an important initial contribution to the task of implementing the Government's priorities within the context of responsible fiscal policies. I stress again that we view the implementation of our policies, and the review of those of the previous Government, as a continuing process in which the decisions announced tonight should be seen as the initial steps. That process will be furthered in many ways, including in discussion with State governments in the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting at the end of June. In that context, we will be looking to increase the State authorities' domestic or overseas borrowing programs for 1983-84 to ensure that, in conjunction with other measures, there will be scope for real growth in those authorities' capital expenditures next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Concluding remarks

Mr Speaker, I wish to underline the importance which our Government places upon the success of the prices and incomes accord and the monetary policies necessary to support it. By reducing the Budget deficit for 1983-84 below that implied by the policies of the previous Government we will be reducing the financing task and hence the burden upon monetary policy. But that financing task, and that burden, will still be considerable-and will be coming on top of a monetary situation which our predecessors had for some time allowed to drift and which, as a consequence, is already most unsatisfactory.

To take only the current financial year, the previous Government set itself a target for growth in the money supply, M3, of 9-11 per cent for 1982-83, but by March this year that target was already virtually out of reach. In the 12 months to March, M3 increased by 12.4 per cent and the average increase for the year to date was already at the top of the previous Government's target range. Yet the monetary expansion effects of the last Budget are heavily concentrated in the current half year. That is to say, with the real push in monetary expansion from the Budget only just recently coming through, the monetary target had already been allowed to drift out of reach. Monetary growth as rapid as the current level of 12 per cent or so is not consistent with this Government's objectives and prompt action is necessary to bring it down. Accordingly, and in keeping with the previously foreshadowed timetable, the Treasury is announcing this evening the details of a bond tender considerably larger than had previously been thought likely to be necessary. The tender will be for an amount of $1,500m , which is $400m larger than any previous tender. I trust that this will indicate to all concerned our determination to pursue appropriate monetary policies-not merely, as was the case with the previous Government, by rhetoric, but by action.

We are determined, as I have said, to achieve a monetary environment in which our prices and incomes accord will succeed and non-inflationary growth can be sustained. I would like to dwell for a moment on that latter point-the requirements for success of the prices and incomes accord. In particular, I want to deal with the criticisms which have been levelled at the Government from some quarters because it did not, in the course of the Summit, give more support to the type of wage outcomes contained in scenario C rather than those in scenario A.

To refresh our memories, I note that Scenario A assumed a national wage case in the second half of this calendar year leading to a general wage increase of about 3 per cent, to be followed by a return to indexation of wages in the first half of 1984; scenario C, on the other hand, assumed that the wages pause would be continued to the end of 1983, with only partial indexation to follow thereafter.

Accepting all the qualifications which must be placed on such exercises- qualifications which I went out of my way to stress in my own address to the Summit Conference-it is true that scenario C indicated both lower inflation and lower unemployment than did scenario A. The Government does not question that conclusion. We have promoted the need for wage restraint and that approach found acceptance by all participants in the Summit. But it is necessary to look not just at immediate requirements but also at the institution of a prices and incomes policy which can be sustainable over the longer term.

Many of Australia's economic problems in recent years were created by the deliberate tactics of the previous Government around the time of the 1980 election in generating unrealistic expectations regarding the magnitude of the wage increases which industry could afford. It would be equally dishonest and equally disastrous-because it simply would not be sustainable-if we went to the other extreme and sought to deny any wage increases at all this year. That would indeed be, to quote Samuel Johnson, a triumph of hope over experience. It is true that the degree of understanding of these issues has been enhanced by the Summit and subsequent discussions. It is equally true that there is still a long way to go and much more to be done to foster that understanding. It is the Government's view, therefore, that in this as in other matters, there must be a sense of proportion, a sense of balance. The Government, for its part, has pursued that balance-in its approach to the budgetary decisions I have announced tonight and, as I have just indicated, in its approach to the prices and incomes accord. Unless the same balanced approach is pursued by all, however, the consensus reached by the Summit will not endure. In concluding, therefore, may I refer again to the notion of equality of sacrifice which is implicit in the prices and incomes accord and which, as I have already noted, has been a guiding principle in the budgetary decisions I have now announced. I cannot stress too strongly the fundamental importance of that principle in the current economic circumstances.

Some of the changes we have made to the previous Government's programs were overdue and would have been desirable in any circumstances. Some, however, will result in the removal of benefits which might perhaps have been justified in better times. It is the Government's belief that the Australian ethic of a fair go provides the will to share the burden. This was the message that the Government received at the Summit. There is no practical alternative to a fairer sharing of restraint if we are to return to a healthier economy in which living standards can rise and jobs can become available to all Australians.

The Government believes that the measures announced tonight provide for a reallocation of incomes and opportunities which is both fair and conducive to economic recovery. With the consistent application of the principles underlying tonight's measures to our further Budget deliberations and monetary policy decisions, we believe that Australia is now well positioned for national reconciliation, reconstruction and recovery. I commend the measures to honourable members. I present the following paper:
Economy-Ministerial Statement, 19 May 1983.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has set out clearly this Government's approach to the economic and social problems facing the country. Our approach is one of responsibility. It is directed at boosting confidence and restoring growth. It is directed at achieving economic conditions that would enable sustainable reductions in interest rates. Let me make it clear from the beginning that there is nothing that would more guarantee the recovery of the housing industry than a reduction in interest rates. We will move forward in a way designed to achieve this goal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer outlined the many hard decisions the Government has had to take. It is because we have faced up to those decisions that I am now in a position to announce the new housing intiatives in this area which the Government sees as so important. I am announcing these in greater detail than did the Treasurer.

From the start Labor has been determined to ensure that housing plays a key part in our action to get this country moving again. In February this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his economic policy speech, described increased housing activity as a crucial element in Labor's national economic recovery strategy. What a marked contrast this was-and is-to the attitude and actions of our political opponents of the Liberal Party and National Party. They disbanded the Department of Housing and Construction and cast its elements in many directions. We of the Hawke Labor Government have brought it back together again . We are focusing on the aspirations of the Australian people who want good housing. Thanks to Labor, we now again have a Department to achieve that purpose . The re-creation of the Department has also been widely welcomed by the housing and construction industries. Now, only two months after coming to government, we are beginning the process of recovery in this area to meet pressing social needs and to get the industry moving.

We have moved quickly in recent months, but with great care. Our initial plan of action for housing was developed under the watchful eye of my colleague the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) over a period of months leading up to its announcement in November last year. However, we have inherited a situation far worse than was envisaged at that time. Until tonight, the current housing industry situation was bleak to say the very least. Only 106,000 new dwellings will be commenced in the current financial year. This will be the lowest annual level since 1962-63-20 years ago-and compares with 132,300 in 1981 -82 and nearly 150,000 in 1980-81. I am proud to be the Housing and Construction Minister of the Hawke Labor Government which is now moving quickly and responsibly to get recovery under way.

In further developing our plan of action we have consulted with the States and a wide range of housing industry and finance representatives. There were preliminary discussions at the National Economic Summit Conference. On 28 April the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) and I met with top level industry and finance representatives to discuss the Government's objectives and the ways in which these could be met. I continued this consultation process when I met with State and Territory housing Ministers last week. We have listened carefully to their views and, as far as possible, have taken these into account in developing our plans. Against this background, the Government has acted to ensure that housing plays its role as a stimulus to economic recovery. We are putting in place a package of measures designed to boost house commencements from the abysmally low figure of 106,000 mentioned earlier for 1982-83 to an annual target rate of 130,000 to 135,000 in the second half of the coming financial year 1983-84. This progressive lift in activity will mean about 128, 000 dwellings will be commenced in 1983-84-an increase of 22,000 over the miserable 1982-83 figure. The additional commencements will generate an expected extra 25,000 jobs on building sites and in immediate associated industries.

The housing industry has one of the highest direct employment multipliers of any major industry. For every job that is created by our economic and housing policies on a building site, one full job is created in other industries in say, the production of building materials or fittings for homes. It also means more jobs in other areas involved in the housing market-for example, the finance industry and real estate. Of course, there are then flow-on effects in the furniture and whitegoods industries. The housing industry and State Ministers have clearly indicated that our target rate for housing commencements can be achieved without running into labour or material bottlenecks or cost pressures. Our target level of commencements is a responsible one. We are aware of the time lags that can occur between increased demand and new construction. We want a stable housing industry and we are not introducing measures that would run the risk of over-heating the industry.

Our package of measures will provide the housing industry with the balanced stimulus it desperately needs. It makes a start on the enormous task we have set ourselves to ensure that all Australians have decent housing. The Government is taking a firm and responsible action to help the home buyer to overcome the deposit gap and to offset the impact of high interest rates and restore confidence in this vitally important industry. There is strong support for the approach we have adopted. We will continue to work closely with all areas of the industry to ensure that the measures are effective and, most importantly, to make people who are in need aware of the assistance that is available to them.

The package will provide a significant boost to public housing. So long as we are confident that this does not lead to any diminution of effort by the States in this area of acute need, direct funding under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement as the Treasurer announced will be increased to $500m in 1983-84. This will be an increase of 50 per cent on the $333m provided in 1982-83 by the previous Government. We will retain the option for the States to nominate part of their Loan Council funds for public housing. These funds are available, as we know, on highly concessional terms and conditions. In addition, the remaining $ 50m of the savings from the wages pause allocated for public housing will be provided in 1983-84. In total, from these sources, we would expect funding for public housing in 1983-84 to be in the vicinity of $700m compared with $530m in 1982-83. This should enable a significant increase in the level of commencements in the public sector. At the same time, it begins the joint Commonwealth-State task of overcoming the years of neglect of public housing in Australia, particularly those years under the Fraser Government.

Ninety per cent of Australians meet their housing needs in the private market. We will be looking to the success of our general economic policies, our specific measures to boost first home buyer confidence and initiatives in the housing finance area to get the market moving again. To assist the low to moderate income first home buyer, the Hawke Government is introducing the First Home Owners Assistance Scheme. Legislation for the new Scheme will be introduced in the Budget session with a target commencement date of 1 October 1983. The Scheme , which provides assistance on a means tested basis-but does not require qualifying savings-will allow people a choice. A home buyer will be able to take the entire grant as an interest subsidy, or part of the assistance as a lump sum in the first year and the rest as an interest subsidy over the five years. For many people the most favourable option will provide a non-repayable tax-free grant of up to $7,000 over five years for a family with two or more children; $6 ,500 over five years for a family with one child; and $5,000 over five years for home purchasers without children.

Another choice will allow the first home buyer to take advantage of the provisions for a lump sum of $3,500 and interest subsidy of $2,750 over five years for families with two children; a lump sum of $3,000 and interest subsidy of $2,750 over five years for a family with one child; a lump sum of $2,500 and interest subsidy of $1,750 over five years for home purchasers without children. These subsidies will be paid to the lending institutions to enable eligible low to moderate income first home buyers to borrow more to reduce the deposit gap, and/or to reduce their repayments in the first five years of home ownership.

The maximum grant will be available to home purchasers with a family income of up to 135 per cent of average weekly earnings with assistance tapering to zero at 155 per cent of average weekly earnings. The test applies to taxable income in the year prior to purchase. For those building or purchasing a home in 1983- 84 the limits applying to taxable income in 1982-83 are $24,300 for a full grant -about $470 per week, tapering to zero at $27,900-about $540 per week.

The Scheme will be sufficiently flexible to provide realistic assistance to eligible home buyers right across Australia. The ability to use the subsidy to increase borrowing capacity should be of particular help in high cost areas like Sydney where the interest subsidy of $7,000 could be used by a family with two children to borrow say, an additional $10,000 to $16,000 to help overcome the deposit gap. Others may wish to use part of the assistance to meet establishment costs and the balance to reduce repayments in the early years. I am also aware that some of my State colleagues are considering additional assistance to very low income earners which will further stimulate the home building industry in their States. The existing Home Deposit Assistance Scheme will be terminated from the date of commencement of the new First Home Owners Assistance Scheme. However, those purchasing prior to this date will continue to be able to apply for assistance under the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. Estimated total outlays on the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme and the new First Home Owners Assistance Scheme will be $120m in 1983-84, increasing to $165m in 1984-85.

As the Treasurer has announced, consistent with our policy of directing scarce government resources to the more needy, we will be terminating from 30 June 1983 the general tax rebate introduced last August by the Fraser Government. However, the government has decided to retain the March 1982 Home Loan Interest Tax Rebate Scheme for lower income home buyers currently receiving assistance. There will be no new entrants to that scheme after 30 September 1983 but those people currently receiving benefits and satisfying the income tests will continue to receive the benefits. This provision will also apply to people in the first five years of home ownership who were not previously aware of their entitlement in the confusion of the Fraser Government schemes. These measures will ensure that the low to moderate income first home buyer who entered home ownership at a time of high interest rates will continue to receive assistance for the first five years of home ownership.

I turn now to the subject of housing finance. A crucial element in the successful implementation of our housing package is an adequate supply of housing funds at affordable interest rates. During our consultations with the financial institutions we received assurances from the banks and building societies that they will be able to increase significantly their lending in 1983 -84. If we are to stimulate demand from low to moderate income earners and achieve the desirable social object of home ownership then adequate finance must be available at affordable rates. The Government is determined to ensure that sufficient funds are available to meet our target rate of 130,000 to 135,000 commencements.

The Treasurer and I are developing measures, in consultation with the financial institutions, to increase the availability of funds from both the traditional and non-traditional lenders of housing finance. As part of this process we will be giving consideration to a number of options including the proposed Australian housing bonds, the possible development of a secondary mortgage market and some innovative approaches to housing finance.

In summary, we have cut away the confusing, ineffective jumble of schemes put in place by the Fraser Government. We have replaced them with one simple scheme offering the low to moderate income home buyer effective direct assistance at the time it is needed most. Home buyers can choose the mix of deposit assistance and interest subsidy that best meets their needs and the housing market in their areas. But we have also protected the benefits currently going to lower income earners under the first home buyer tax rebate. In doing this, we have developed our programs in close consultation with the housing industry, housing finance institutions and housing consumer representatives before announcing them here tonight. This stands in stark contrast to the Fraser Government's approach of announcing its programs then summoning the industry and demanding their support. It called that consultation. We do not. Ours is real dialogue.

Any assessment of this package of measures outlined tonight leads to the conclusion that they will be of major assistance first, to low to moderate income first home buyers; secondly, to the public housing sector; thirdly, to the housing industry, particularly in terms of stimulating new dwelling commencements and thus employment; and last but not least, to sustained economic recovery. I commend these policies and this statement to the House and to the Australian people. I present the following paper:
Housing-Ministerial statement, 19 May 1983.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Debate (on motion by Mr Fife) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

By introducing this Bill the Government is honouring an undertaking given during the recent election campaign to review the provisions of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme. The changes to the scheme contained in the Bill were foreshadowed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement of 28 March.

The Bill provides for three changes in the scheme. The first change relates to commutation. In future, a retiring member will be permitted to convert no more than one-half of his or her retiring allowance to a lump sum benefit. This contrasts with the present arrangements under which a retiring member may convert the whole of the retiring allowance to a lump sum. The Government believes commutation of the whole retiring allowance conflicts with the basic purpose of the scheme which is to ensure income maintenance in retirement. Of course, members who elect to commute in future will be affected by the changes to the income tax arrangements announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) earlier tonight.

The second change relates to spouse's benefits. Under the law as it stands, commutation of the member's retiring allowance does not affect the amount of the annuity payable to the surviving spouse because the spouse's annuity is calculated as if the former member had not commuted his or her retiring allowance. The Government considers that it is more appropriate to relate the spouse's annuity to the member's residual pension and not the pension that would have been payable had the member not commuted. Consequently, the Bill provides that, for members retiring after the date on which the amendments come into operation, the surviving spouse will receive five-sixths of the residual retiring allowance that would have been payable to the former member. Special provisions have been included in the Bill to ensure that the spouse of a member who commuted under the existing provisions will not be disadvantaged by the new arrangements.

The third change contained in the Bill will impose restrictions on the payment of a parliamentary retiring allowance or annuity to a person who is in receipt of a salary as the holder of an office of profit under the Crown or a pension arising from the holding of such an office. Where the former member or the spouse of a former member receives such a salary or pension, the parliamentary retiring allowance or annuity will be reduced by the lesser of the amount of that salary or pension, or one-half of the parliamentary retiring allowance or annuity disregarding any commutation. For the purpose of this provision, former members and their spouses will be required to give notice of taking up an office of profit under the Crown and provide information about any salary or pension they derive from such an office. The restrictions will only apply to a member who retires from the Parliament after the date on which these amendments come into force, and the spouse of such a member. The existing provisions will continue to apply to those members who have already retired from the Parliament and the spouses of such members.

The Australian Government Actuary has advised that he expects the net effect of these three changes will be a reduction in the overall cost of the scheme. The Bill also contains a number of consequential and other technical amendments. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Moore) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, as outlined earlier tonight by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his economic statement, is the initial step in giving effect to our election commitment to take immediate action to create worthwhile employment opportunities, especially for the record number of Australians now unemployed. The Bill establishes the Community Employment Program with the intention of generating a level of activity in 1983-84 consistent with our objective to provide in a full year, through this program, up to 70,000 full time jobs for an average duration of six months. In particular, the Community Employment Program will be aimed at those most disadvantaged among the ranks of the unemployed who will be least likely to be assisted by employment growth generated by the general economic recovery which will result from this Government's policies.

The Treasurer's economic statement made very clear that Australia's current economic problems are without recent precedent and that the seriousness of the economic situation imposes very real constraints on the Government. Notwithstanding these difficulties, we were elected with a commitment to create jobs and we are determined to fulfil that commitment. The need for such action is desirable at a time when Australia has the worst unemployment since the Great Depression. Seven years of the policies of the previous Government have led to an increase in unemployment of almost half a million with the rate of unemployment in April standing at 10.2 per cent or almost three quarters of a million people. Over this period the average duration of unemployment has risen from around three months to more than seven months at the current time.

The social and economic consequences of this explosion in unemployment have been immense and need no elaboration to any concerned member of this House. These consequences, however, were virtually ignored by the previous Government. The Fraser Government was elected on a promise to provide jobs for all those wanting work. After more than seven years its abysmal failure to fulfil this promise is painfully evident. As the dimensions of its failure become more apparent, the Fraser Government steadfastly refused to accept responsibility for the jobs crisis, but instead sought to shift the blame. Its two most popular scapegoats were wages growth and the international recession. This Government recognises the crucial importance of wage restraint in current economic circumstances, but it is the responsibility of the national Government to provide the environment and the leadership to attain appropriate wage outcomes, as this Government has done. The Fraser Government failed utterly in this regard .

The Hawke Government recognises the difficulties posed for domestic economic management by current international circumstances, but it is the responsibility of the national Government to meet the international challenge head-on, to implement domestic policies which will foster growth in activity and employment, notwithstanding adverse external influences. We are adopting positive policies to overcome the legacies left by the previous Government. Part of these policies is our commitment to job creation measures directly aimed at increasing employment opportunities in both the public and private sectors of the economy. Such policies were steadfastly rejected particularly in regard to the public sector by those occupying the other side of the House except for the one-year program to sugar coat the wage pause. But the need and justification for such policies in the current circumstances cannot be disputed. Most Western governments operate specific employment creation schemes as an integral ingredient of policies to reduce or contain unemployment. Even such a conservative government as the Thatcher Government in the United Kingdom has seen the need to operate specific job programs. Similarly in Australia political conservatives have at times recognised the value and impact of such programs, as is illustrated by the following quotation:

In summary I would like to emphasise that by remaining aloof and closing our eyes to job creation schemes, Australia is at variance with accepted practice in most other Western countries. Certainly overseas experience appears to indicate that such programs are worth while. Further more their merit is even more underlined by the likely continuation of high levels of unemployment in Australia. Most likely there is room for some mixture of private sector wage subsidy schemes and public sector project employment. It would seem that detailed planning, a slow build-up and a large measure of local involvement would ensure a good chance of successful implementation.

This ringing endorsement of job creation programs came from none other than the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, in a letter to the former Prime Minister in June last year. Certainly this Government agrees with the Queensland Premier on this issue. Our commitment to job generation has also been endorsed strongly by all groups at the recent National Economic Summit Conference.

This Government will adopt a two-fold approach to directly assisting the unemployed through action, first to create jobs and second to provide the unemployed with the training needed to fill the jobs which will be created through a sustained economic recovery. The Community Employment Program, along with our housing package outlined earlier tonight are first steps in the process . This program will involve the Commonwealth Government in constructive partnership with the States, local government and community groups to provide worthwhile and productive jobs in both the public and private sector, on projects of social and economic benefit to the community, for those unemployed Australians hardest hit by the recession in the labour market.

It should be painfully evident to honourable members that there is a vast amount of such worthwhile and productive work, of social and economic benefit, which needs to be done in Australia at the State, local and community levels and that there are record numbers of unemployed Australians, men and women, who can, and want to, do that work. Our program will provide the framework and financing to bring forward from all areas within the community projects which will provide such work.

As I have already said, our objective is to generate a level of activity under this program in 1983-84 consistent with supporting in a full year up to 70,000 full time jobs for an average duration of six months. Up to twice the number of jobs can be expected to be created indirectly by the increased demand for goods and services and the higher incomes resulting from implementing the program. As a basis for achieving this objective, the Commonwealth Government intends to allocate $300m to the Community Employment Program in 1983-84. Of that amount $ 50m will be set aside for job creation programs through Commonwealth departments and authorities. The remainder, including the Jobs on Local Roads initiative, under which it is proposed to allocate $70m to enable local governments to construct and maintain local roads, will be allocated to projects sponsored by State and local governments and community organisations. A sum of $20m of this amount will be for project activity involving water supply improvement programs in country towns.

In addition to the allocation to the Community Employment Program the Government will continue to meet commitments under the wage pause program set up by the previous Government. This will add a further $100m to job creation measures in 1983-84. Despite reservations about the adequacy of this program in fully meeting our job creation objectives, it is our view that pre-existing agreements under this wage pause program should be honoured.

Consistent with our election commitment, the Commonwealth under the Community Employment Program will provide the bulk of funds to worthwhile projects to pay for wages and other costs. The Commonwealth will, however, be seeking on a State basis, a contribution of 30 per cent of total costs from project sponsors. This will allow all sectors to make a contribution towards overcoming our employment legacy and will mean the creation of a greater number of jobs. The Commonwealth, though, will remain flexible on this matter. We will be prepared to accept greater contributions towards meeting up to 49 per cent of the cost of projects where such funds are available. On the other hand, we will be prepared to provide up to full funding where a desirable project is in danger of not being able to proceed without such Commonwealth funding. Funds appropriated under this program will be allocated among the States and Territories on the basis of population, with the exception of funds allocated to Commonwealth departments and authorities and 40 per cent of the funds allocated to road programs. This 40 per cent portion of road funds will be distributed on the basis of a formula under the Commonwealth Roads Grants Act. Apart from this allocation, priority will be given when approving projects to areas experiencing especially severe unemployment problems.

The Commonwealth will direct and oversight the program, through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations but the States and the Northern Territory will be responsible for the administration of the program within their boundaries, although not of course for those projects conducted by Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities. I will be having early discussions with the States to reach agreement on these administrative arrangements so that the program can be implemented from July 1983. I am confident that the States will approach these discussions with the urgency and commitment to help the unemployed which this Government has demonstrated by initiating this program.

Committees comprising Commonwealth and State officials, local government, community organisations and interested groups will be established in each State and Territory to consider projects for approval. They will consult widely in the community as to what type of projects are needed and they will give assistance where necessary, to interested groups in developing projects. Final project approval will remain with me or my nominee. To be eligible for approval projects would have to conform to the following guidelines: Projects must be labour intensive, offering work for at least three months and a maximum of one year in the first instance at appropriate minimum award rates; projects must involve high Australian content, non-Australian content would be limited to 20 per cent of all projects in a State or Territory; projects will need to involve activities leading to productive output and permanent jobs, or provide services of permanent public and community value; projects will have to provide worthwhile work experience and/or training opportunities to enable participants to enter the normal work force; and projects must also be additional to those planned and would not otherwise have been funded under normal budgetary conditions. Those eligible for participation must be Commonwealth Employment Service registrants who have been out of work for at least three months, with priority then being given to those who have been unemployed for at least nine months, those who have never worked-particularly the very disadvantaged of the labour market, such as Aborigines-and those for other reasons in need of immediate employment. Equal access should be provided for females under the program, which in some instances may necessitate special measures to ensure that women receive an equal share of the jobs created. Finally, vacancies for projects funded under the program must be lodged with the Commonwealth Employment Service.

To ensure that the program makes the most efficient use of resources to meet our objectives, there will, after an initial period of operation, be a joint Commonwealth and State evaluation conducted by the Bureau of Labour Market Research in conjunction with the States concerned. These guidelines will be the basis of a more effective and equitable job creation package than that provided by the wage pause program. Like the wage pause program, the Community Employment Program will contain provision for equal access to work by men and women alike and ensure that Aboriginal Australians and other particularly disadvantaged groups are catered for. However, the Community Employment Program, through its giving of priority to those out of work for long periods, and its insistence on adherence to the guidelines, in contrast to what has been happening under the wage pause program, will be more tightly targeted to those most disadvantaged in the labour market. In addition, the program's administration will be streamlined and more effective and greater provision will be made for direct involvement of local government and community groups.

The Community Employment Program does not represent the end of our job creation activities. Our election program forshadowed the introduction of a Private Sector Assistance Program to provide training and employment opportunities in the private sector. We intend to proceed with this program during 1983-84. As part of the process of introduction of the scheme we will be conducting a broad review of all existing training and assistance programs to ensure that they fully meet the Hawke Government's objectives in this area. The overall result will be, however, a substantial increase in the Government's commitments to employment and training activities. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has already indicated, total expenditure in 1983-84 in this area will be $733m-an increase of 110 per cent on the funds provided on these crucial programs during 1982-83. This figure is clear evidence of the Governments' commitment to provide greater job opportunities for all Australians. The Community Employment Program is the first step towards fulfilling that commitment. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Steele Hall) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill to amend the income tax law will give effect to some of the taxation proposals announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tonight. The Government's reasons for making those and other changes are set out in the statement and it seems unnecessary for me to go over the same ground again in this introductory speech. The measures included in the Bill affect taxpayers in the 1982-83 year and, for administrative reasons, need to be given immediate legislative effect. A further Bill covering the balance of the taxation initiatives announced tonight will be introduced in the Budget sittings. Among concessions being terminated by this Bill are the two year write-off for the cost of converting oil-fired plant to an alternative energy source and the 40 per cent conversion allowance for the cost of non-oil-fired plant installed to replace oil-fired plant. As indicated in tonight's statement, neither of these deductions will be available where the expenditure is incurred under contracts entered into after today or the conversion work is commenced after today. The special 100 per cent depreciation allowance for petroleum fuel storage facilities will also cease in respect of facilities acquired under a contract entered into after today and facilities that the taxpayer starts to construct after today. In a case where fuel storage facilities continue to qualify for the special write-off, an additional eligibility requirement will be that they be in use for the purpose of producing assessable income or installed ready for use for that purpose before 1 July 1984.

Amendments proposed by the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 that is already before the House will give effect to certain concessions for primary producers announced by the previous Government. By that Bill the special rate of depreciation on a range of primary production plant, including structural improvements for the storage of grain, hay or fodder, is to be increased from 20 per cent to 33 1/3 per cent, broadly with effect from 19 July 1982. As announced earlier this evening, this overgenerous 33 1/3 per cent rate is to be discontinued and the 20 per cent rate reinstated. The 20 per cent rate will, however, apply only to eligible plant and improvements acquired under a contract entered into after today or which the taxpayer commenced to construct after today.

To clear the way for implementation of the Government's Medicare policy, the rebate for basic health insurance contributions is by this Bill to be discontinued in respect of premiums paid to secure cover after 30 June 1983. The Bill also makes provision, as part of an overall package of measures to apply in the housing area, for the termination from 30 June 1983 of the income tax rebate introduced by the former Government in last year's Budget. That rebate, which applied to the portion of interest payments that exceeded 10 per cent per annum on loans of up to $60,000, was quite inequitable in the way it directed assistance away from those most in need. The earlier-that is, the March 1982- home loan interest rebate will, of course, remain in the law and legislation to modify it as proposed by the Treasurer this evening will be introduced in the Budget sittings.

As regards interest withholding tax, this Bill also gives effect to the proposal to withdraw the general exemptions from withholding tax in respect of interest on the overseas borrowings of so-called 'Australian entities' and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The exemption now available in respect of interest on overseas borrowings of Australian resident companies by way of widely distributed bearer debentures issued overseas will not be disturbed and, as I will explain later, new provisions will maintain exemptions for government and government authority borrowings affected by the withdrawal of existing exemptions. Withdrawal of the two exemptions will apply to interest on loans raised in pursuance of contractural obligations entered into after today. Interest on existing loans will not be affected.

In addition, interest on any loans which are raised in pursuance of contractural obligations entered into after today, and which meet the requirements of the existing law, may continue to be exempt, but only where the interest is paid on or before the date on which the legislation is enacted and is attributable to that interim period. Exemption of interest on the overseas borrowings of the States, and of Commonwealth and State authorities, which are raised in pursuance of contractural obligations entered into after today will be maintained by the new provision. Exemption from withholding tax for interest on external Commonwealth loans at present operates where there is a determination by the Treasurer that exemption should apply in relation to the loan. The Bill provides for this procedure to apply also to borrowings of the States, and of Commonwealth and State authorities. The Bill provides, however, that a certificate will not be given if the funds from a particular borrowing will be used by an authority in direct competition with private sector enterprises. A memorandum explaining the technical features of the Bill will be made available to the House and I think that I need to say no more at this stage about the details. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Moore) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

There was general agreement at the National Economic Summit that an Economic Planning Advisory Council-known as EPAC-should be established to continue the process of co-operation and consultation begun at the Summit Conference. The purpose of this Bill is to put this commitment to co-operation and consultation into effect. Through EPAC the Government will have available to it, on a continuing basis, independent advice from State Governments, industry, unions and community groups which will be invaluable to the process of economic policy formulation. However, this information flow will not be just one way. The public release of a large volume of Government information prior to the National Economic Summit is evidence of the fact that the Government is firmly committed to knowledge sharing. The Government is convinced that such knowledge sharing plays an integral part in establishing a common perception among various community groups regarding the causes of, and possible solutions to, Australia's economic difficulties.

The Bill before the House defines the functions of the Council and invests it with sufficiently wide powers to enable it to execute its functions. Provisions are made for the Council to express its views freely and to have its own independent secretariat. It is important that EPAC be constituted as a statutory body in order to provide the Council with the status, permanence and stability it needs to do its job effectively. It is also important to ensure that EPAC is as independent as possible of any department of government, and statutory status is necessary to achieve this.

The functions of the Council are defined in clause 6 of the Bill. In essence, the Council's role will be to act as a vehicle for community participation in the development of Government economic policy. In particular, it is intended that the Council will: Draw together the views of community representatives on prospective economic conditions and appropriate economic policies; indentify feasible and desirable goals and targets for the economy as a whole; provide perspectives on the medium and longer term economic outlook; and develop policies to help realise the maximum growth potentialities of the economy and assist in the achievement of sustained economic growth.

These functions will allow the Council a very wide charter. In addition to acting as a vehicle for knowledge sharing and policy consultation, EPAC will enlarge our knowledge base. In part, this will be through its basic research activities, which will be directed at fundamental problems facing the economy. As well, it is intended that EPAC will, after it has found its feet, undertake what we have called indicative planning, that is, it will advise on feasible and desirable economic goals and on policies to realise the economy's maximum growth potentialities. The Government considers that it is of considerable value for the nation to try to assess the longer term trends and to seek to influence those trends in a desirable direction. The Council will have seventeen members, including three Commonwealth Ministers and three State Government representatives. For this purpose the Northern Territory will be treated on similar terms as the State Governments. In addition, one member will be selected in consultation with local government organisations, three in consultation with business, one in consultation with rural industry, four in consultation with trade unions, one in consultation with welfare organisations, and one in consultation with consumer and community groups. The State Government representatives will be nominated by their respective governments. The representation of the States will be arranged on a rotating basis, with rotations every two years. For non-government members, it is the Government's intention that they will, after an initial phasing-in arrangement, serve for four years. The latter will be appointed by the Government after consultation with relevant organisations as set out in the Bill. Non-government members will be selected on the basis of those who are best able to contribute to the work of the Council rather than as nominees of organisations.

To discharge its important functions, the Council is to be provided with appropriate powers, listed in clauses 7, 8 and 19 and 22 to 24 of the Bill. The Council will be able to conduct inquiries and collect information on any aspect of its functions. Clause 7 contains provisions in regard to the publishing of reports. While the clause provides that the minister may refrain from publishing a report or may publish a report with deletions if he considers that to do so is necessary to protect the public interest, it is the Government's intention that this power be exercised only if there are overwhelming reasons in the national interest for so doing. The Government remains committed to knowledge sharing with all members of the community.

The Council will be able to consult widely with Commonwealth and State bodies and with commercial, industrial, consumer, welfare and other organisations. The Council will have powers to engage consultants to conduct studies for it and to arrange with the Commonwealth and State authorities for officers of those authorities to be available to assist the Council. The Council will also be able to form committees of Council members and others, who will conduct investigations on behalf of the Council and will report their findings and recommendations to the Council. These powers should enable the Council to meet its responsibilities adequately.

The legislation gives the Council the necessary degree of independence so that its advice can be provided to Government freely and without unwarranted influence. Clause 6 of the Bill provides that the Council, in deciding which matters it should consider, shall consult with, but shall not be bound by the views of, the Commonwealth Government. The Bill also provides that the Commonwealth members will not vote when the Council is deciding on the advice to be given to the Commonwealth Government in a policy report. These provisions will make sure that EPAC's advice is truly at arms length from government. Provision is also made for the recording of minority opinions although it is the Government's expectation that, as far as possible the Council will endeavour to find a consensus in its opinions.

Another important area where independence is ensured is in the staffing of EPAC . It is intended that EPAC will be served by professional staff in an independent secretariat. The staffing requirements will be a matter for negotiation with the Council when it has been established. The staff are to be employed under the Public Service Act, but clause 22 of the Bill provides specifically that staff members shall perform their functions and duties in accordance with the directions of the Council. The budgetary costs associated with the establishment and running of EPAC, which will mainly reflect the costs of staffing and maintainng the secretariat, will be met in full by the Commonwealth Government.

The foregoing represent the more important purposes of the Bill. There are, in addition, the usual provisions of a Bill of this nature concerning the appointment, terms of office, payment of expenses of Council members, and acting members and related matters. The Council will meet as necessary to perform its functions. A Council member will be required to disclose any interest he may have in any matter under consideration by the Council where such an interest would conflict with the proper performance of his functions. Unless the Council determines otherwise, such an interest will debar the Council member involved from taking part in any decision on the matter in question and from being present at any discussions on that matter.

I would like to thank the members of the representative working party that was set up following the National Economic Summit for their assistance in mapping out the most appropriate form for EPAC. It is by efforts such as this that the spirit of consultation and co-operation established by the National Economic Summit will be maintained. The Government believes that there is an overwhelming case for establishing an effective economic policy advisory body in Australia as an independent and permanent statutory authority. Nothing less will properly safeguard the status, permanence and stability of EPAC. This Bill provides the necessary safeguards. I commend the bill to the house.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Petrol Pricing-Drought Assistance-Proposed Senior Citizens Centre, Willetton-Job Creation Programs-Economic Statement-Fraser Government-'Youth Work' Employment Program-Chilean Refugees

PROCTEXT.PARA: Petrol Pricing-Drought Assistance-Proposed Senior Citizens Centre, Willetton-Job Creation Programs-Economic Statement-Fraser Government-'Youth Work' Employment Program-Chilean Refugees
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my electorate of Petrie there are 73 service stations. These include lessees or licensees of major oil companies, owner dealers and commission agents. They all have one thing in common. Their lives are controlled by the major oil companies. I received a delegation of these men at my electorate office last week and the story they had to tell me was absolutely astonishing. They, of course, are the people the public blame for the price of petrol. The public does not generally realise the power that the multinational oil companies have over the people who put petrol into their cars.

SPEECH.PARA: The first problem of the petrol retailers in my electorate concerns the price at which petrol companies sell their petrol to distributors.
