Just to take a notional case of what might be and what undoubtedly has been happening at some time or other, let us say the petrol company was selling petrol to retailers at 39.9c per litre. This would be the maximum wholesale price set by the Petrol Products Pricing Authority. Retailers might, in those circumstances, have wanted to sell at 42.9c per litre in order to give themselves a margin to pay costs. However, because of circumstances in the industry at the time, the sale price to the public might have been 37.9c per litre. That would mean, of course, if that were the end of the story, that when the retailers sold their petrol to the public they would sell at a loss. This is because when there is a petrol price war the major oil companies do not tend to lower their wholesale price. Instead, they pay a subsidy to the retailers.

In the hypothetical case we are considering, the oil companies might subsequently reimburse service station proprietors 4c a litre. This means that in the long run the petrol retailers make a profit from the sale of their petrol . However, it is less than they would have got in an open market situation. Moreover, they have lost their cash flow and they are out of pocket for the time being. This obviously leaves a great deal of scope for manipulation by the petrol companies. They have the petrol retailers in their power by virtue of the subsidies which they pay, so petrol retailers are not in fact free to engage in healthy competition to provide a service to the public. They are forever looking over their shoulders at the policies of the major oil suppliers who control them .

A further difficulty arises from the fact that the price at which the major oil companies choose to sell their petrol to retailers is subject to variation by petrol companies. There are instances in my electorate where the same major oil supplier sells petrol at different prices to different retailers whose service stations are situated very close to one another. This power is used to compel service stations to go into self-service. Obviously then the major oil suppliers have tremendous power over ordinary service station proprietors. For example, I have been told of one case of a service station proprietor who did not wish to go into self-service but, rather, wished to continue a full service operation, partly in order to help subsidise the job of one of his employees engaged in pumping petrol. He intended to charge an extra one cent for the full service, a service which motorists were able to choose whether they wanted. The petrol company, however, insisted that if he charged an extra one cent for the full service he would have to lose one cent of the rebate. This, of course, meant that he would be providing full service at no profit whatever. Even those proponents of the free enterprise system sitting opposite would have to agree that this is not exactly an open market situation. Surely, if there were members of the public who were prepared to pay an extra one cent per litre for the benefits of the full service they should have been allowed to do so. However, in this case the oil suppliers would not allow them that choice, a choice which, incidentally, would have kept a man in a job.

There is another dimension yet of the plight of service station proprietors in my electorate and elsewhere. There are people in the trade called jobbers. These are people who buy petrol from the major oil suppliers and sell it inter alia to service stations. However, these people are the tools of a particularly invidious form of competition between the major oil suppliers. The major oil companies sell fuel to these jobbers at a price less than that at which they sell to ordinary service station operations. However, they sell fuel to the jobbers on the understanding that the jobbers will not sell it to the leased sites of the oil company selling them the oil. In other words, oil company A sells fuel to jobbers with an agreement that they will not sell fuel to sites leased from oil company A. So the jobbers are expected to go out, having bought petrol from a particular petrol company, to try to sell this petrol to the leased sites of other major oil suppliers. However, at the same time, the major oil suppliers make it perfectly clear to their own lessees that if they are caught buying petrol from a jobber rather than from the oil company from which they are leasing, their lease will be terminated. In other words, the dealings of the major oil companies with the jobbers are based on a strange double standard. They are prepared to allow their own petrol to go to sites leased from other major oil companies but they are not prepared to allow the petrol of other companies to go to the leased sites which they themselves have. The only person that takes any risk in this form of competition is the service station proprietor who loses his lease if he gets caught buying petrol from a jobber rather than from his own petrol company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to register my extreme concern at the Government's virtual silence on the drought. It was significant tonight in the mini-Budget announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that no assistance measures were mentioned. Despite election promises we have heard nothing substantial from the Government on new drought aid measures or on post- drought assistance. We have had a few limp reassurances like that given recently by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the National Farmers Federation. But assurances are not detailed explanations of election promises to which farmers are entitled.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Government's election promises and, in so doing, remember that they were made in February-March at a time when the drought situation throughout the nation was extremely grave. We were promised additional drought aid measures and the utilisation of a range of tax rebates to encourage producers to protect themselves against drought. We have not heard one word about those since the election. The silence demonstrates a gross abrogation of responsibility on the part of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). All he has done is announce that pumpkins and citrus pulp are eligible for the fodder subsidy. The Prime Minister has shown himself to be equally irresponsible . While the Minister was overseas, the Prime Minister, in answer to a question in the House, announced that a review of drought relief arrangements was being undertaken for consideration by the Government. Frankly, that is not good enough . Promises were made without any accompanying details. Australia's primary producers should have been given the details immediately the Government assumed office. They have heard nothing of substance.

The Prime Minister, in his rural policy speech, promised that a Labor Government would provide drought measures to ensure that all types of farmers receive equitable treatment. Again, we have heard no more about that. In his prepared address to the National Farmers Federation, the Minister for Primary Industry devoted a massive one paragraph out of a 12-page statement to the subject of drought. All he said was that the Prime Minister had reaffirmed that the Government would continue to provide assistance to drought affected farmers. The Government does not seem to realise that, following recent good falls of rain in eastern Australia, many farmers are urgently asking whether the Commonwealth fodder and interest payment subsidies will be continued after drought declarations are lifted.

The previous Government made a firm undertaking to continue the interest payment subsidy for one year beyond the lifting of drought declarations. We made that abundantly clear so that farmers knew where they stood. This Government has said absolutely nothing. The truth is that the Government has not got a clue about what it is doing. Its Ministers are contradicting each other every day. The Minister for Primary Industry has performed some of the greatest contradictions on record with regard to drought aid. He accused the previous Minister of implementing bandaid assistance when the fodder and interest payment subsidies were introduced. He criticised the complexity of the necessary application form. But then he must have realised that he would not win any votes because farmers welcomed the drought initiatives. The National Farmers Federation in its 1982-83 annual report stated that the Commonwealth drought aid measures, together with improvements and extensions to the core measures, comprised the most comprehensive package of drought relief in Australia's history.

So Labor went to the election not only supporting the drought measures and undertaking to maintain them but also promising to extend them. Nothing has been said since and farmers have every right to view the Government's promises with utter cynicism and contempt. Tonight's announcement that the Bicentennial Water Resources Program is to be scrapped is the last straw to the man on the land and to those people who are faced with drought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to urge favourable consideration of a funding application to the Department of Health for assistance to build an autumn or senior citizens centre in Willetton in my electorate of Tangney. The need for this centre to be stage one of a three stage project has been well documented. There will be a significant boost to local employment as a result of the construction. The project has been planned by the Canning City Council which already owns land on Herald Avenue suitable for the entire complex, including well-aged and frail-aged accommodation. The first stage for which funding is now being sought involves a meeting place where aged people still living in their own homes can socialise and enjoy indoor activities. Attached will be a dining room and kitchen. The kitchen will initially serve 100 meals a day within the centre and prepare 200 meals on wheels a day. Indications are that this will very quickly grow to a total of 400 meals a day.

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of this stage of the project, including site costs and furnishing, is estimated at close to $1.2m. The Council has applied for a Commonwealth grant of $770,000, a State grant of $20,000 and will provide $420,000 itself. The catchment area will be all of the city of Canning south of the Canning River, an area with a present population of 35,000 to 40,000. The area is a mix of older housing and a new housing area experiencing rapid growth. A demographic study conducted by the Council has revealed a high proportion of well-aged people living in their own homes, substantially in the older area. Overall, 12.5 per cent are aged 55 and over. This indicates an immediate population of 4,385 who would benefit from the centre. Population predictions are for a total catchment of over 45,000 by the year 2000, while demographic trends indicate a rising proportion of aged residents.

By the year 2000 the proportion of people aged 55 and over is expected to be 16 per cent giving a total population of users of over 6,500. The well- aged people in the existing population will provide the users for stage one of the complex for which funding is now sought. As these people grow older they will add to the demand for specialised aged people's accommodation and especially frail-aged accommodation which will be provided by the subsequent stages of the project. People moving into the planned accommodation will continue to use the stage one autumn centre facilities which will also come to be used by the population of the newer housing area as it ages.

I have already commended Canning Council to this House for its concern with facilities for the aged and its foresight in planning them. The current project is another fine example of that. The Council has used demographic research to isolate present needs which in the future will be much more urgent. 'Planning for tomorrow must begin today' has become a trite expression, not least among politicians. But here we are presented with a ready made opportunity to put the maxim into practice. I hope we can face up to the challenge so that future generations will be thankful to us.

Unfortunately it seems that an amount of red tape is threatening to engulf the project, along with some unfortunate circumstances. After being acknowledged by the Department in October of last year, it seems the file on the Council's funding application was lost. There were further delays when an officer appointed to examine the proposed site was first taken ill and later transferred . Further hold-ups seem to revolve around the size of the grant applied for, which is more than the normal, although I suggest that the scope and imagination of the project is more than normal, and the inclusion of escalation allowances, which will necessarily be incurred in construction, in the grant cost estimates.

As I have explained, the need for this centre has been carefully documented. It forms an element in an overall plan for care of its aged by the City of Canning. It will bring great pleasure to many thousands of elderly people as well as daily hot meals, and ultimately specialised accommodation. The need for the centre will only become more critical if we delay and the costs will escalate. Citizens who have worked throughout their lives contributing to society should be able to expect some facilities for use in their old age, just as we provide facilities for sports people and for youth. Earlier, I mentioned the boost to local employment which this project will provide and I will conclude on that note. Construction would take about eight months, employing more than 150 people on site and another 300 off site on tasks such as prefabrication. Of course, there would also be a substantial spin-off throughout the business community. On completion, the first stage of the project will employ a permanent staff of about eleven. Again, I commend this most worth while and urgently necessary project to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been most impressed by the job creation scheme proposed by the city of Knox, one of the municipalities in my electorate of La Trobe. Knox was quick off the mark in providing a program of work projects with a high labour component which can be funded from the Federal Government's Community Works Job Creation Program. Indications had been given that 75 per cent of the funds would be made available for local government and the Knox Council must be congratulated for producing a scheme with alacrity and which contains a labour component comprising 78 per cent of the total cost of $870,000 .

SPEECH.PARA: The stated objectives of the Council have been firstly, to complement the objectives of both the Federal and State governments to generate job creation, work experience and training due to high unemployment and the economic downturn; secondly, to use the funds made available as a result of the wage freeze; and, thirdly, to maximise the availability of Federal, State and local government resources to provide employment opportunities for the citizens of Knox.

The city of Knox has a high proportion of young people between the ages of 15 and 19 years and over 6,000 people between the ages of 20 and 24 years. It is an area which has been one of the hardest hit by the economic downturn because of its high level of manufacturing industry. Although the unemployment level for the city of Knox is slightly below the Victorian average, there are 3,000 people registered as unemployed. The projects submitted by the Knox Council have taken into account the following factors: Firstly, the availability of personnel from the Commonwealth Employment Service, together with training and employment grants; secondly, guidelines under the State Government employment initiatives program; thirdly, actions which will provide a meaningful contribution for the Knox citizens through services, information, future savings and improved decision making; and fourthly, the objective to maximise manpower resources to gain maximum job opportunities.

The Knox submission details 23 projects which have been developed providing 1, 871 man weeks of employment valued at $677,069 within 23 trade, labour or professional fields, or 77.8 per cent of the total cost of $870,694. The intention is to allocate job demands under various positions to provide each person employed with at least six months work and/or job experience and training . The projects are considered suitable for council funds and eligible for financial assistance from the State Government's employment and training schemes . In addition, many could be eligible for financial assistance from the Commonwealth's Community Works Job Creation Program.

In the short time I have available I would like to give an indication of the kinds of projects which have been created by the Knox City Council. First of all , there is a playground for disabled children. The aim is to develop a sub- regional playground with the specific needs of disabled people in mind. the playground will provide innovative and challenging experiences for disabled children. The intention is to build this playground at a suitable location in Knox, thereby providing an environment where disabled children and those more fortunate can mix freely. The work that will be provided will be for carpenters and labourers.

Another project which has been created is landscaping for the Basin triangle. This project will provide a community focus for the Basin township in the form of landscaped gardens within the Basin triangle. Here again, there will be work for carpenters and for labourers. Another proposal is the Boronia flood mitigation scheme. This is a scheme to upgrade the drainage system in the vicinity of Boronia township to accord with current design criteria. Commercial and multi-unit residential development and additional associated road works have increased the storm water run-off to a point where storms of intensity well below normally accepted design standards cause flooding. In this case, work is provided for professional and civil engineers, project supervisors, survey assistants, concreters, drainers and machine operators.

Another scheme is the bicycle path overpass. The aim is to establish an A grade separated crossing at Forest Road which would allow the extension to the cycle way development that presently utilises railway land to the north. Again, this will provide work for carpenters and labourers. The Collier reserve scheme relates to the development of a pleasant park and rest area for travellers through the city of Knox on this important site on the north-west corner of Stud Road and Burwood Highway. This will provide work for a number of labourers.

I wish that I had more time to detail the rest of these most creative projects. I commend the Knox Council for its initiatives and I trust that its submission will receive the support of the Federal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the House has been in session for the past three weeks all we have heard about from the Opposition is the broken promises of a 10 -week-old government. I think it might not be a bad idea if I reminded the House about the long line of promises made and broken during seven successive years of Liberal Government. I could not cover them all in five minutes but I will give honourable members a sample. In 1975 the then Leader of the Liberal Party said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will maintain present levels of assistance to Aborigines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you a school teacher?

—I ask the honourable member to listen. The cumulative real loss to Aborigines in progressive Liberal Budgets amounts to $416.5m. Involved in these real losses have been: Aboriginal health spending, currently 23 per cent less than in 1975; Aboriginal education funding, down 37 per cent on 1975; Aboriginal housing funds, down an estimated 54 per cent on 1975; and community management and services funds have accumulated a real loss of $185m since 1975. So much for the promise to maintain the levels of assistance to Aborigines. in 1975 the then Leader of the Liberal Party went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We will ensure that where children are in greater need because of educational disadvantage, they will receive extra financial support.

Following this promise the disadvantaged schools programs funds actually fell during the seven years of Liberal Government. In 1978 the Liberals announced that an annual rate of inflation of 5 per cent was within our grasp by mid-1979 and that it would go on falling under its policies. By mid-1979 the inflation rate was 10.7 per cent-more than double the rate promised. In 1977 the Liberal Government said that a 2 per cent reduction in interest rates in the next 12 months was a target that could and would be achieved. By the end of 1977 new housing loan mortgages from savings banks were at an interest rate of 9.25 per cent to 10.5 per cent. They fell to 8.75 per cent in mid-1979 but then climbed back to 13.5 per cent in 1981. Nevertheless, successive statements from the Government kept telling us that interest rates would continue to fall. As we know, they did not. They have not and they will not except under this Government . In 1977 Mr Malcolm Fraser, in his elction speech, said:
We have reduced taxes-revived incentive and restored fair reward for achievement.

Those were very hollow words. The Fraser Government was the highest taxer in Australia's history. It was responsible for increases in health insurance costs, higher home mortgage repayments, record income taxes and higher indirect taxes. Incidentally, without the Senate it would have introduced a whole lot more areas of indirect taxes on a whole new range of goods. In 1975 the Liberal Government said that it would fully index personal income tax for inflation over three years. In 1981 indexation was abandoned altogether. Again, in 1975, the Liberals said:
Our reforms will give back to people money they earn by their own hard work.
In reality total tax has claimed an increasing proportion of national income from 1975 to 1983. The burden has, as usual, fallen on the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer. In 1977 the Liberals said:
Unemployment will fall from February and will keep falling.

In 1975 approximately 180,000 people were unemployed. The figure is now well over 700,000. It will be up to the Labor Government to keep faith with the army of unemployed. It is worth noting that 4 per cent of the 15 to 19 year-olds were unemployed in 1974. We now have 20 per cent unemployed in that age group. So much for the promises of the previous Government.

Mr Fraser said that Medibank would be retained. It was abolished. Since that promise was made Medibank has become muddlebank. It was refurbished, remodelled, restructured, rehashed and reheated time and time again and always against the community interest. The Australian Assistance Plan, which was abolished, will be reintroduced. The Australian electorate grew tired of promises from the Liberals . The election on 5 March confirmed this. The people elected us because they knew we have the will to try to undo seven years of careless government. They elected us because they know we will concentrate on the two things which are most important to Australia today-economic growth and jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The newly elected Labor Government likes to present itself to the Australian electorate as having a monopoly over compassion and concern. In regard to the situation of unemployment it has made significant noises at this stage at least about the concept of community based employment programs. I wish to place on record the history and the success of a community based employment program in my electorate with which I was very intimately associated known as Youth Work. A group of us established Youth Work back in 1979 when we perceived there was a very real problem of finding adequate employment and training opportunities in the future for a range of young people, many of whom, for no reasons related to themselves, were obviously going to have difficulties in fitting into the realities of a difficult employment situation. We found in our electorate and elsewhere in Sydney, especially in parts of the western suburbs, that a large number of young people had not received adequate education. Because of this their opportunities, when it came to a competitive situation, were obviously limited. We worked on the principle that the first thing we had to do was give these young people the opportunity to re-establish a sense of self-esteem, of self-value, of achievement, of belonging to the community and of giving through that three-part operation. We had to give those people the opportunity of feeling that they had a contribution to make to society as a whole. We believed that we had to create within the community, firstly, a sense of accepting that there was a problem-I have to say that was not always an easy thing to achieve-and, secondly, that no government of any colour could possibly overcome the fundamental problems of unemployment alone; that it was simply not adequate to say to the Australian people: 'Trust in us and we will do everything for you. You merely have to wait back and take the benefits of our policies'. The fact of the matter is, that as we established the success of this program during those four to five years, and as subsequent events in Australia and overseas have shown, no Federal or State government which is unable to convince the electorate as a whole of the need to work together on these sorts of problems will be able to find adequate answers to them. The program which we established with the full financial support of the Commonwealth Government at the time, known as Youth Work, worked on the principle of giving young unemployed people who had been out of employment for a period of at least six months-they were referred to us principally by the Commonwealth Employment Service officers-the opportunity to enter into a 17-week work training program. The basis of Youth Work worked on the principle that we establish a charitable organisation which was in fact a limited liability company. The young people who joined Youth Work were brought in as part owners and managers of that company. Perhaps that was one of the reasons we were so successful. Since 1979 we have successfully trained about 130 young people. We have a success rate in placing them of over 70 per cent.
—One hundred and thirty; what about the other tens of thousands?

—I accept that. The point I am trying to make is this: Programs of that nature, if they were multiplied right across Australia in every community within the Australian work place, based on the principle that governments alone cannot solve the problems of unemployment without the full co-operation of the people, then I believe we will be getting to the crux of the problem. The fact of the matter is that the young people who have gone through this program have been given the opportunity to gain a range of skills. We have managed to get the full support of the private sector in the electorate. It has positions available for the young people. They have been given the opportunity of being in a work place type environment. From that, as I said, the principle objective to rebuild their sense of self-esteem has been achieved. In addition to the specific ongoing work opportunities, we also give the electorate as a whole the opportunity on an individual basis to make a contribution by giving these people work for which they are-
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to draw the House's attention to the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) yesterday in this place in which he referred to the intake of refugees from Central America under the previous Government. In the last year there were only 100 refugees from this region. The Minister was followed by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister to exercise the greatest care in allowing people into this country from that continent. The Minister is dealing with something which has the potential to prove extremely serious, if not explosive, within our Australian community.
On page 667 of Hansard the honourable member is reported as saying:
I repeat, where the decision is good it will be approved-
He was referring to Mr West's statement-
but I caution the Minister in relation to South America. I do not need to say much more on that matter.

To me that is an outrageous statement, for a person who claims in this place to be a humanitarian. I consider the statement to be racist in the extreme. On the eleventh of this month a general strike was called in Chile, and one of the most oppressive actions taken by the Chilean military leadership against the people of Chile occurred. There were demonstrations in the streets by school children, women and workers. The military shot dead a 15 year-old boy for daring to stand on the footpath to observe parents and workers marching down the street. The people who took part in the demonstrations committed such great crimes as marching down the streets, banging pots and pans together, honking their car horns and refusing to send their children to school! Red Harrison, in a segment of the AM program of 16 May called 'Dawn Raids in Chile', stated that more than 2,000 men were called from their beds just after 4 o'clock in the morning and taken to a football field for questioning. Warren Duncan, the Australian Broadcasting Commission journalist, reported that at least 120 of those people were in fact arrested. Police also arrested a further 350 people, according to an AAP-AP report.

In another protest four lawyers were charged after 200 people demonstrated inside a court house. It is reported in the Press that the 200 people were beaten by the military justice guards. If these people are justice guards, I would hardly think their role is to go around beating up innocent citizens. According to the Santiago newspaper, Mercurio, a 22-year-old man was shot after uniformed police had fired on a group of demonstrators in a working class neighbourhood. The Minister for the Interior stated that because of the strike and demonstrations he would be taking legal action against the trade union leaders of that country.

I commend the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for indicating in a statement in this place that he intends to allow more refugees from a place such as Chile into this country. I would like the Minister to instruct our representatives at our embassy in Chile to make the services of that embassy available to people who are being persecuted and to allow them to come to this country as refugees. The honourable member for Denison stands condemned. Once again he has performed badly here this week. I suggest that he has had a very bad week this week, and he probably will have a worse one next week. He stands condemned for his statements in the House yesterday, which were nothing more than racist. Those statements were aimed at a people who are being persecuted by a harsh and cruel government in Chile.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11.5 p.m.
